Chapter 1. Introduction

The Department's mission is to build a stronger and more competitive Canada, to support Canadians in making choices that help them live productive and rewarding lives, and to improve Canadians' quality of life. Our work touches Canadians at every stage, from learning to employment to parenting to retirement. Through partnerships with businesses, community organizations, cities, provinces and territories, the Department collaborates with others to deliver targeted support for Canadian children, youth, workers, seniors, the homeless, Aboriginal people and persons with disabilities.

The Department relies, in part, on Grants and Contributions (Gs&Cs) to succeed in its mission to enhance the well-being of Canadians, and to promote national economic growth and productivity.

The Operations Guide is a practical, online reference tool meant to guide program delivery staff in delivering effective Gs&Cs programming. It is a generic resource that broadly applies to all project-based Gs&Cs initiatives (rather than individual, one-on-one agreements) and, as such, provides:

  • an overview of the work context;
  • a detailed explanation of the project life cycle;
  • clear descriptions of program delivery staff roles and responsibilities;
  • step-by-step procedural instructions; and,
  • links to reference materials such as current legislation,
  • regulations, terms and conditions, policies, directives,
  • branch-specific resources (where available online) and other supporting materials.

The Operations Guide is not a stand-alone document and must be applied in conjunction with various Directives, Guidelines, Policies and Legislation, in addition to the Common System for Grants and Contributions (CSGC) which guides administration and management of all Gs&Cs programming.

Additionally, a Policy for Portfolio-Wide Training for Grants and Contributions Practitioners has been implemented within the Department. Information and other useful tools in support of the policy can be found on the Centre of Expertise Training Page.

1.1 Project Life Cycle and Structure of the Guide

The project life cycle approach is a way of organizing the major steps involved in moving from one phase of Gs&Cs program administration to the next. It simultaneously provides the overarching context for program delivery while guiding program delivery staff through each of the phases involved in the process to support achievable outcomes while remaining transparent and accountable for the use of public funds.

Despite its distinct phases, the project life cycle is not a linear process. Each phase is related to every other phase in the cycle, and not simply to the phase immediately before or after. For example, clear and consistent assessment practices make the recommendation, review and approval phase transparent to organizations. Meaningful agreements with clear objectives and anticipated results lead to efficient payment and activity reporting, and monitoring practices.

Throughout the project life cycle, program delivery staff often revisit and revise tasks within the phases based on the changing needs of the community or of the Department, or as a result of lessons learned from monitoring and evaluation activities.

Each phase of the project life cycle becomes an opportunity for program delivery staff—working together as a team—to manage Gs&Cs effectively and improve results for Canadians.

Planning
In the planning phase, program delivery staff is responsible for determining how to implement programs to respond to identified needs and government priorities.
Application
In this phase, applicants develop applications that would be eligible for funding. Program delivery staff is responsible for reviewing applications for completeness and identifying areas that require further development.
Assessment
In the assessment phase, program delivery staff completes several key responsibilities: assess the applicant, project activities and budget, determine if an environmental assessment is required and conduct risk assessments.
Recommendation and Approval
In the recommendation and approval phase, program delivery staff prepares a recommendation for a project to obtain approval for funding.
Agreement
In the agreement phase, program delivery staff prepares schedules for the agreement, explains the agreement to recipients and obtains appropriate signatures.
Payments and Financial Management
In this phase, program delivery staff identifies the information required for reports and procedures for processing claims. Contribution Monitoring (Activity, Financial ∓ Results Monitoring)

In this phase, program delivery staff is responsible for conducting activity, financial and results monitoring based on the assessed level of risk associated with each project.
Close-Out
In this phase, program delivery staff is responsible for final project evaluation and the steps taken to close out a file.

Structure of the Guide

Following some introductory material about Roles and Responsibilities and Transfer Payments, the Guide is structure. to follow the project life cycle common to all Gs&Cs programs—whether delivered nationally, regionally or locally—across the Department while also recognizing that individual regions, branches and programs often customize these administrative practices to suit the unique needs of their targeted clientele. In essence, this Guide describes the stages program delivery staff must follow when soliciting, assessing, recommending, approving, preparing, implementing, monitoring and closing agreements.

  1. Introduction
  2. Role of Program Delivery Staff in Administrating Grants and Contributions:. This section addresses the roles and responsibilities of the Program Delivery Staffing during the Project Life Cycle, the communication protocol with applicant and recipient and the segregation of duties.
  3. Transfer Payments. This section addresses the types of transfer payments.
  4. Planning: This section addresses how the Department sets goals, develops strategies and outlines actions and timelines for meeting those goals. Planning follows a logical process to determine what actions should be taken to address identified needs.
  5. Application: This section addresses how to solicit and develop proposals, ensure complete applications and acknowledge their receipt.
  6. Assessment: This part of the process includes steps to assess the applicant, the application and the budget.
  7. Risk Assessment: This section addresses the Risk Assessment, Management and Mitigation tool and demonstrates the importance of considering risk throughout the project life cycle.
  8. Recommendation, Review and Approval: The approval process from recommendation to approval for funding.
  9. The Funding Agreement: This section outlines the steps followed to prepare the agreement documents and obtain the signatures.
  10. Activity Reporting and Payment: This section aids in identifying the information required for reports and to process claims.
  11. Monitoring and Mitigation Strategies: This section provides information on activity, financial and results monitoring in addition to mitigation strategies.
  12. Close-out: This section covers the final project evaluation and the steps taken to close-out a file.

1.2 The Common System for Grants and Contributions

The Common System for Grants and Contributions (CSGC) and its associate. CSGC User Guide is a web-based application available on the Department's Intranet system. When used in tandem with this Guide, these online tools help program delivery staff administer, deliver and monitor Gs&Cs programming.

The system was originally designed to meet the needs of the Department's business lines, following the project life cycle and the client cycle, and continues to be modified to reflect new business processes as the Department improves the efficiency and effectiveness of Gs&Cs programs.

The CSGC has two modules:

  1. the Project Life Cycle (PLC) is used to administer grants and contributions; and,
  2. the Client Module is used to pay benefits to individuals through grants, contributions and other services delivered by the Department.

The content of this Guide largely corresponds with the use of the first CSGC module, following the project life cycle approach to move from one phase of project administration to the next.

The CSGC is also linked to the Department's financial management system (SAP) for the administration of payments, program budgets, expenditures and commitments.

The CSGC supports program delivery staff's work by:

  • reducing the need for paper documentation (e.g. printed notes to file);
  • organizing information in searchable files that can easily be retrieved;
  • ensuring compliance with:
    • program terms and conditions
    • TBS Policy on Transfer Payments
    • operational policies
    • program guidelines;
  • standardizing forms;
  • strengthening financial management;
  • facilitating the generation of reports;
  • making it easier to track and demonstrate program and project results; and,
  • providing an audit trail and tracking capacity.

While carrying out Gs&Cs activities, one should simultaneously consult both this Guide and the CSGC User Guide, as they are complementary—yet distinct—guidance components of the project life cycle.

Chapter 2. The Role of Program Delivery Staff in Administrating Grants and Contributions (Gs&Cs)

Before beginning to work through the operational requirements of delivering Gs&Cs programs, it is important to understand:

  • the overall context of departmental program delivery planning and how it affects the work of program delivery staff;
  • the roles and responsibilities throughout the project life cycle of program delivery staff;
  • the segregation of duties and how it further defines these roles and responsibilities; and,
  • the appropriate manner to communicate with Applicants and Recipients.

2.1 Roles and Responsibilities during the Project Life Cycle

Whether programs are delivered nationally, regionally or locally, program delivery staff are responsible for the effective administration of Gs&Cs throughout the project life cycle. These responsibilities may include, but are not necessarily limited to:

  • contributing to national/regional/local strategies for the use of grants and contributions funds;
  • promoting programs in the community;
  • developing, assessing, negotiating, and recommending projects for approval;
  • administering agreements with individuals, communities and organizations;
  • ensuring that transfer payments are made in a manner that complies with the Financial Administration Act , the Treasury Board Policy o. Transfer Payments and the Policy on Commitment Control, Account Verification and Payment;
  • monitoring and evaluating project activities – especially using . risk-based approach which takes into consideration knowledge of the organization;
  • providing guidance to funding organizations to ensure effective implementation of agreements;
  • liaising with other departments, when necessary, for project development or to avoid duplication;
  • engagin. stakeholders, both internal and external to the Department, on program priorities and specific projects;
  • facilitating and participating in the development of partnerships with a broad range of government and non-government organizations in order to achieve common objectives;
  • providing National Headquarters (NHQ) and Regional Headquarters (RHQ) with status reports and project summary information, as required;
  • recommending community representatives for NHQ/RHQ stakeholder engagement committees;
  • sharing lessons learned and success stories; and,
  • ensuring Government of Canada visibility through projects.

Although the information found within this Guide mainly pertains to the tasks of program delivery staff , there exist, of course, a number of other positions which directly support the program delivery staff and the delivery of Gs&Cs programming, including Managers, Senior Development Officers, Business Expert Managers, Business Expert Consultants, etc…

2.2 Communication Protocol with Applicant and Recipient

The following communication protocol supports the existing escalation process for Gs&Cs programs and provides consistent messaging when responding to enquiries from applicants or recipients about the status of their application or request for amendment in cases where the projects are pending approval. The Communication Protocol with Applicants and Recipients also includes steps to be followed to escalate complex cases.

Key Message

The following standardized key message is to be used when program delivery staff communicates with applicants concerning projects pending approval:

"Your application is currently being processed. Following the assessment of applications, applicants will be notified in writing whether their project has been approved."

The following standardized key message is to be used when program delivery staff communicates with recipients concerning amendments pending approval:

"Your request for an amendment is currently being processed. Following the review and assessment phase, the Department will contact you once a decision is made."

In addition to this messages, program delivery staff may remind applicants and/or recipients that any expenses incurred prior to the start date, or approval date in case of a major amendment, are at the applicant's and/or recipient's own risk and costs and will not be reimbursed by the Department.

Documentation – Note to File

All requests from applicants or recipients concerning the status of their application or amendment request are to be noted in the Common System for Grants and Contributions (CSGC). A "Note to File" must include: the name of the applicant or recipient representative, contact information (address, telephone and email); the date and time of the interaction with the Department; and the nature of the interaction.

Referring Calls to Managers

If, over the course of any interaction with an applicant or recipient, program delivery staff determines that concerns are increasing, they are instructed to courteously advise the applicant or recipient that the matter is being referred to a manager. Staff will then inform the manager of the matter as per normal escalation processes in order to address and/or resolve the applicant's or recipient's concerns.

Escalation

In cases where an applicant or recipient contacts program delivery staff and staff determines that the applicant or recipient's concerns regarding their application or amendment pending approval are escalating, program delivery staff should refer the matter to their program manager via email. The program manager must assess the applicant's or recipient's concerns based on information provided by staff. If the applicant or recipient continues to express concerns or dissatisfaction with actions taken, and the manager ascertains that the applicant or recipient will escalate their concerns higher (i.e. contact the program director or other program officials, a Member of Parliament or the Minister etc.), the program manager must notify the program director immediately via email. The program director will advise the appropriate NHQ program director and follow the normal escalation process.

To support appropriate accountability and ensure optimal issue management, regional and NHQ program delivery and management staff involved in the escalation of problematic files must brief their superiors on emerging issues and ensure that the systematic documentation of facts and relevant information is done as a "Note to File" both in the paper file and in the CSGC.

2.3 Segregation of Duties

The segregation of duties is an internal process that strengthens the Department's program delivery within the community. In practical terms, it ensures that no one program delivery staff member independently executes all activities of the project life cycle for an assigned file, this would entail an appropriate division of roles and responsibilities between those who review and approve applications, and those who approve payments, monitor project progress and deal with performance issues during the life of an agreement. Segregation happens between the program delivery staff who assesses the application for funding and the program delivery staff who manages the agreement. The segregation of duties can occur after the Recommendation and Approval phase or once the agreement is signed. PDS should check with their manager or their program-specific guidelines to confirm where segregation occurs for their program.

This practice:

  • guarantees no single employee has simultaneous access to financial functions that should be segregated, such as the input and approval of a payment;
  • helps program delivery staff avoid conflicts of interest;
  • strengthens departmental accountability and transparency for Gs&Cs funding;
  • standardizes the steps involved in Gs&Cs administration; and,
  • improves program efficiencies.

The segregation of duties is one component of the Department's delivery of Grants and Contributions designed to improve program and project outcomes while ensuring national consistency and accountability.
Managers are accountable for coordinating the assignment of files and for ensuring that the segregation of duties is being properly defined for all program delivery staff.

Segregation of duties is managed differently across the spectrum of departmental programs. Please ask your team leader/manager how the segregation of duties is applied within your program.

Segregation of Duties Model

Although interpreted in various ways across the Department, a common form divides the project life cycle into two discrete phases, as per the example outlined here:

 

Front Office:
Application Management		 Back Office:
Agreement Management & Close-out
Application (The Funding Agreement)*
Assessment Payment & Activity Reporting
Risk Assessment & Management** Risk Assessment & Management**
Recommendation, Review & obtain Approval Monitoring. & Mitigation Strategie.
(The Funding Agreement)* Close-out

. Shared responsibility: The segregation of duties can occur after the Recommendation and Approval phase or once the agreement is signed. Program delivery staff should check with their team leader/manager or their program-specific guidelines to confirm where segregation occurs for their program.

** RAMM can be shared between the Front and Back Offices depending on the program area.

Under this segregation of duties model, program delivery staff are responsible for either the Application Management (referred to as Front office) or the Agreement Management and Close-Out (referred to as Back office).

Functions can be rotated among program delivery staff on a file-by-file basis -- for example, one could complete the Application Management phase for project A, but undertake the Agreement Management phase for project B. Alternatively, program delivery staff could specialize in one function or the other -- for example, one may concentrate on the Application Management function while another focuses on the Agreement Management.

While certain programs are not subject to the departmental Segregation of Duties Directive; they do, however, follow the spirit of the directive. Regions will determine how they will implement the principles of segregation of duties according to their resource levels and regional structure. File assignments should be done as applications are received and should ideally not change throughout the screening and assessment processes.

Chapter 3. Transfer Payments

Transfer payments are transfers of money, goods, services or assets made from an appropriation to individuals, organizations or other levels of government, without the federal government directly receiving goods or services in return.

The Department facilitates community capacity building by contributing programs, services, expertise and information that improve skills, expand learning opportunities, create jobs, develop support services, disseminate information, and engage citizens in the social and economic development of their communities through transfer payments. Projects funded by the Department will ultimately support the vision, mission and mandate of the Department.

There are three types of transfer payments:

  • grants;
  • contributions; and,
  • other transfer payments.

To read about the general conditions which must be met for all projects funded by specific programs, refe. to the Treasury Boar. Policy on Transfer Payments and its associated Directive.

3.1 Grants

Grants are unconditional transfer payments that the Government provides to individuals or organizations for activities that meet eligibility criteria set by the funding program. It is a transfer payment which is not subject to being accounted for or audited, but for which eligibility and entitlement may be verified. The applicant may be required to report on results achieved.

Grant funds can be either statutory or non-statutory.

A statutory grant is set out in statute by parliament with a specific funding amount, recipient (or class of recipients), and purpose. Terms and Conditions are not always required for a statutory grant, nor are projects generally assessed. A recipient is able to receive the grant simply by meeting eligibility criteria described in the statute.

A non-statutory grant is created and governed by a set of Terms and Conditions approved by the Treasury Board. They are similar to contribution programs and are generally project based. A recipient must apply and be approved for funding by the Minister (or delegate) prior to payment rather than simply being eligible.

For a first-hand look at the basic requirements relating to the administration of grants, refer to the Treasury Boar. Policy on Transfer Payments and its associated Directive, including Appendix D: Terms and Conditions for Grants and Appendix F: Funding Agreement Provision for Grants.

3.2 Contributions

A. Contributions

A contribution is a conditional transfer payment to an individual or organization for a specified purpose, the conditions of which must be defined in a contribution agreement. The contribution is subject to being accounted for and audited.

All contribution funding agreements share the following features:

  • a conditional agreement is signed by both parties (i.e. the Department and the organization);
  • the organization must account for expenditure categories and funding amounts; and,
  • the Department has the right to audit an organization's use of contribution funds.

For a first-hand look at the basic requirements relating to the administration of contributions, refer to the Treasury Boar. Policy on Transfer Payments and its associated Directive, including Appendix E: Terms and Conditions for Contributions and Appendix G: Funding Agreement Provision for Contributions.

B. Contributions to Aboriginal Recipients

Contributions to Aboriginal recipients are very similar to contributions to all other organizations or individuals. They must be for a purpose specified in a formal funding agreement and the Aboriginal recipient must account for the use of the contribution funds. For some programs, the Department uses Flexible contributions for Aboriginal recipients.

Flexible contributions are used frequently in programs targeting Aboriginal organizations. They are used when there is a two or more year agreement and the recipient requires the flexibility to move expenditures and funds between fiscal years. Funds unexpended at the end of a fiscal year may be transferred to the next fiscal year. Any unexpended funds at the expiry of an agreement must still be returned to the Department. Flexible contributions must be specifically listed as an option in program Terms and Conditions and must be based on recipient need. Flexible contributions can only be made to aboriginal recipients.

For a first-hand look at the basic requirements relating to the administration of contributions to Aboriginal recipients, refer to the Treasury Boar. Policy on Transfer Payments and its associated Directive, including Appendix K: Transfer Payments to Aboriginal Recipients.

C. Contributions to Provinces and Territories

In many programs provincial and territorial governments are eligible recipients, but the program is not intended for devolution to the provinces and territories for their own delivery (like in the Labour Market Agreements or Employment Benefits and Support Measures.) In these contributions a provinces and territories should be treated the same way as any other applicant to the program, regardless of additional flexibilities in the directive on transfer payments.

3.3 Other Transfer Payments

Other transfer payments are transfers to other levels of government or transfers to foreign recipients. Both are generally funding agreements, although grants may be used where appropriate or set out in statute (as in a statutory grant).

Examples of other transfer payments would be the Labour Market Agreements (LMA), Labour Market Development Agreements(LMDAs) and Labour Program who has agreements with foreign recipients.

For a first-hand look at the basic requirements relating to the administration of other transfer payments, refer to the Treasury Board Policy on Transfer Payments and its associated Directive, including Appendix J. Transfer . Payments to Foreign Recipients.

3.4 Sources of Funding

Consolidated Revenue Funds (CRF) is the Government of Canada's bank account which combines all public monies received by the federal government, such as GST, income tax. It is from this fund that departments receive their funding. In our department, CRF pays for Operations and Maintenance (O&M) costs, service contracts, and supplies as well as for some grant and contribution programs.

The Employment Insurance (EI) account is a designated account and is used for income benefits and payments to individuals (through EI Part I), provide employment benefits and aid to gaining employment (through EI Part II), and supports a number of employment programs;

Money from the EI account cannot be used to fund anything that is not legislated under the Employment Insurance Act and approved through the annual EI Expenditure Plan submitted to the Treasury Board on an annual basis.

Chapter 5. Applications

The application process must be fair and transparent, thus helping to ensure that all applicants have equal access to program funds.

There are five key steps to this stage of the project life cycle:

  1. application intake;
  2. developing applications;
  3. ensuring complete applications;
  4. receiving and acknowledging applications; and
  5. opening the project file.

Application Intake

The method chosen by a program to accept applications will depend upon a number of factors such as the funding stream, community priorities and needs, availability of service providers, geography, requirements of the program’s terms and conditions, the amount of funding available and stakeholder expectations.

Information on funding opportunities can be found on the Funding Programs website which provides a central point of access to all grants and contributions programs offered by the Department.

Programs can receive applications in many ways, including:

  • Continuous Intake
  • Call for Concept (Expression of Interest/Letter of Intent)
  • Call for Proposals
  • Solicited Applications
  • Unsolicited Applications

Whatever the process chosen, it must be based on the principles of fairness, openness and transparency. Applicants should also be reminded that they are not entitled to departmental funding until a legal agreement has been signed by both parties. No costs can be incurred and no activities can take place before the start date of a signed agreement. No matter the process selected, any applications granted an extension beyond the identified deadline must be noted on file and justification for accepting late submissions be documented.

Continuous Intake

Continuous intake entails a process where a program’s funding criteria are made available to the public on a long term basis with no specific deadline for the submission of applications. Applicants can therefore submit an application for funding at any time, which the program then processes on a first come, first serve basis.

Call for Concept (Expression of Interest / Letter of Intent)

Most often, this method is a formal process where organizations are invited by the Department to submit a proposal based on program initiatives. The call for concept can also be used as a screening mechanism or to develop a list of potential applicants. Once the Call for Concepts have been reviewed, applicants may be requested to submit a complete application.

Call for Proposals

A Call for Proposals (CFP) is an open, formal and planned process used to:

  • identify interested, qualified applicants;
  • inform potential applicants of a new program delivery requirement via a proactive, targeted marketing approach; and
  • request the submission of a formal application for funding.

A CFP is based on the Department’s national, regional or local program business plan.

The application package for a CFP typically includes the following key information:

  • an outline of the program objectives and priorities;
  • an invitation to submit proposals;
  • the eligibility criteria;
  • the required elements of a proposal;
  • the deadline for submission;
  • a description of the review and selection process; and
  • a description of service standards.

Once approved, a CFP is posted on the Department’s Internet site on the Funding Programs landing page; other dissemination options could include regular mail, email, and advertising in national and local newspapers.

For additional details on the CFP process - including information on exceptions for entering into a CFP process, please consul. th. Call for Proposal page on the Centre of Expertise website.

Solicited Applications

A program occasionally solicits applications from individual organizations; this may occur, for instance, when an unanticipated situation arises requiring a rapid response or following a call for concept process. There are several ways in which applications can be targeted. One could, for example, create a list of individuals and organizations with a proven track record in delivering effective programs and services, then use this list to contact potential applicants—in person, by phone, mail, email or fax—and invite them to submit an application. Potential contacts can be identified by:

  • reviewing other office lists;
  • searching the CSGC for past and current funding organizations;
  • brainstorming with colleagues who know the sector or community and its clients well;
  • engaging umbrella organizations including asking for their membership lists; and
  • consulting with other departments and agencies.
Unsolicited Applications

The Department may receive unsolicited applications at any time.

Applicants often approach a variety of funders in the hope of securing financing for their initiatives. They may also submit an application to the Department rather than a specific program when they believe they have a good idea but they don’t know where it fits. Generally, the applicant has not been approached by the Department but has heard of the program through word of mouth or their own research.

Depending upon the program, if an application appears to meet a program’s criteria and procedures, the applicant could either be informed of any CFPs, or engaged and provided with feedback as required.

If, however, an application has merit but falls outside the scope of the solicited program, the applicant should be referred to appropriate programs within the Department or to other departments.

5.2 Tools

Receiving Applications via Grants and Contributions Online Services (GCOS)

Within your program area external organizations may be able to apply for funding using GCOS. The GCOS provides applicants and recipients with a safe, secure and user-friendly environment to apply for funding online.

Once an Application for Funding has been successfully submitted by an applicant via the GCOS, it is automatically routed to the appropriate Cost Centre (CC) within the CSGC staging area based on the program selected and postal code (where applicable).

For more information on the CSGC Staging Area please refer to the Online Services Toolkit on the COE Website.

The Applicant Guide

The Applicant Guide will assist applicants in filling out the standard Application for Funding form by providing organizations program specific clarification on the level of detail required to complete the application.

Program areas determine what level of information is contained in their respective version of the Applicant Guide (as each program has specific eligibility requirements) and determine which Budget Detail Template to attach as an annex.

The Applicant Guide :

  • is program specific;
  • specifies the level of information required to complete each section;
  • provides the appropriate Budget Detail Template for that program;
  • stipulates costs categories;
  • outlines eligible costs; and
  • outlines the level of detail required to assess the application.

The program specific Applicant Guide outlines the documents and information that are required to be submitted with the Application for Funding:

  • application for funding;
  • business and GST/HST number;
  • amounts owing to the Government of Canada
  • project description and details (including, if applicable, supporting documentation);
  • budget; and
  • any additional information listed in the Applicant Guide.
The Application for Funding

The Application for Funding may be submitted using a paper application or through GCOS. When submitting a paper application, it must contain at least one original signature.

Applications submitted online must follow GCOS signature requirements. Please refer to the GCOS Account Registration User Guide for additional information.

For more complex applications, applicants may be requested to include additional information or documentation. These additional requirements would be stipulated in the Applicant Guide.
The Application for Funding contains the following information:

  • Part 1 – Organization (organization identification, contact and capacity)
  • Part 2 – Project (identification, description and details)
  • Part 3 – Funding (anticipated sources of contribution, budget and budget details)
  • Part 4 - Declaration
Part 1 – Organization

This section of the application establishes the organization’s identity, contact information and collects tombstone data.

Business and GST/HST Number.

As a legal entity, a business is assigned a Business Number by the federal government; each identifying number is unique to a specific business. Businesses are required to provide their Business Numbers to the Department when entering into an agreement.

If applicable, when asking an applicant their Business Number and their GST/HST number, the nine-digit first part as well as the extension beginning with the two letters (e.g. ‘RT)’ is the required information. An example of a Business Number with the GST/HST account number is 123456789 RT0001.

If a potential applicant does business i. Quebec, the Business Number does not include the GST/HST accounts because Revenu Québec administers GST/HST on behalf o. CRA.

Please refer to th. Canada Revenue Agency website for additional information on CRA Business Number.

Organizations that do not have a business number cannot apply for funding using GCOS. In addition, applicants who want to use the GCOS must register for an account.

Amounts Owing to the Government of Canada

Program delivery staff must ensure that applicants complete the Declaration - Amounts Owing to the Government of Canada section of the Application for Funding paper form, or when applying via GCOS, complete the “Amounts Due” screen.

The term “amounts owing” refers to debts with the federal government. It is necessary, therefore, to find out from an applicant if they are in this situation before any applications for future funding can be considered. If they do have an outstanding debt, program delivery staff should ensure steps have been taken by the organization to repay their debt before their application can be accepted.

Should it be discovered, following the signing of an agreement, that the organization has an outstanding debt with the Federal government, they would be considered in a default situation. The ‘Default’ clause contained within the agreement would then apply and corrective action, including termination, may be warranted. Please refer to The Funding Agreement Chapter of the Operations Guide for additional information.

Action must also be taken in the following situation relative to applicants in default with other federal departments or agencies:

  • If they declare they have amounts owing to other federal departments or agencies, and the amount owing is significant, the Department’s Chief Financial Officer Branch (CFOB) must be provided with a copy of the application form.
  • CFOB will then attempt to identify the status of the amount owing to the other department or agency. They will follow up with a written report that documents the results of their inquiry and advises on whether or not to proceed with an agreement.

Please refer to the Close-Out – Overpayments Chapter of the Operations Guide for additional information on overpayments.

Part 2 - Project

This section of the application provides details about the project including the project description, objectives, and activities.

The Project Description and Details

An application is considered complete when all the required information and documentation has been provided as per program specific requirements. This includes, but is not limited to:

  • Project Title: it should be short and easy to reference in correspondence, agreements, etc;
  • Proposed Start and End Date of the project;
  • Project Objectives: this is one of the most important sections of the application, the project objectives must be clearly linked to the objectives of the program(s) to which the applicant is applying, identify a specific outcome that the project is designed to accomplish and identify who will benefit from the project. Well defined objectives are S.M.A.R.T.: specific, measurable, attainable, relevant, and time-based.. Again, it is important that project activities and objectives be clearly described, and should this not be the case, clarification from the applicant should be requested.
  • The Project Activities must be clearly linked to the objectives of the project and should include:
    • the scope of the project (local, regional, national, international);
    • project timelines;
    • how the project responds to program goals, objectives and priorities;
    • expected results and milestones;
    • how the findings, if applicable, will be disseminated (for example, where the project outcome is a research or evaluation report, a plan for the dissemination of the document would be required); and
    • who will benefit, and how.
  • The expected Project Results of the project must be clearly linked to the project objectives. Expected results further define and often quantify the project objectives. They describe the tangible results that will occur as a result of the Government’s investment in the project. You must ensure that the expected results are:
    • clearly written;
    • tangible;
    • measurable;
    • realistic/attainable; and
    • related to the project activities.

    It should be demonstrated that the applicant has the knowledge and resources to evaluate the project, or offers a provision in the application for securing the required expertise. (More complex projects may require outside expertise to develop and carry out a thorough evaluation.)

  • Expected results should reflect the outcomes and outputs of the project objectives. Some examples include:
    • Expected results for individuals can be expressed in many ways, including;
      • Outcomes
        • the anticipated number of participant/clients served (if applicable);
        • the number and percentage of participants expected to achieve the outcome;
        • the number and percentage of returns to work or school; and
        • the results of intervention (in addition to participant outcomes, results could also include short, medium and long-term impacts, direct or indirect impacts, etc.)
      • For Research, Policy, or Community Development type projects, the following are also considered as expected outputs:
        • production and dissemination of reports;
        • tools, products, systems; and/or
        • strategies.
      • Outcomes:
        • greater collaboration amongst stakeholders;
        • increased capacity of all service providers related to the project; and
        • community members will have access to XX up-to-date tools and resources.
      • Outputs:
        • approximately 5 dissemination forums will be held with approximately 125 participants per forum;
        • a resource directory, which includes an inventory of services provided by organizations involved with various aspects of the project, will be developed and shared across the provincial network; and
        • a minimum of 20 participants will be trained in public speaking and will deliver community presentations in various meetings.

The Project Details will include information on:

  • Results measurement indicators;
  • how the project relates to the ongoing work of the organization;
  • partnerships with other organizations;
  • whether it meets regional, national and local priorities; and
  • the environmental impact.
Part 3 – Funding

The Department uses the information provided in the section to assess the overall cost of the proposed project.

The Budget

In many ways, a budget is like a financial snapshot of the full application; it is one of the most important, and most detailed, pieces of the application package. The budget, therefore, should be reviewed carefully—both in its entirety and item by item—to ensure it is complete, accurate, reasonable, represents fair market value and the best value for money. In fact, a well-planned budget enables an organization to complete required tasks on time and in a cost-effective manner.

If applicants are applying via GCOS, they must provide details on how the project will be funded in the appropriate screens.

Budget Detail Template

For contribution programs, there are three (3) Budget Detail Templates (Set A – General, Set A for Opportunities Fund and Skills Link and Set B). For grants programs, there are two (2) Budget Detail Templates (Set A - General and Set B). These Budget Detail Templates replace all existing “Budget Negotiation Notes” and ensure a consistent approach to budget and information collection at the time of application. These streamlined templates include a general listing based on cost categories.

The appropriate Budget Detail Template (based on the standard sets of cost categories) is attached to the Applicant Guide (as an Annex).

Cost Category Sets

All contribution programs (with the exception of Canada Summer Jobs program) are required to use one of two cost category sets depending upon program funding types, Set A or Set B. Set A has a general structure as well as an option specific to Opportunities Fund for Persons with Disabilities and Skills Link programs to support the flat rate costing option for certain cost categories. Set A is structured to support programs for which organizations must report separately on administrative costs (also known as indirect costs) and direct costs. For programs which follow Set B, this distinction is not required.

All grants programs are also required to use one of the two cost category sets depending upon program funding types: Set A and Set B for grant programs.

Refer to the complete list of programs, funding types, applicable cost category sets and Questions and Answers (Qs & As) regarding departmental flat rate for Skills Link and Opportunities Fund for Persons with Disabilities (OF) found on the CoE website.

The appropriate cost category sets are included in all paper and electronic forms for the application for funding and the agreement. When projects are entered into the CSGC the appropriate cost category structure will appear.

The following is a summary of the cost category sets for grants and contributions:
