These cost category sets:

  • provide common standard definitions;
  • reduce differences and inconsistencies in reporting requirements from one program to another;
  • reduce internal and external administrative burden;
  • create a CSGC database containing information on project costs and expenditures that assist in program reporting, analysis and design; and
  • reduce the number of amendments required to deal with adjustments between budget cost categories.

To assist both applicants and program delivery staff in determining what types of expenditures are eligible, and which categories and sub-categories various costs correspond to, a standard eligible cost listing for each cost category set has been developed.

A comprehensive budget includes:

  • Proposed expenditure start and end dates (or, the funding period). It is important to discuss these dates with the applicant so that if the project is approved, the dates can be readily confirmed when the agreement is prepared. Always make the applicant aware that no costs can be incurred before the start and after the end dates of the agreement funding period. For this reason, the Department needs to know at the application stage if there will be a start-up or close-out period, along with essential project-related expenditures.
  • A detailed breakdown of expenses and descriptions of cost categories, such as staff wages, capital and project costs and participant costs. This section should also specify which costs, if any, will be sub-projects administrative costs (i.e. the applicant's use of a third party to perform all or part of the project activities that make up an agreement), and if any flat rates are applicable.
  • For projects under Opportunities Fund for Persons with Disabilities (OF) and Skills Link programs, a verification by program delivery staff that, if applicable (when an organization chooses this costing option), the flat rate has been calculated accurately and applied only to the cost categories for which a flat rate is possible. Specific expenditures covered by flat rates do not need to be detailed or negotiated at the time of application. Consult Questions and Answers regarding departmental flat rates for Skills Link and Opportunities Fund for Persons with Disabilities (OF) for how to calculate flat rate and other questions relating to flat rate.
  • A declaration, by potential organizations, of other sources of funding regardless of the amount of the contribution requested from the Department. Other funders are active supporters of the project who contribute time and resources, and who have an interest in the outcome. Evidence of partnership includes:
    • financial (cash or in-kind) contribution;
    • contribution of human resources for project delivery;
    • joint delivery of a project or service; and
    • capital investment.
  • An explanation as to the value of in-kind contributions and why the contribution is required.
    • In-kind contributions are goods or services provided by the organization or by other organizations and partners; these could include land, and goods required to carry out projects and activities. Generally, these can be considered if they are new or incremental assets provided for the project, are specific to the project, are quantifiable, and are essential to the project going forward.
    • To assess the value of the cash or in-kind contributions from other sources, program delivery staff can:
      • refer to the available local labour market information when assessing wage contributions;
      • consult supplier valuation for identical or similar materials, equipment or products;
      • compare proposed rent costs to the going rates for similar space in the geographic location; and
      • ensure travel costs are related to the project and necessary for project success and ensure that the project funds are only paying for the amount of space required for project activities.
    • In order to complete the assessment, confirmation of commitment from partnering organizations identifying the amount of financial or in-kind contribution must be submitted. Incorporating this information into the application phase will prove beneficial during the agreement set up and monitoring phase.
    • For more information on in-kind, please refer to the Guide on In-Kind Contribution.
  • If an applicant identifies the need for advance payments, a completed Forecast of Project Expenditures must be submitted. This forecast indicates the expected expenditures for each reporting period. All new advance paying contribution projects entered in the CSGC, (with the exception of Canada Summer Jobs program) will use the forecast of project expenditures to track anticipated agreement expenses for specific, pre-determined fixed payment periods. For more information on Forecast of Project Expenditures, please refer to the Activity Reporting and Payment Chapter of the Operations Guide. The forecast of project expenditures is required to prepare a contribution agreement.
  • Project cost details: every applicant must provide a list of costs eligible for reimbursement and a breakdown of how these were determined. This information should be kept in the project file for future financial monitoring.

Program delivery staff involved in guiding and reviewing an applicant’s budget development process should also advise them of the following considerations:

  • Budgetary dollar values and project costs in applications, forecast of project expenditures, or negotiated agreements are not necessarily equal to actual costs reimbursed. Actual costs incurred and claimed by the applicant may vary from budgeted costs. The Department will only reimburse up to the actual costs incurred.
  • As an exception to the ‘reimburse up to the actual costs incurred’ rule, the Department has developed and implemented a flat rate option for the Opportunities Fund for Persons with Disabilities (OF) and the Skills Link programs. The use of the flat rate has impacts throughout the project life cycle. Within these categories, specific costs do not need to be detailed or negotiated at the time of application, nor are they subject to monitoring. The flat rate expenditures do not require to be supported by additional documentation. The amount eligible for reimbursement for these categories is simply based on a given percentage of the total amount of other categories. Please refer to the FMPR Desk Aid.
  • Applicants should be notified that administrative costs, not directly related to the proposed project activities but necessary for the organization to function effectively, may be eligible for reimbursement. The requirements for whether administrative costs must be separately reported from 3. Direct Costs, c) Project Costs varies by program (see programs and associated cost category set list for more details; those following Set A separate these costs, while those following Set B do not).
  • Applicants may not have to provide invoices, back-up calculations, accounting records, etc. in support of a claim. They must, however, keep this supporting documentation available for possible review by the Department at a later date, possibly within the context of project monitoring, with the exception of expenditures where flat rate applies (categories subject to flat rate are not monitored).
  • Applicants must obtain written, departmental approval for goods or services contracts of $25,000 or more (before taxes), or for contracts with businesses or individuals associated with the contribution organization.
  • Applicants must disclose and receive written approval before subcontracting any part of project activities. For further details on contracting and the use of sub-contractors, please consult section 5.21 of the CFOB Grants and Contributions Policy.
  • Finally, applicants must use a fair, transparent and competitive process when procuring goods and services for the project, or when subcontracting project activities, where the value is $25,000 or more (before taxes). If they do not intend to use a competitive process, a written justification for a sole-source approach must be provided to, and subsequently approved by the Department’s delegated authority. Column B, before proceeding.
Part 4 – Declaration

The Application for Funding must be signed by an official, authorized representative of the organization and must be signed in accordance with the organization’s statutes, by-laws or other constituting documents.

5.3 Role of Program Delivery Staff

The Application Phase

Regardless of the application intake method, the role of program delivery staff is both to promote government programs, and to assist potential organizations with inquires about the application process or the program to which they are applying. In order to fulfill this role, staff should:

  • describe the scope, benefits and limitations of the program so that potential applicants can decide whether or not to proceed with an application;
  • interpret and have knowledge of program terms and conditions to ensure the proposed project will help realize the goals of the program, the organization and the community;
  • guide applicants through the application process, and inform them of the assessment and approval process;
  • clarify the logistics - format, number of copies, timelines, and address for application submission; and
  • respond to applicant questions and be available for consultation.

Note: The role of program delivery staff may vary according to program specific needs or variances between national and regional delivery.

Maintaining Objectivity

Throughout the application development stage, program delivery staff must ensure they respect the Government of Canada’s obligation to remain accountable to Canadians for the best use of public funds.

When working with potential organizations, there exist a number of potential situations which program delivery staff should avoid. Some examples include:

  • telling an organization exactly what it should or should not do;
  • completing the application for the organization;
  • taking sides with one faction of a group or community against another;
  • promoting project funding for organizations with which one is personally associated;
  • attempting to solve organizational problems through the use of project funds; and
  • becoming an advocate for an applicant before such time that an application can be recommended for funding.
Ensuring Complete Applications

An important aspect of the role of program delivery staff is to review and identify any missing information. Incomplete applications can result in delays to the assessment process; negative decisions based on a lack of information, and missed funding deadlines.

Receiving and Acknowledging Applications

The Department can receive applications either through a paper process or via GCOS.
When receiving a paper application, program delivery staff must:

  1. ensure it includes a signed departmental Application for Funding and any other documentation required under the specific program terms and conditions, all duly completed and signed by the applicant;
  2. stamp the date of receipt on the hard copy of the application or proposal and if applicable, keep the envelop and/or e-mail for future reference;
  3. enter the application information into the Project Set-up phase of the CSGC;
  4. open a paper file and record the CSGC file number on the application. The signed application for funding and all hard copies of accompanying documentation may be placed on the paper file or scanned and uploaded into the CSGC; and
  5. send an acknowledgement letter or email to the applicant confirming receipt of the application. The letter may also include additional information such as the number assigned to the file, the name and telephone number of the program delivery staff responsible for assessing the application, or a request for any missing documentation. A copy should be kept in the electronic or paper file.

All paper applications received for national or regional Gs&Cs programs with continuous intake should be inputted into the Common System for Grants and Contributions (CSGC) within two (2) business days of receipt.

Note that the Department has implemented an ‘Acknowledgment of Application’ service standard, applicable to all departmental Gs&Cs programs, which states that:

“Under normal conditions, the Department will acknowledge receipt of your proposal within 21 calendar days of receiving your application package.”

Program delivery staff must record the application received date, as well as the date that the acknowledgement was sent to applicant in CSGC. Two mandatory fields exist in the CSGC – ‘Application Received Date’ (located in the Project Setup/Project Summary phase of the CSGC/PLC process) and ‘Acknowledgement Letter Sent’ (located in the Project Maintenance/Project Events phase)..

For further details, please consult the ESDC Grants and Contributions Service Standards Directive

When receiving applications via GCOS, the process is automated. Confirmation of receipt of applications submitted electronically is displayed on the screen and sent by e-mail to applicants once the application has been successfully submitted.

Once the electronic application and supporting documents (if applicable), have been submitted via GCOS, it is routed to the CSGC staging area for the responsible office. From there, program delivery staff will review it and determine if it is a valid application for the program. If so, program delivery staff will import the file into CSGC and populate the appropriate CSGC screens.

Electronic applications received by GCOS should be uploaded from the staging area within two (2) business days of receipt.

Please refer to the Operational Directive on the Streamlined Application Process, Approval Request Form and Approval Process for Grants and Contributions Programs.

Opening the CSGC and Project File

In addition to entering or importing (if submitted electronically via GCOS) an application for funding into the CSGC, a paper file is required in order to safeguard any paper originals.

Paper vs Electronic Files

As the Department continues to move away from a paper based process, we are now communicating and receiving documents electronically (e.g. receiving information through e-mail or GCOS). Paper and/or electronic documents together make up the project file. The Department does not expect that every electronic correspondence be printed and saved in a paper file. Electronic documents should be saved in the CSGC under the appropriate section, while hard copies of documents should be saved in the physical project file. The two files do not have to mirror one another; however, together they must have all the required elements of a complete project file.

All information submitted by an organization, via GCOS, is imported through the CSGC staging area; therefore hard copies of these documents are not required in the paper file since they can be retrieved virtually through the CSGC.

Chapter 6. Assessment

Referring to the 2012 Ops Guide, Chapter 5

Assessment is a criteria-based process that helps program delivery staff evaluate the relative merit of funding applications and explain the resulting recommendations to applicants, the public, and departmental and ministerial authorities. It allows the Department to assess the strengths and weaknesses of an application, and to select those applications most deserving of funding.

While criteria may vary from program to program, it must be determined that the application:

  • meets program terms and conditions and planning priorities as defined by relevant local, regional and national business or operational plans;
  • responds to an identified need or specific issue;
  • is realistic in what it intends to do and the outcomes it expects to achieve;
  • provides good value for funding requested (consider what is being achieved vis-à- vis the amount requested; are projected costs comparable to fair market value);
  • includes partnerships that will reduce certain costs within the proposed project, if applicable;
  • demonstrates that the applicant has the capacity to successfully complete the proposed project;
  • is compliant with all applicable federal, provincial and municipal laws, by-laws and regulations;
  • ensures that all permits, licenses, consents and other authorizations will be obtained prior to the commencement of the project;
  • entails an acceptable level of risk; and,
  • meets all requirements under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.

The assessment process ensures that all applications are evaluated against program prerequisites, client and community needs, availability of funds and current year goals. It results in a clear rationale that demonstrates how every aspect of the application has been measured objectively against established criteria, and decisions have been made in a consistent manner. It must not only be fair, but also perceived as such by way of a transparent process that demonstrates accountability and ensures decisions are documented, communicated and open to public scrutiny. Without a clear rationale and a transparent process for choosing one project over another, applicants may feel unfairly treated and seek remedy within the Department, through Members of Parliament, or through the media.

Assessment also provides for communication between the Department and the applicant in order to clarify program requirements, and discuss potential risks and risk mitigation strategies. This kind of discussion with the applicant, the community and other funders may reveal new information regarding the project or the applicant, which may possibly affect the successful outcome of the project.

Ultimately, a thorough assessment will support the result of a funding agreement that is clear, specific, easier to monitor, and, consequently, more likely to achieve expected results. In situations where an assessment has not been utilized to clearly identify the conditions for approval, and help set the expected milestones and outcomes, monitoring becomes more complex, and the risk where achieving expected results is concerned increases.

Learn more about conducting the assessment during this phase of the project life cycle.

6.1 Conducting the Assessment

The assessment process may differ from program to program and region to region. In some instances, an internal – and if required, an external – assessment committee or board is used to evaluate large numbers of applications; however, in most cases, program delivery staff in charge of the file—possibly in consultation with colleagues—are responsible for this task.

Whether the project is assessed individually or by a group, the process usually involves two readings of the applications at hand:

  • The first reading determines if the project seems feasible and well developed, and meets basic program criteria and applicant eligibility requirements.
  • The second reading is a complete and thorough assessment of every aspect of the application, including detailed information about the applicant, the project and the degree of associated risk.
The First Reading

During a first reading, either program delivery staff or the internal assessment committee develops a general first impression of the application quality, and determines whether it meets community needs in a practical way. This preliminary stage helps anyone involved evaluate applications based on their knowledge of program and departmental priorities, and their experience with this applicant as well as other applicants. First readings are particularly useful when a large number of applications are being considered.

Remember to objectively assess the substance of the application. Although a clearly written application can often reflect an applicant’s general organizational ability, an application should not be accepted or rejected based solely on its presentation.

As the application is reviewed, program delivery staff should be able to answer the following questions in the affirmative:

  • Does the application meet program terms and conditions?
  • Does it fit within the Department's Integrated Business Plan?
  • Is the applicant eligible?
  • Does the project seem reasonable and realistic?
  • Are the activities feasible, given the proposed time frame and budget?
  • Does the project address identified needs and avoid duplication of existing initiatives (of which program delivery staff are aware)?
  • Does it answer the "who, what, where, when, how and why" questions?
  • Are the risks manageable?

When necessary (and when program-specific guidelines allow), contact applicants at any point during the assessment process if further information or clarification is required; note all questions as the application is being read and then decide who can best provide the answers. Any further information received should be documented in the CSGC and the project file, including:

  • the date the applicant was contacted;
  • the name and title of the contact person;
  • the questions that were asked;
  • the information obtained; and,
  • any follow up required or action taken.

After a first reading, one must decide what to do with the application:

  1. 1. If the application is complete and has merit, it is ready for a more in-depth assessment and a second reading.
  2. 2. If the application is incomplete or further information is required, one could either reject the application immediately or, if the program allows, hold the application until the necessary information from the applicant has been received.
  3. 3. If the application is ineligible under the terms and conditions of the specific program or is clearly not feasible, notify the applicant in writing that the project has been rejected, and, if applicable, referred to another program or department.

The Second Reading

Once the first reading has been accomplished and a decision to not reject the application has been made, a more detailed assessment – in the form of a second reading – needs to be performed; if program delivery staff are satisfied with the results of the second reading, the availability of funds to support the project must then be confirmed.

This second reading involves a very in-depth, analytical assessment of the:

  • applicant, including:
    • eligibility
    • track record
    • applicant stability
    • organizational capacity
    • relationship with the Department
  • The application, including its:
    • objectives, and expected outputs and outcomes
    • proposed activities
    • environmental impact
    • partnerships
    • evaluation strategies
  • budget, including:
    • in-kind contributions
    • stacking of assistance
    • contracting and sub-contracting
    • value for money
    • eligibility of costs

At this stage, program delivery staff can use a generic CSGC checklist or program- specific checklist to document, consolidate, track and verify information about potential applicants, application content, financial data (such as the budget), environmental aspects (when necessary), consultations and evaluation approach.

Critically, throughout the process of application assessment, one must simultaneously carry out the process of risk assessment relative to each of the three above-mentioned elements and, ultimately, decide whether and how the potential risks identified could be managed, should the project be recommended for funding.

Assessing the Applicant

Just as one would need to interview any candidate for a job, so too should program delivery staff take a closer look at the applicant behind each application submitted.

To do so, program delivery staff should weigh several factors when evaluating an applicant's capacity to complete the proposed project, including:

  • activity performance;
  • ability to demonstrate results;
  • financial performance;
  • organizational administration; and
  • stability of the board and/or organization.

Often, experts and community representatives can provide additional information about an applicant's background and suitability.

Applicant Eligibility

The first step program delivery staff must undertake is to confirm that the applicant is eligible for funding under the program terms and conditions. Consult program-specific guidelines and ensure that enough information has been received from the applicant to properly gauge their eligibility, requesting further input or clarification from the program or the applicant, as necessary.

Should it be determined that the applicant is not eligible, the assessment process ends here and the application is rejected.

Applicant Track Record

To assess an applicant's track record, program delivery staff must determine whether the applicant has managed past projects similar to the one currently being proposed, and if so, to what degree desired results were achieved.

Hence, previous projects—whether funded by the Department or by others—should be reviewed. This can be done by:

  • asking the applicant to provide a detailed history of funding received from HRSDC, other federal departments and agencies, other levels of government and private organizations (should this information not already be detailed in the application);
  • weighing the applicant's experience in carrying out similar activities in order to verify their capacity and effectiveness; ask the applicant to provide additional information or references, as required;
  • searching the CSGC for information about the applicant's background and history in delivering HRSDC-funded projects, such as that provided via the Organization History screen or individual project close-out summary reports;
  • reviewing the results of previous agreements held by the applicant with other federal departments or agencies, and the outcomes realized for each; and,
  • obtaining information from other levels of government relative to their experiences with the applicant, if HRSDC holds memoranda of understanding with them to facilitate such information-sharing practices. Privacy considerations, however, may prevent obtaining additional details from these sources.
  • Refer to risk factor #7, financial performance, and risk factor #8, activity performance, of the Risk Assessment Tool for supplementary guidance in this area.

Applicant Stability

Even if the applicant's track record is established with the Department, circumstances may change from one project to another; program delivery staff should, therefore, assess the current organizational stability of the applicant.

To this end, one should:

  • review the applicant's documentation to determine if the proposed activities continue to be consistent with the organization's mission and mandate;
    • evaluate the applicant's current capacity to carry out the project:
      • Is this a new venture for the organization?
    • Is there a history of previous funding?
    • Is the organization incorporated?
    • Does it have its own operational funding or access to credit, independent of solicited project funding?
    • Are there risk management measures in place;
  • review the organization's documentation (such as annual reports, websites, brochures, newsletters, etc.) to determine the applicant's usual client group(s);
  • consult other organizations and stakeholder groups familiar with the applicant; and,
  • check with local, regional and national HRSDC offices and other government departments.

Applicant Organizational Capacity

Program delivery staff must closely examine the capacity of an applicant in order to determine whether sufficient expertise and resources to successfully manage projects is available. If the applicant is unknown to the Department or proposes activities they have not done before, a more in-depth assessment of their overall potential to deliver expected results should be carried out.

In order to complete this task, the following factors should be assessed:

  • administrative setup;
  • ability to maintain financial and internal controls; and,
  • status in the Departmental Accounts Receivable System (DARS)

Refer to risk factor #4, organizational administration, and risk factor #5, stability of the board and/or organization of the Risk Assessment, Management and Mitigation (RAMM) Tool for supplementary guidance in this area.

Administrative Setup

The examination of certain aspects of an organization's administration can be revealing when assessing whether the managers and employees have the necessary resources, supports, skills, training and expertise required to carry out the proposed project.

During a review of the applicant's administrative capacity:

  • confirm the organization has a system of administrative policies and practices in place to effectively manage the project;
  • examine the current organizational structure or payroll to ascertain whether it has the employees necessary to complete the proposed activities; if not, does the application make provisions to obtain such expertise; and,
  • determine whether requested funding will supplement (and not replace) the organization's normal operating budget and support staff to lead project activities; specifically, this can be done by:
    • reviewing, if available, the organization's financial statements or budgets from the two previous years; and,
    • identifying, if possible, other sources of funding for ongoing organizational activities such as revenues, operating funds from other sources, etc.

Ability to Maintain Financial and Internal Controls

Managers rely on coordinated financial and internal controls to:

  • ensure the accuracy and reliability of financial data;
  • promote operational efficiency and adherence to stated policy; and,
  • safeguard assets against errors, waste and fraud.

Typically, there are four main types of controls:

  1. organization;
  2. segregation function;
  3. finance and accounting; and,
  4. additional safeguards.

Within this context, the effectiveness of an organization's financial and internal controls can be assessed by:

  • investigating the organization's record-keeping practices and internal controls to measure its ability to remain accountable for the use of HRSDC funds; and,
  • reviewing, if available, its financial statements for the past two years, including the balance sheet, income statement and forecast of project expenditures for the coming year (seek the advice of a financial officer whenever these statements are consolidated or complex).

Organization Controls

These controls reflect whether the organization has appropriate human resource practices due to the existence of:

  • effective hiring practices;
  • adequate training programs;
  • appropriate supervision;
  • objective performance standards;
  • fair and equitable evaluation and promotion practices; and,
  • effective, tamper-proof systems that discourage abuse.

Segregation of Function Controls

Basically, such controls ensure no one employee is ever in a position that enables them to perpetrate and conceal irregularities or fraud. Incompatible functions, for example, should be separated – the same person cannot make out cheques, sign them, record them in the register and perform the bank reconciliation function. In smaller organizations, two individuals should be required to sign cheques.

Ideally, large organizations are planned or structured to segregate internal control functions from operational functions. For example, accounting functions remain distinct from operational functions when an accountant maintains financial records and a manager makes decisions relative to daily operations. Note here that some departmental programs may require that the applicant identify the person responsible for accounting functions within the organization.

As far as possible, organizations should always separate groups that have access to assets from those who authorize purchases.

Finance and Accounting Controls

Typically, large organizations segregate finance, or treasury, functions (such as paying bills) from accounting, or controller, functions (such as recording transactions) so that the same person cannot issue cheques, sign them and record them in the financial account ledgers. Note that applicants are generally required to identify those with legal signing authority for the organization.

Possible accounting controls include:

  • self-balancing features incorporated into the use of the subsidiary and general ledgers, where the subsidiary ledger entries balance with a main control account;
  • arrangements where one employee reviews the work of another – for example, the bookkeeper prepares cheques and the manager spot-checks invoices prior to payment; and,
  • restricted ability to make journal entries, where only authorized individuals have access to financial records.

Additional Safeguard Controls

These could include:

  • restricting access to assets such as computer terminals;
  • periodically comparing assets on hand to recorded amounts by inventory counts;
  • confirming book balance with bank account balance (or, bank reconciliation);
  • protecting records by keeping bookkeeping records in a safe place;
  • obtaining insurance coverage; and,
  • analyzing the debt load carried by the organization to determine its ability to meet forecast of project expenditures requirements.

Status in DARS

At this stage, program delivery staff must check the Departmental Accounts Receivable System (DARS) to ensure the applicant organization has no outstanding debts. If debts to the Crown exist, they must always be taken into account whenever new applications are assessed in order to support:

  1. the sound management of contribution overpayments;
  2. accountability for public funds ; and,
  3. consistent and equitable treatment of all applicants.

To do this, review screen DW009 to verify there is no existing overpayment to the applicant. This confirmation should be printed and included in the physical file.

However, if DW009 indicates an overpayment, consult screen DC001 (using the client identification number) to obtain further information.

Where the applicant is an organization, they must either repay the outstanding balance, or negotiate an acceptable repayment arrangement, before any new funding agreement can be put in place. Carefully document the status of any repayment situation in the project file.

Individuals who have an existing overpayment in default with the Department should, as much as possible, negotiate a repayment schedule before requesting new funding from the Department.

However, it is recognized that some programs provide funding to individuals who are unemployed or who are experiencing hardship. By assisting these clients through an intervention there is an expectation that upon successful completion of the project they would be able to secure employment and repay the debt. Hence, under such circumstances, individuals with an outstanding overpayment would not be required to have a repayment schedule in place in order to be eligible for assistance.

Relationship with the Department

Employer-employee relationships must not be created between the Department and the funding organization.

To determine if such a relationship could develop, review the application to assess whether any of the following questions can be answered in the affirmative; the more so the case, the greater the possibility that an employer-employee relationship may develop. Carefully analyse and address this possibility before recommending funding.

  • Will HRSDC exercise supervisory control (as distinct from inspection of work) over the organization? That is, does it exercise control not only over what is done (the objective), but how, when and where the work is carried out?
  • Will HRSDC have the power to discipline the organization's staff, make hiring and firing decisions or become involved in sub-contracting project activities? In other words, is the Department limiting the applicant's opportunity or authority to hire or contract staff as needed to carry out activities?
  • Will HRSDC be responsible for training the organization's staff? (It is, however, acceptable for HRSDC to contribute to the cost of professional development for the applicant's staff if it is only a small portion of the total contribution to the applicant, and if the training is necessary and relevant to project activities.)
  • Will HRSDC make payments to an organization on the basis of time, at regular intervals, directly to individuals (i.e. staff), subject to source deductions? The Department can only reimburse eligible costs as they are incurred by the organization (so the costs are the organization's, not the Department’s) and does not remunerate the organization or their staff.
  • Is there evidence that the Public Service Employment Act may be contravened? Project activities must not be the same as or similar to the Department's activities, and the organization cannot perform departmental duties and functions. The Act defines the process that federal departments must use to hire staff and does not allow the use of contribution funds to pay individuals to perform tasks that would normally be completed by a federal employee.
  • Will HRSDC be responsible for providing tools, equipment, material, premises or facilities to the organization?
  • Will the organization or their staff attend internal departmental meetings? Are they on internal departmental communications systems (such as email)?
  • Will the organization be integrated into HRSDC as an organization and the work being performed become an integral part of the Department’s work? Project activities must not be seen as part of departmental operations (for example, located on departmental premises; in close proximity without being clearly set off as a separate facility; or exhibiting signs that infer the organization is part of the Department). Moreover, organizations must never suggest to clients, either explicitly or implicitly, that they are working for or representing HRSDC.
  • Could the organization profit from their involvement in the project? An organization should have no opportunity to profit from their activities, as HRSDC can only reimburse actual costs.
  • Could the organization be exposed to any risk of loss while performing their work? An organization could incur costs which exceed the Department’s contribution, which could mean that they may suffer a loss. Similarly, they might also suffer a liability—through errors and omissions, wrongful dismissal, property damage, personal injury, etc.—that becomes a loss. Whatever the case, these losses must only be borne by the organization and not by the Department, which can only reimburse the cost of liability insurance that would protect the organization.

For more information, see Avoiding Employer-Employee Relationships in Chapter 8.

Consultation with Experts and Community Representatives

Consultations with experts are sometimes necessary in order to understand the proposed project as it relates to the applicant, departmental priorities, other funders' commitments and community support for the initiative. In these situations, applicants must be informed, in advance, that experts will be consulted to verify information and solicit their assistance in evaluating the application.

Throughout these consultation activities, the need to maintain confidentiality and privacy must remain paramount. While program delivery staff may have to disclose some application details for consultation purposes, one must ensure that information protected under the Privacy Act remains confidential.

The consultation process usually involves the following recommended procedures:

  • Consult the applicant first: develop a list of questions, based on the application, for which you require more information. Document all written and verbal contacts, including discussions, in the CSGC and paper file. As often as practical, rely on written documentation over verbal communication in order to establish a paper trail.
  • Within the Department, talk to other program delivery staff who have dealt with the applicant, or similar project activities, in the past to assess their record of success and community impact.
  • Liaise with potential co-funders to foster cooperative relationships and avoid any duplication of funding. Confirm the source and nature of other funding resources by speaking to co-funders, project partners and other government departments.
  • Contact community, stakeholder and local government representatives directly to gauge their support for the project (if such support is required by program terms and conditions or guidelines). Discuss the value of the project as well as any concerns or unresolved issues.
  • Ensure the applicant has obtained union concurrence—in writing—if proposed activities will be held in a workplace with a collective agreement, as this is a funding condition.
  • Contact the applicant to clarify all concerns and issues raised during consultations.

6.2 Assessing the Application

Perhaps the most critical component of the assessment process, an application is key to understanding how a project would unfold. Ideally, it delineates a course of action that will deliver—and measure—expected results.

When assessing an application, program delivery staff should look for project effectiveness and efficiency while also considering the RAMM factors associated with project activities. This involves analyzing its various aspects, including:

  • activity performance;
  • project duration;
  • complexity of proposed activities;
  • involvement of partners;
  • public sensitivity;
  • possible environmental impact; and,
  • planned evaluation strategies.
Proposed Activities

When assessing proposed activities, answer the following questions with respect to these areas of particular concern:

Program parameters, strategic priorities and compliance with laws:

  • Do they currently meet program terms and conditions, and priorities (or should they be refined or modified)?
  • How do they compare with local, regional and national priorities, as identified in the integrated business plan and local strategic plan?
  • Do they respond to identified needs within the community?
  • Are the activities compliant with all applicable federal, provincial and municipal laws, by-laws and regulations?
  • Has the applicant obtain all permits, licenses, consents and other authorizations that are necessary to carry out the project?

Project objectives and expected results:

  • Have they been clearly defined within a reasonable timeframe?
  • Are they measurable in terms of time, output and anticipated outcomes?

Eligible activities:

  • Are they necessary?
  • Are they feasible?
  • Are they well defined?
  • Are they described in sufficient detail as part of a well-conceived implementation plan?
  • Do they represent the most effective way to meet project goals and identified needs?
  • Are the roles and responsibilities of project staff and partners clearly defined?
  • Has the applicant identified the means by which participant eligibility will be identified?

Scheduled timeframes:

  • Can they be completed within the specified timeframe?
  • Are the timelines too generous?

Potential for duplication:

  • Would the proposed activities duplicate a product or service already existing in the community according to your knowledge of the labour market, community services and activity sector?
  • Are there similar undertakings in the area?

Potential for unfair competition:

  • Will HRSDC assistance to this particular project adversely impact any other local or national initiatives or businesses similar to what is being proposed?
  • What do community and industry stakeholders (such as the chamber of commerce or board of trade, municipal government, local business and social service associations) say?
  • Can the applicant demonstrate (in detail via the application) that the requested funds will not result in an unfair advantage over any other organization or competitor?
Official Languages

Section 6.5.13 of the Treasury Board Policy on Transfer Payments, requires departments to ensure that programs meet the obligations of the Government of Canada as prescribed in the Official Languages Act (OLA) at the time of both their design and implementation.

A decision by the Supreme Court of Canada states that measures to respect the formal and substantive equality of both official languages should also apply.

Program delivery staff must, in assessing the application using the three-question grid below, check for the need or desirability for the project to cater to members of both official languages communities or provide services in both official languages.

To facilitate this assessment, the application should:

  • clearly identify the linguistic profile of the beneficiaries targeted by the project;
  • document any specific needs of the official language minority communities and specify how the project will meet these needs; and,
  • demonstrate that the applicant has the necessary human and financial resources to meet the specific needs of official language minority communities.
Questions for determining whether the applicant’s project should cater to members of both official language communities or provide services in both official languages? Yes/No
  1. Are there individuals or groups from both official language communities among the targeted beneficiaries of the project?
  2. In regard to the general public of the locality or localities targeted by the project, is there a significant demand for services in both official languages?
  3. If, by its very nature, the project is for a single language group, would it be desirable to promote it to the other group?

If the answer to any one of these three questions is ‘yes’, one must consider that the applicant’s project should cater to members of both official language communities or provide services in both official languages and official languages obligations should be reflected in the funding agreement.

Note:

  1. "Formal equality" is achieved when members of official language minority communities and those of the majority community are treated the same way by providing identical services in English and French. ’Substantive equality’ is achieved when taking into consideration the specific needs of the minority community by providing activities or services with different content or using a different delivery method to ensure that the minority receives services of the same quality as the majority.
  2. The targeted beneficiaries of the project are defined as follows: individuals, organizations or people that can benefit from the activity or service.
  3. The localities that are the subject of a ’significant demand’ for services in both official languages are identified by the Burolis tool. Please refer to it as required.
Environmental Impact

The Canadian Environmental Assessment Act (CEAA) applies to any activity for which HRSDC is the responsible authority, whether as a project proponent, regulator, source of funding or land. The Act ensures the environmental effects of federal projects receive early consideration in the planning process, and provides opportunities for public consultation.

At HRSDC, environmental issues are taken into account during both the assessment and monitoring phases of the project life cycle; no project can be approved unless it is unlikely to cause significant adverse environmental effects, and public concern about its environmental impact is minimal.

For every potential HRSDC-funded project, program delivery staff must determine whether it will require a formal environmental assessment (EA), as per the requirements of the Act, prior to funding approval. In order to ensure that projects conform to the requirements of the CEAA, responsible program delivery staff should:

  • ensure that the pre-screening questionnaire has been completed for each project; and,
  • ensure that a preliminary assessment has been performed for each project requiring an environmental assessment.

To fulfill this pre-screening requirement, first ask the applicant to fill out the Proponent/Organization Environmental Assessment Checklist as part of their application package. Once they complete this task, ensure that they are comfortable with the accuracy of their answers, and then review both their application and their EA checklist answers to assess whether their project should be subject to an EA process.

If it is decided that an EA is required, refer to the Environmental Assessment Guide for further details on how to proceed. If an environmental assessment is obligatory, its completion becomes a condition for approval, as project activities cannot begin until the assessment has been completed and any mitigation measures, if applicable, identified and implemented.

If an EA is not required, document that decision by adding the checklists to the project file. Once a determination has been made, fill out the HRSDC Internal Environmental Assessment Checklist [in the CSGC].

Note that EA processes can vary slightly from region to region. Please consult the regional EA coordinator for information specific to the applicable region.

For complete EA guidance, please consult the Environmental Assessment Guide.

Partnerships

HRSDC programs usually encourage, or require, applicants to develop effective partnerships with those who can contribute either cash or non-cash assets to the project.

When evaluating partnerships, program delivery staff should:

  • verify the potential roles and relationships of proposed partners – are these clearly defined in the application and budget? Will they be active participants, technical advisors or something else? Partnerships, for example, could indicate community support and help ensure the short- or long-term viability of a project. Partners, in turn, could originate within the private sector, a not-for profit organization, an agency, an educational or public institution;
  • ensure that partners provide a letter stating their role and intended contribution to the project;
  • check that partner objectives are compatible with applicant objectives, as stated in the project application, and that any benefits to the partners as a result of their involvement in the project, do not outweigh benefits to the applicant; and,
  • review the budget to look for any indication that partners will receive remuneration as a result of project funding. In such cases, they are consultants or contractors – not partners.

The organization may also receive funding from other federal departments or levels of government. For more information on partnerships, consult the Partnership Handbook.

Evaluation Strategies

An evaluation strategy provides both the applicant and HRSDC with performance measurement indicators that can help gauge the progress and success of the project at hand.

To determine if the application demonstrates how progress will be measured:

  • review the proposed results measurement strategy -- does it relate directly to project objectives? Will it actually be able to verify that these have been met; and,
  • ensure performance indicators mesh with identified project milestones.

To confirm that an evaluation method has been identified for each performance indicator:

  • establish whether the type and method of evaluation has been identified for each indicator, either within the application or through follow-up consultation with the applicant; and,
  • ascertain whether the evaluation method provides sufficient information for the Department to later calculate value for money, community impact and quantifiable results.

6.3 Assessing the Budget

A close examination of the proposed budget, even at this early stage in the project life cycle, helps the Department promote sound financial management practices and fiscal accountability for the use of public funds. To conduct this kind of assessment, program delivery staff must, therefore, decide whether:

  • the budget is sufficiently detailed;
  • projected costs are reasonable and represent actual expenditures; and,
  • capital assets are properly identified.

The following procedures can help with these determinations:

  • Review proposed budget costs to establish whether they fall within program- specific guidelines and fairly reflect proposed activities by:
    • checking the program terms and conditions to confirm the eligibility of proposed expenditures;
    • weighing anticipated expenditures against proposed activities to verify if they are reasonable;
    • analyzing how budget line items were determined; discuss these with the applicant to ensure a clear understanding of expenditures;
    • finding out if the applicant will require advance payments; if they will and the project is recommended for funding, the applicant must supply a forecast of project expenditures; and,
    • verifying that they demonstrate value for money.
  • Determine if cost breakdowns are reasonable, sufficiently detailed and accurate by:
    • reviewing the budget detail template;
    • confirming that all expenses are clearly based on actual, documented costs; and,
    • evaluating the appropriateness and cost effectiveness of each budget item.
  • Ensure projected costs reflect current market value.
  • Review anticipated expenditures against other projects with similar content and duration to determine whether the application is consistent.
  • Examine contributions from the applicant and other sources to determine whether they are sufficient and reliable, based on written confirmation of these contributions.
  • Substantiate the value of non-cash assets (in-kind) as contributions.
  • Confirm that stacking limits have been respected and the stacking of assistance avoided.
  • Determine whether the policy directive Contracting for Goods or Services by Contributions Organizations and the Use of Subcontractors applies.
  • As required, consult a more experienced colleague or manager who may have been responsible for similar projects
  • Confirm that proposed activities could not proceed without the Department's contribution – should this not be the case, seek justification vis-à-vis the request for funding.
  • Include any notes indicating that proposed costs have been evaluated and that requested amounts are accurate, reasonable, and complete. in order to document the assessment process. If clarification from the applicant is required on any aspect of the budget, add the resulting notes or documentation to the project file.

Note: For proposed projects entered into CSGC on or after December 3rd, 2012, program delivery staff should ensure that costs have been identified according to the appropriate cost categories and sub- categories (where applicable). Refer to the appropriate program standard cost category sets for more details.

Value for Money

When assessing value for money, the potential monetary investment required to fund project activities must be weighed against the value of the project to the community and the applicant. Economy, efficiency and effectiveness are three principles to keep in mind throughout this process.

To determine whether projected expenditures are reasonable when compared to the project's expected results, review the anticipated costs to see if the applicant has demonstrated the value of the proposed activities, relative to cost categories such as the following, and document the findings in the project file:

Rent:

  • confirm that activities require the rental of space, and that the space is adequate for the intended use;
  • establish whether the square footage being rented is reasonable for the project's activities;
  • compare proposed rent costs to the going rates for a similar space in that geographic location; and,
  • confirm that project funds are only paying for the space that is to be used for project activities.

Staff Wages:

  • refer to available local labour market information to corroborate that proposed project wages are set at the going rate for each position and geographic location.

Other Project Costs:

  • review project activities to verify whether the time being charged to the project by an administrator or executive director is reasonable and necessary; and,
  • determine whether the costs of product development or service provision are reasonable when compared to those of other organizations.

Note: For proposed projects entered in CSGC on or after December 3rd 2012 the program delivery staff should refer to the appropriate program cost category set for more details, as flat rate may be applicable.

Next, determine how well the project outcomes (such as new knowledge, the application of knowledge in a new context, a new product or process, job creation) will address the need or opportunity by:

  • discussing the possible impact of the lost opportunity—should the project not be undertaken—with the applicant;
  • describing what
  • the resulting impact would be if the project did not proceed without government funding; and,
  • assessing the benefit of the proposed outcomes in monetary terms, should the project be successful.

The question to ask is, "Has the applicant tried to establish partnerships and find other sources of funding?", then document both the rationale used to determine the answer and the findings in the project file.

It is important to keep in mind that for some programs, additional sources of funding are required – in other words, HRSDC may not provide 100% of the required project funds; therefore, please refer to program-specific guidelines.

In-kind Contributions

In-kind contributions are goods or services provided by the organization or other organizations/partners. They could include land, buildings, equipment, use of facilities, labour, goods and securities required to carry out projects and activities. Programs often accept in-kind contributions as part of an organization’s matching contribution. As such, the applicant will not be able to request reimbursement for these costs.

If, for example, the applicant donates the use of space they own, or normally use for other purposes, to the project, and will not make a claim for payment of rent, then the amount for rent can be considered as an in-kind contribution.

To be eligible as an in-kind contribution, it must be:

  • essential to the project's success;
  • eligible under the program's terms and conditions;
  • supported by a commitment from the applicant and a valuation confirmed by a departmental official during the assessment phase;
  • approved and documented by HRSDC at the initial approval or amendment phase; and,
  • recorded in the organization’s contribution agreement at fair value; applicants' non-cash assets should only be recognized when fair value can be reasonably estimated.

To confirm the value of these assets to the proposed project, assess them against objective criteria, such as prevailing consultant rates or the commercial value of rental space. Then, compare this valuation with the estimate and supporting documentation provided by the applicant. If necessary, negotiate with the applicant in good faith to overcome any difference of opinion and, ultimately, agree on the overall worth of all in- kind contributions they and their partners have offered to contribute to the project. If any doubt remains concerning the value of any asset, request an independent assessment, possibly from a regional economist or a labour market information analyst (located in Service Canada centres).

Stacking of Assistance

Every applicant must inform HRSDC of all contributions—whether of cash or in-kind— they anticipate receiving from other sources. Where the amount of a contribution made is in excess of $100,000, the guideline on the Directive of the Policy on Transfer Payments requires an end-of-project check on an organization's actual funding including total government funding received for the initiative, .This information is required in order to confirm that the applicant does not finance one set of project activities several times over using funds from various sources -- a practice known as the ‘stacking of assistance’.

When performing the budget assessment, ensure that applicants supply proof of possible funding from other sources for every project they propose. This can be done as follows:

  • reference and verify each additional source;
  • ensure each funder represents a new investment specific to the project;
  • talk to the applicant about all issues concerning other sources of revenue, requirements for repayment, and alternatives should contributors fail to deliver anticipated funds;
  • evaluate continued project viability, should funding from any other source fall through; and,
  • check program-specific terms and conditions to confirm whether the total government contribution to a given project is limited.

See Chapter 8, Other Sources of Project Funding - Stacking of Assistance for further details.

Chapter 7. Risk Assessment

Note: Grants are not subject to Risk Assessment, Management and Mitigation (RAMM).

Modern management of contribution programs balances control with flexibility by adopting consistent, risk-based management approaches, with the objective of reducing administrative requirements, particularly where the risk is low. Risk assessment and monitoring is a proactive approach to effectively manage, review and problem-solve any potential issues within a project to ensure that the agreement is implemented as approved.

Every project funded by the Department comes with a certain level of risk; there will always be circumstances and events that cannot be predicted or controlled that could, ultimately, impact success of a project including leading to failure. Given this reality, one must carefully identify, assess, communicate and manage the potential risks associated with a project in order to minimize uncertainty and maximize opportunities as it moves through the various stages of the project life cycle.

Risk refers to the effect of uncertainty on the achievement of the objectives of a project. A risk factor refers to a specific event or circumstance that is considered to be a likely contributor to the achievement or non-achievement of objectives.

7.1 The Risk Assessment, Management and Mitigation (RAMM) Approach

When assessing the risk of a project, it is understood that:

  • it is impossible to completely eliminate risk altogether, but it is possible to manage and mitigate risk by deciding what is acceptable in relation to expected results, and then to plan accordingly;
  • there is always a possibility that something could go wrong, and one must consider how serious the implications of failure might be (both for the project and the department);
  • measures must be implemented to mitigate risk;
  • projects must be monitored to ensure that the risk elements remain under control;
  • financial controls must be developed and implemented to avoid the potential loss of public funds; and
  • the Department agrees to share part of the risk with the recipient and other funders and/or partners.

The Risk Assessment, Management and Mitigation (RAMM) approach is the Department standard used to assess, manage and monitor project-related levels of risk for all funding contribution agreements. The RAMM tool assists program delivery staff to evaluate the project risk as well as to develop strategies to manage and mitigate the identified risk

Purpose of RAMM

  • RAMM is a flexible and balanced approach which allows the PDS to assess the risk of a project and/or to identify mitigation strategies and monitoring plans throughout the project life cycle as a result of changing circumstances regarding the applicant, the project activities, budget or results.
  • RAMM allows PDS to identify and manage the risks of a project and take into account previous and ongoing experience with organizations. Based on the level of risk assessed, mitigation strategies are identified at the beginning of the project.

By using RAMM and sound judgment, PDS can determine the level of risk and understand the risk factors that could prevent the project from achieving success and if required, negotiate adjustments that will ensure the success of the project.

7.2 Risk Assessment, Management and Mitigation (RAMM) Factors

The RAMM includes ten (10) risk factors, which are used to assess the risk level (low, medium, high) related to a particular organization and project.

The ten (10) risk factors (defined in section 7.5) are:

  1. project value;
  2. project duration;
  3. complexity of activities;
  4. organizational administration;
  5. stability of the board and/or organization;
  6. ability to demonstrate results;
  7. financial performance;
  8. activity performance;
  9. involvement of partners; and
  10. public sensitivity.

Note: The Canada Summer Jobs program is subject to RAMM, however, only six (6) out of the ten (10) risk factors are assessed. For more information, please refer to the program specific guidelines.

Although a project may have some of its risk factors assessed as "high" this does not necessarily mean that the project will be unsuccessful or that it will not be approved for funding. The RAMM approach allows for the development of appropriate strategies to mitigate risks by providing a comprehensive monitoring plan.

The project risk score is calculated based on the risk level selected for each individual risk factor. The project activities and financial requirements should be carefully reviewed when assessing the ten risk factors. The definitions of each risk factor must be considered as this will help in the determination of the accurate risk level.

The risk level must be accurate and reflect the current state of the project. Therefore, the project risk factors and associated justifications must be reviewed on an annual basis, or whenever issues are identified. At any time program delivery staff become aware of changes to the project, a new risk assessment should be completed (i.e. amendments) If any changes are made to the risk levels or justifications, program delivery staff need to ensure the changes are saved. If there are no changes following a review, a note to file is still required confirming that a review was completed. Managers/Team Leaders are responsible to ensure that a review of the risk levels and / or justification is completed. RAMM provides the opportunity to re-assess all risk factors at a later moment or any moment during the course of the project as information becomes available.

When a re-assessment is initiated, the ten (10) RAMM factors are pre-filled with previously assessed levels of risks and justifications. New justification must accompany each revised level of risk. The re-assessment may change one or more risk scores, which may also affect one or more risk mitigation strategies: advance payment frequency, monitoring (financial, activities, and results); and/or reporting requirements.

If a change affects one or more risk mitigation strategies, the CSGC will generate/display a warning message informing program delivery staff that a change of frequency for one or more of the risk mitigation strategies has occurred. At this time, the CSGC cannot alter the frequency of payments and reporting; the CSGC does not allow changing the payment and reporting frequency from monthly to quarterly (or vice versa).

7.3 Use of the Risk Assessment, Management and Mitigation (RAMM) tool

A new risk based methodology derived from the RAMM tool was introduced on December 17, 2012. The RAMM tool remains the same but the risk scores are used in a more strategic way, enabling a more tailored approach to managing risk, with more monitoring efforts being directed to the highest risk areas. It allows us to strategically implement monitoring at the onset.

The CSGC is programmed using specific formulas (a pre-set combination of RAMM factors), to inform program delivery staff on appropriate risk mitigation strategies, which include:

  • frequency of advance payment and reporting; and
  • frequency of monitoring (financial, activities, and results).

This approach does not change the way program delivery staff assess the ten (10) RAMM factors. Program delivery staff are still required to assign a risk level and justification for each risk factor. Once the assessed level of risks have the proper justification and are saved in the CSGC, four (4) risk scores are then displayed in a read-only format for reference. The four risk scores refer to:

  • Organizational risk (uses 5 of the factors);
  • Financial risk (uses 5 of the factors);
  • Activity risk (uses 5 of the factors); and,
  • Results risk (uses 5 of the factors).

Each score, except for the RAMM overall score, is calculated through the automatic separation of pre-determined combinations of five (5) key RAMM factors; the combination of factors is different for each relating risk (organizational, financial, activity and results).

7.4 RAMM Guidelines for funding agreements with other orders of government

When assessing risk, program delivery staff should consider that other orders of government (provincial, municipal) already have established internal monitoring and control mechanisms in place. Program delivery staff should minimize the number of financial monitoring for these agreements, and focus on the verification of activities and results. Please refer to the Monitoring and Mitigations Chapter for more details on monitoring agreements with other orders of government.

7.5 Ten (10) RAMM factors and possible mitigation strategies

When assessing the risk level for each factor, program delivery staff must identify any strategies that could be relied upon to help mitigate these risks.

Mitigation Strategy:

  • Mitigation is a proactive process to identify and determine how the management of the project can be used to reduce risk.
  • Developing mitigation strategies encourages a collaborative relationship with the recipient and provides increased opportunities to identify risk and/or issues and plan appropriate mitigation strategies to ensure success.
  • Mitigation strategies are mandatory for all medium–high or high risk factors.

The CSGC RAMM screen has a dialogue box where one can put forward any number of mitigation strategies to manage identified risks.

The following section provides possible mitigation strategies which can be considered when filling in the “mitigation boxes”; however, program delivery staff should not feel limited to these options as every project involves unique risks, and mitigation approaches should be tailored to meet those risks.

1. Project Value

The project value refers to the amount of the proposed agreement at the time of the original approval (Department’s contribution).

The CSGC has been programmed to automatically attribute a level of risk based on the total dollar value of the agreement.

The greater the dollar value, the greater the risk.

Dollar Amount Risk Level Possible mitigation strategy
$1,000,000 and more High Conduct initial visit with all partners.
$750,000 to $999,999 Medium-high
$500,000 to $749,999 Medium
$250,000 to $499,999 Medium-low
$0 to $249,999 Low
2. Project Duration

This refers to the duration, as measured in months, of the proposed project.

The CSGC has been programmed to automatically attribute a level of risk based on the duration of the project. The duration is calculated in months. Lengthier projects are attributed a higher risk level.

Time Frame (months) Risk Level Possible mitigation strategy
More than 24 months High Hold formal discussions with the recipient concerning expectations at multiple milestones (depending on level of risk).
Between 19 and 24 months Medium-high
Between 13 and 18 months Medium
Between 6 and 12 months Medium-low
Less than 6 months Low
3. Complexity of Activities

This refers to the complexity of the activities of the proposed project, based on specific project design features and delivery requirements.

Activities can be complex and may include several parts which are interconnected to make the whole project a success. As such one activity could affect the outcome of the project or create delays if it is not completed.
Complex activities or tasks usually include:

  • a combination of many associated tasks or activities which are interconnected or dependent on each other;
  • multi-layered activities;
  • innovative or new activities which have not been significantly performed or experienced through this program and are, therefore, difficult to understand, define or monitor; and,
  • inclusion of participants or the intention to offer services to one or more client groups which could include:
    • aboriginal peoples;
    • homeless people and those at risk of homelessness;
    • persons with disabilities;
    • youth; and,
    • students.

An organization that undertakes complex activities with considerable horizontal scope within a project may have greater challenges with project management, communication and delivery.

Complexity Level Risk Level Possible mitigation strategies
Very complex activities High Recommend that the recipient partners with another more experienced organization.

4. Organizational Administration

This assesses the ability of the organization to effectively administer projects (based on demonstrated evidence such as previous agreements or progress reports).

An organization has demonstrated through previous agreements or through the administration of other projects or activities that it has the capacity to administer the project because it:

  • has administrative policies and practices that support the efficient management and sound administration of projects; and,
  • applies sound management principles and due diligence, including the management and protection of personal information, in day-to-day operations and activities.

5. Stability of the Board or Organization

This entails a determination of the level of stability of the board or organization. For example, is the organization new, or does it have a new board of directors? Is the staff stable and experienced?

An organization (not-for-profit or for-profit organization) which has a stable board of directors is considered to be consistent, dependable and reliable. Generally, the more stable an organization is, the more capable it will be at managing any uncertainty with regards to future events and outcomes.

Risk will be at its lowest if the recipient has had an excellent, long-standing relationship with the Department. Generally, mechanisms and networks are in place to deal with, and manage, project issues.

9. Involvement of Partners

This refers to the level of risk associated with the involvement of partners.  What are the impacts on the success of the project?

While most departmental funding programs require the involvement of partners or third parties, it may add an element of risk. Generally, the greater the number of partners or third parties who participate in the project, the more difficult it may become to obtain and measure agreement results. Risk increases when partners are involved if:

  • there is a danger of one or more partners withdrawing funding or support;
  • project success is contingent upon the timing of partner contributions; or,
  • issues arise over product ownership or project control.

Partner: a person or organization that contributes to the overall success of the project. The contribution can be cash or non-cash assets (also referred to as “in-kind” contributions). A partnership does not necessarily require a legal agreement.

Third Party: a person or organization that has signed an agreement with the organization under the terms and conditions of a master agreement between the organization and the federal government.

10. Public Sensitivity

This factor refers to the level of sensitivity related to the work being undertaken or to the nature of the organization, as well as the possible impact of the project on the public.

Some projects may be subject to a significant degree of public scrutiny due to the nature of the activities or the specific program's public profile. For such projects, the level of risk should be assessed in terms of the potential impact that it could have on the Department or the public. When assessing this factor, consider the risk and potential impacts of seeing project-related activities reported in the front pages of a daily newspaper.

Chapter 8. Recommendation, Review and Approval

Referring to the 2012 Ops Guide, Chapter 7

Immediately following application assessment, a three-step approval process begins. This is the phase in the project life cycle where HRSDC staff and senior managers ensure due diligence has been performed when committing public funds in support of new projects.

Departmental approval involves three key steps:

  1. the recommendation process;
  2. review by senior management; and,
  3. funding approval.

Many applications for funding will be approved but others could be rejected at any point during these three stages, whether by the program delivery staff in charge of the file, senior managers, signing authorities in the approval chain or, very rarely, MPs, MPPs or MLAs when their concurrence is required. Most often, however, program delivery staff reject inadequate applications during the assessment, review or recommendation phases. Regardless the reason for rejection, the application must, at all times, be handled professionally with a sense of tact and diplomacy.

8.1 Recommendation

The recommendation process follows directly from the results of the assessment phase; it documents the reasons for recommending either the approval or rejection of an application, and is based upon the assessment performed by program delivery staff and, in addition, possibly on an initial review by managers. Where the assessment phase is about collecting information, the recommendation phase is about summarizing this information as a concise and accurate recommendation rationale and report based on assessment results, including consultation with colleagues, community experts, and possibly, an internal review committee.

The Recommendation Rationale and Report

Whether the project receives a positive or negative recommendation, program delivery staff must complete the CSGC Recommendation Rationale screen. The recommendation rationale (which becomes the basis for a recommendation report) can be written using brief narrative paragraphs or bullets.

Although the CSGC Recommendation Rationale screen does not list each of the items formally indicated in the recommendation section of the Proposal Assessment, Recommendation and Approval Form, one should include enough detail to assist an official unfamiliar with the proposed project or applicant in making an informed decision relative to project acceptance or rejection.

The recommendation rationale must, therefore:

  • outline the reasons for approving or rejecting the application; and,
  • provide details concerning:
    • the applicant's mandate, background and history with the Department;
    • how well the project objectives address departmental priorities, programobjectives and guidelines;
    • project activities;
    • how well the applicant demonstrates the expertise and capacities required tomanage the project and achieve desired results. Do they, for example, have thenecessary staff, space and equipment? Is their plan solid and cost- effective?
    • expected project results, such as outputs and outcomes;
