    • any other information deemed appropriate to support the recommendation andaddress program requirements; and,
    • conditions for approval, explaining any issues raised during the assessmentphase—contributions from partners, environmental assessment follow-up, jointfunding, etc.—that must be addressed prior to, or within, the agreement (you candocument these on the CSGC Additional Conditions screen).

Once the rationale is complete, print the CSGC Recommendation Report screen for a hard copy summary of the project recommendation (pre-filled), which all authorities can then review and sign.

The Recommendation Report is final upon signature of the relevant program delivery staff, reviewing authority (such as a manager) and approval authority (the Minister or delegated authority).

7.2 Review

By and large, the review phase of the approval process gives program delivery staff an opportunity to seek the advice of colleagues in reviewing their recommendation and supporting rationale. It also provides senior managers with an opportunity to focus on the details of a recommendation before confirming—or possibly, rejecting—the recommended decision.

For more complex initiatives with larger budgets, many HRSDC transfer payment programs rely on the use of Internal Review Committees (IRC) to make balanced, objective and transparent decisions about project funding. Such committees support the delegated signing authority that ultimately approves an application by ensuring due diligence takes place when considering the field of eligible applications.

Internal Review Committees

At a certain dollar value level, or for large or complex applications (often involving technical or specialized projects), consulting an Internal Review Committee (IRC) -- whose members could include independent subject matter experts, departmental staff, other government officials and community representatives – will be required.

An IRC, which brings more people into the process of assessing and recommending an application, can take one of two formats:

  • For applications requesting $350,001 or more, an in-person, video or teleconferencemeeting to finalize applicant recommendations is automatically required. Documentsare distributed to review committee members in preparation for the meeting anddiscussion must also cover identified risks and the implementation of appropriate riskmanagement strategies.
  • For applications requesting $350,000 or less, feedback and resolution typically occurwithout face-to-face meetings. As with the other format, print or electronic documentsare shared with review committee members, and discussion must also cover identified risks and the implementation of appropriate risk management strategies.

The use of an IRC offers several benefits:

  • greater process objectivity and transparency;
  • a wider range of views;
  • an increased level of community involvement;
  • a broader mix of expertise;
  • a solid foundation of support for program recommendations;
  • a stronger rationale for the decisions made and conditions applied; and,
  • more feedback available to the applicant.

While the use of IRCs may significantly benefit the assessment process, one must weigh such benefits against the investment of both human and financial (O&M) resources required. Within this context, the following should be considered:

  • number of reviewers necessary;
  • range of expertise required;
  • availability of subject matter experts;
  • development of a standard evaluation grid or guidelines to ensure consistentevaluations among committee members;
  • weight attributed to reviewer comments;
  • turnaround timelines;
  • adequacy of administrative supports; and,
  • obligation to pay honoraria or travel expenses should committee members beinvited from outside the Department.

There is a particular need to ensure ethical practices are adhered to at all times by all members. The committee, for example, should decide at the outset how to resolve any potential conflicts of interest that may arise. Privacy and confidentiality must also be maintained throughout.

Ultimately, the Internal Review Committee process leads to a record of decision, which then becomes a source document used to draft the funding agreement and associated schedules; it must, therefore, be placed in the project file. The record of decision, which must be signed off by the Internal Review Committee Chair, may also require subsequent Internal Review Committee meetings to address any significant issues that might arise during the project life cycle.

Although external review committees also exist—for the Community Entity Model of the Homelessness Partnering Strategy; and, New Horizons for Seniors Program—the majority of review committees used by transfer payment programs are internal.

Check program-specific guidelines for a more detailed understanding of the process to be followed within the particular program.

For more information, including local, regional and national membership and associated roles and responsibilities, please see also the Program Operations Branch Directive on Internal Review Committees.

8.3 Pre-Commitment of Funds

The Project Pre-Commitment screen of the Common System for Grants and Contributions (CSGC) is used to submit project and financial information to the Corporate Management Systems (CMS). This information is used to set-up soft commitments to ensure that the program budget does not become over-committed while applications are awaiting approval from the Minister or the delegated authority. All programs, with the exception of Work Sharing, are required to pre-commit funds.

If the agreement extends beyond the current fiscal year, the pre-commitment funding for the potential agreement must be split into the estimated amounts to be expended in each fiscal year as reflected in the forecast of project expenditures and the Manage Fiscal Year Split screen, and reflected in the CMS. Refer also to the ‘Committing Funds’ section of Chapter 8. While a project budget is always prepared for the entire duration of the project, HRSDC funds are always committed and accounted for on a fiscal year basis. The Manage Fiscal Year Splits screen in the CSGC is used to allocate the total HRSDC contribution amount to fiscal years as well as change the existing fiscal year allocation.

Please note that when a pre-commitment transaction is cancelled, the system will return the funding back to the program budget.

8.4 Approval

If the application is favourably assessed, program delivery staff prepare a recommendation that outlines the rationale for approval and any attached conditions on the CSGC Recommendation Rationale screen. Individuals with delegated signing authority must verify and approve the recommendation in most cases; in others, Ministerial approval or the concurrence of other parties, such as MPs, MPPs or MLAs, may have to be obtained.

For the majority of programs, and dependent upon the level of funding, the approval process involves the following steps:

  1. Once the application has been assessed and recommended for funding by programdelivery staff, the Recommendation Report is printed from the CSGC and sent forapproval to the first authorization level as indicated on the Approval/Rejection screen.
  2. The ‘Approved By’ section should be signed by the individual with delegatedsigning authority for the specified program. Please refer to the Financial DelegationInstrument for complette details related to specific programs.
  3. Each identified approval authority signs the hard copy of the RecommendationReport.
  4. When all necessary signatures have been obtained, record every decision on theCSGC Record Approval/Rejection screen.
  5. If one of the levels rejects the project or requires changes, the report is returned to theresponsible program delivery staff for the required revisions, following whichthe revised recommendation goes through the approval process again.

Applications can be approved either with or without conditions.

Once approved, and the funding commitment has been verified, program delivery staff can provide the applicant with formal notification of approval (taking into account the 5- business day wait period, as outlined below). When contacting the applicant, ensure they understand that:

  • the funding agreement must be signed before activities can begin; and,
  • expenses incurred before the project start date will not be reimbursed, except in rareand exceptional circumstances (for example, supplies must be purchased in remotelocations before cold temperatures prevent delivery), and require approval from seniormanagement.
5- Business Day Wait Period

Once official approval has been received and entered into the CSGC, program delivery staff are obliged to wait for a period of five business days before the organization may be contacted in order to communicate the funding decision. This time period is meant to provide the Minister’s Office with the opportunity to issue announcements, should it be wished.

The operational guidance is worded as follows:

“Project Officers need to enter the date of approval signatures into the CSGC within 48 hours of that approval. The 5-business day wait period will be counted from the first business day following the data entry in the CSGC. Waivers for the 5-business day wait period are to be requested for exceptional circumstances only and made by programs through their respective ADM/EHSM office.
The 5-business day wait period was introduced to ensure that announcement opportunities can be considered before successful applicants are contacted by any departmental officials and informed of their project being approved. This is particularly important for regionally approved files, where a daily CSGC report of approved projects is produced and reviewed at National Headquarters to support announcement decisions.”
Delegated Signing Authority

While approval authority is ultimately the Minister's responsibility, it is often delegated to officials at national, regional and local levels. Because this varies from program to program and according to the project value, please refer to the Financial Delegation Instrument for the program-specific delegation of authority. The CSGC also displays a message advising users of the appropriate minimum level of signing authority required for a specific program and confirms when the appropriate level has been secured.

Obtaining Ministerial Approval

Among the programs that do require the Minister's signature, the process may vary slightly in the execution of specific details but typically follows these steps:

  1. Program delivery staff send the printed CSGC Recommendation Report to theauthorization levels indicated on the Approval/Rejection screen, including theappropriate regional/national authority, for review.
  2. The Recommendation Report is sent to the Minister's Office for signature,accompanied by the supporting rationale.
  3. The Minister signs the approval section of the Report.
  4. Program delivery staff record the approval in the CSGC Approval/Rejection screen,which, consequently, initiates the 5-business day wait period.

The responsibleofficers are required to enter the date of approval signatures into the CSGC within48 hours of approval being granted.

Obtaining Concurrence

Some programs require concurrence from federal Members of Parliament (MPs), members of provincial parliaments or legislative assemblies (MPPs, MLAs) or others such as regional development agencies (for example, Western Economic Diversification). There is no standard concurrence form; instead, these are developed locally.

Program delivery staff must check for program-specific procedures but, in general, obtaining concurrence involves the following steps:

  1. Once approved, either support staff or program delivery staff send individual projects or lists of projects to an MP's office along with the recommendation rationale for each.
  2. If the MP requests adjustments, revises or rejects a project, program delivery staff will negotiate with the applicant or the MP to obtain concurrence.
  3. In many cases, the MP indicates concurrence by signing a concurrence form; when lists of approved projects are sent, the MP may indicate concurrence by signing the entire list of projects.

When obtaining concurrence is a program requirement, projects cannot begin until this has been received.

Non-consensus

In very rare situations, a disagreement may arise between program delivery staff assessing and recommending the application, and the local MP or other party whose concurrence is required. In these cases, and if their program allows, program delivery staff may choose to note their disagreement by filing a non-consensus report that describes the reasons for the difference of opinion.

To do so, the non-consensus form must be completed, signed and submitted, together with the completed CSGC Recommendation Report, to the manager. The manager, in turn, will take any necessary action, possibly forwarding it to more senior authorities, including – if appropriate -- to the Minister's Office, for comment and a final decision.

Approval with Conditions

When applications are recommended with conditions attached, this information should be shared with applicants as soon as possible; the earlier applicants are informed of the conditions, the more quickly they will be able to address them.

Speak with applicants over the phone or in person and follow up in writing to ensure they fully understand:

  • the details of all required conditions;
  • the steps they must take to address these conditions before the project can proceed, or, if applicable, clarify any conditions to be met during the course of the project;
  • that conditions must be met, the project approved, the funds committed and the agreement signed before activities can begin; and,
  • that expenses incurred prior to the agreement start date will not be reimbursed.
Formal Notification of Approval

Once an application is formally approved, an organization must have a signed agreement in place before they can proceed with project activities funded by HRSDC.

Applicants are informed of project approval when program delivery staff contact them by phone and follow up in writing with a letter from the Minister, MP, Department or program area. One should enter notes to file about telephone conversations in the CSGC using the Record Approval/Rejection screen and keep a hard copy of any signed letters in the project file.

Refer to program-specific guidelines and requirements for more precise direction concerning notifying applicants of project approval.

Rejection

If, however, it is felt that, after working closely with them, the application should be rejected; one should phone or meet with them in order to explain why the application will not be recommended for funding. Remember to maintain a professional demeanour at all times when saying no.

During this point in the assessment or recommendation phases of the project life cycle, the applicant, upon being informed of a negative recommendation, may choose to either withdraw their application or continue with the formal process; senior managers or a review committee may later decide to reject (or, less likely, support) the application during the review or approval phases.

Whatever the applicant’s choice, the reasons for recommending the rejection of an application must be documented on the CSGC Recommendation Rationale screen.

Reasons for rejection can include (but are not limited to) the following:

  • the application was submitted late;
  • the proposed project doesn't meet local, regional or national departmental planning priorities;
  • the application does not meet the program's terms and conditions;
  • project goals and objectives do not correspond with those of the program;
  • the proposed budget exceeds what is allowed under program criteria;
  • the activities cannot be completed within program time frames;
  • the applicant has not established their capacity to carry out the project;
  • the application is generally weak or poorly constructed;
  • there is strong community opposition to the activities or applicant; and,
  • a high participation rate has resulted in program funds insufficient to recommend all the application received.

Applicants not approved for funding should be informed, in writing, as soon as possible of the status of their file.

Confirm whether or not a program-specific letter template exists for use when rejecting an application. In (or attached to) this letter, one must include a rationale that outlines the reasons for rejection. The Program Director, Manager or a Senior Authority, other than the program delivery staff who reviewed the application, must sign the rejection letter.

Once the letter has been sent, the status of the application is to be entered into the CSGC—including the file name and location of the rejection letter—and a copy of this correspondence added to the project file.

Saying No

Informing the applicant of a negative decision may entail a delicate conversation requiring program delivery staff to remain professional; speak with them directly, either in person or over the telephone, before sending a written letter of rejection.

Consider discussing the recommendation with a colleague before speaking to an applicant as this will give one an opportunity to practice presenting the rationale for a decision.

When informing an applicant that their application will not be recommended for funding, one should calmly, clearly and concisely:

  • describe the process used to reach the decision;
  • present an objective rationale for the recommendation;
  • emphasize positive aspects of the application while indicating areas for improvement;
  • reference information collected during the assessment phase to support the rationale;
  • point out ways in which the application does not address departmental or program objectives -- should this be the case -- and emphasize the need for consistency in meeting these overarching criteria;
  • mention the results of consultations with outside experts, internal managers and review committees to demonstrate that the decision was arrived at through consensus;
  • offer alternatives, such as other programs in HRSDC, federal departments and agencies, other levels of government, and the private sector; and,
  • encourage, if appropriate, the organization to submit applications in the future.

If an applicant is persistent but has submitted a application that is obviously inappropriate for funding, one should:

  • offer reasonable options, if any exist;
  • clearly reiterate exactly why their application does not meet program criteria or funding priorities, and suggest alternate sources of funding; and,
  • be clear that the decision will not change.

Do not hesitate to ask the manager or another colleague for support.

Chapter 9. The Standard Funding Agreement

Please refer to the 2012 Ops Guide, Chapter 8A

Note: For files created prior to December 15, 2012, refer to Chapter 8 B The Funding Agreement.

At this stage of the project life cycle, program delivery staff focuses on the development of a funding agreement that sets out the provisions that will bind the parties to it. Every agreement must be consistent with the Treasury Board Policy on Transfer Payments, its associated Directive, the HRSDC Grants and Contributions Policy, and program-specific terms, conditions and guidelines.

The Treasury Board Directive outlines minimal requirements for the following types of funding agreements:

  1. grants to other orders of government
  2. grants to foreign organizations
  3. grants to other organizations
  4. contributions to other orders of government
  5. contributions to foreign organizations
  6. contributions to aboriginal organizations
  7. contributions to other organizations
  8. upfront multi-year funding

The signed agreement is evidence of the commitment made between HRSDC and the organization. Once signed, the terms cannot be changed without a formal amendment and the consent of all parties involved. That being said, there is some flexibility worked into most agreements to allow one or both parties to make unilateral or collaborative adjustments to certain aspects of the agreement without a formal amendment.

Both the Department and the organization must comply with the provisions of the funding agreement. The Department's responsibility is usually limited to making timely payments of its funding to the organization whereas the organization has a whole array of responsibilities. These range from achieving the planned results, to managing the project soundly and ethically, to properly recognizing the Department’s financial support towards the project, to reporting to the Department on progress and results, and to, in relation to contributions, reporting on activities and expenditures.

A written agreement both formalizes the commitments made between HRSDC and the organization and ensures accountability for the use of public funds. It also becomes the primary instrument for project monitoring and evaluation.

The creation of a new funding agreement involves the following steps:

  • Confirming Available Funds and Applicant Interest
  • Setting up the Agreement
  • Committing Funds
  • Signing the Agreement

This chapter also covers the following topics:

  • Delegated Authority
  • The Agreement (or Initial) Visit
  • Up-front Multi-year Funding
  • Incorporating Risk Management
  • Avoiding Employer-Employee Relationships
  • Employment Equity Issues
  • Revenue Generation

8.1 Confirming Available Funds and Applicant Interest

Once an application for funding is recommended and approved, program delivery staff must:

  • if pre-commitment of funds was not completed during the recommendation andapproval phase, check with the appropriate financial officer to verify that fundsremain available to meet the commitment;
  • at the expiry of the prescribed wait period, confirm the applicant’s interest inproceeding with the project;
  • review again all project and organization information on file to ensure it isaccurate and up-to-date and to address any remaining concerns;
  • obtain from the applicant, generally using the generic departmental form, adocument that identifies the organization’s authorized signatories for agreementpurposes, for cheque purposes, and, as applicable, for claim forms, forecast ofproject expenditures and activity report purposes; and,
  • obtain specimen signatures of each of the authorized signatories identified by the applicant.

Note: Specimen signatures will no longer be requested from organizations prior to knowing if funding would be approved. This will eliminate duplication of work for program delivery staff having to validate the signatures prior to signing the agreement and reduce the burden for organizations.

At the time of agreement negotiation organizations must indicate which individuals in their organization have the legal authority to sign agreements, cheques, claim forms and reports. The Department requires a specimen of these signatures and an indication of the number and combination of signatures required for each of the various documents.

At a minimum, the organization will have to provide specimen signatures of its delegates for agreement purposes at the time of agreement signing. Any missing specimen signatures must be collected by program delivery staff prior to processing of the first claim form.

The Signing Officers form is a document that is required to be used to validate the officials who are being authorized to sign on behalf of an organization for agreement, cheque and claim form purposes. This form is also used to support claim payments and monitoring throughout the project life cycle and should be referenced often. To validate the officials named on the Signing Officers form, program delivery staff should do their best to verify the accuracy of what is being reported. This can be done in a variety of ways:

  • Verify information listed from the organization’s website
  • Request a current Board of Director’s listing from the organization
  • Review the organization’s bi-laws (or other supporting documentation) that wassubmitted with the application

To ensure program funds are being managed appropriately, it is very important to ensure that program delivery staff verify or validate the information presented in this form prior to signing the Standard Contribution Agreement. If there is any doubt as to the accuracy of the information being submitted by an organization, it is extremely important that this be raised to the Team Leader/Manager immediately.

Applicants may choose to sign the application and subsequent documents—such as the funding agreement—with a stamped signature, which is legally binding. If a stamped signature is used, the applicant must provide a copy of it in addition to the specimen signature.

A faxed signature may also be acceptable except where existing directives or program guidelines dictate otherwise. If an application is received by fax, each page must bear the signee's initials, and the entire document must be clear and legible.

Furthermore, applicants may need to provide information about their accounting practices and insurance coverage, which HRSDC staff might use to verify authenticity.

If the applicant declines to enter into a funding agreement for any reason, program delivery staff must obtain a written confirmation of withdrawal from the applicant and place it on the file prior to closing the file. If the applicant does not comply with the request for a withdrawal notice within a reasonable timeframe (approximately 30 days), program delivery staff should prepare a letter confirming the withdrawal, have it signed by the program manager, send it to the applicant, place a copy on file, and close the file.

Reminder: All letters (or equivalent communications) placed on the paper file should also be placed on the electronic file using the CSGC Document Location feature.

If the applicant agrees to move forward, program delivery staff should immediately start preparing the funding agreement.

9.2 Setting up the Agreement

The process of setting up an agreement is currently split among two phases in the CSGC, namely, the Grant Letter / Agreement Set-up phase and the Create Grant Letter / Agreement phases.

As specified in the introduction to this chapter, the Treasury Board Directive on Transfer Payments identifies eight types of funding agreements. HRSDC primarily uses the following types of transfer payments:

  1. contributions to other organizations; and,
  2. grants to other organizations.

At HRSDC, programs that fund simple, low materiality grants may use an application- agreement. This is essentially an application form signed by the applicant that doubles as the grant agreement once signed by HRSDC.

Canada Summer Jobs uses a contribution application-agreement.

Standard Agreement (SA) Templates

HRSDC has adopted for department-wide use a standard agreement template for contributions (SCA). This template is suited to conclude agreements where funding is drawn either from the Consolidated Revenue Fund or from the Employment Insurance Account (under Part II of the Employment Insurance Act), by virtue of the Terms and Conditions of a particular program.

Adoption of an SA template for grants is planned for the near future. This template will share many characteristics with the SA template for contributions. For the time being, programs use their own template.

The departmental Gs and Cs training curriculum includes a Desk Aid that offers plain language versions of the SA clauses, an explanation of the SA clause numbering scheme and quick references to applicable CSGC screens/functionality.

Agreement Structure

The SCA template is composed of up to five sections:

  • Identification of the parties to the agreement
  • Articles of Agreement
  • Schedule A – Project Description
  • Schedule B – Financial Provisions
  • Schedule C – Additional Provisions
Identification of Parties to the Agreement

The federal government is always identified as the first party to a funding agreement. In the HRSDC-Service Canada-Labour context, the federal government could be one of the following three persons:

  • The Minister of HRSDC
  • The Minister of Labour
  • The Employment Insurance Commissioner

These persons are formerly identified in funding agreements as being representatives of “Her Majesty the Queen in right of Canada”, however, throughout the remainder of the agreement, they are simply referred to as ‘Canada’.

The second party to the agreement is identified at the beginning of the agreement by its proper legal name and, following this, simply referred to as “the Recipient”. Where the organization is an unincorporated association, the corporate name of the associated persons should be reflected here and a clause added to Schedule C – Additional Provisions (see “Ad-hoc clauses”) identifying these persons by name.

Articles of Agreement

This section contains a basic set of non-financial clauses that generally apply to all projects regardless of the funding program. Of the preamble and thirty-five (35) articles, four articles only are subject to vary from one project to the next. Where applicable, these potential variations will be described below.

The 35 articles are identified as follows:

  • Agreement
  • Interpretation
  • Effective Date andDuration
  • Purpose
  • Canada’s Funding
  • Appropriation
  • Reduction or Termination of Funding
  • RecipientDeclarations
  • Project Records
  • Canada’s Right to Audit
  • Financial and ActivityMonitoring
  • Inquiry by the AuditorGeneral of Canada
  • Final Report
  • Evaluation
  • Contracting Procedures
  • Termination of Agreement
  • Indemnification
  • Insurance
  • Relationship betweenthe Parties and Non- liability of Canada
  • Conflict of interest
  • Informing Canadians ofthe Government ofCanada’s Funding
  • Access to Information
  • Proactive Disclosure
  • Disposition ofCapital Assets
  • Intellectual Property
  • Notices
  • Dispute Resolution
  • Assignment of the Agreement
  • Successors and Assigns
  • Compliance with Laws
  • Applicable Law
  • Amendment
  • Unincorporated Association
  • Counterparts
  • English Language
The Preamble

The articles of agreement begin with a preamble that sets out the context within which the agreement is being made and is to be understood. The context is expressed as a series of statements beginning with the word ‘Whereas’. Although the preamble does not set out any obligations for one party or the other, it is still considered as forming part of the legal agreement.

The first 'Whereas' statement describes the specific program (or programs) under which the project is being funded and, thus, is subject to change from one project to the next.

Agreement

This section lists the documents that comprise the entire agreement and establishes their authority over the parties' dealings with respect to the project.

This list is subject to change from one project to the next in that a number of programs do not require 'Schedule C – Additional Provisions'. When this is the case, the reference to Schedule C shall be excluded from this section.

Interpretation

To ensure that the parties to the agreement understand and interpret it in the same way, this section defines a number of terms that reoccur throughout the agreement.

Effective Date and Duration

This section sets out the date as of when the parties shall be bound by the agreement. This is to be distinguished from the project start date, which is generally a later date.

This section also establishes that certain agreement provisions may still apply after the agreement has expired or has been terminated by either party; essentially, all clauses that specify a timeframe beyond the project end date still apply (e.g. 9.2; 10.1; 12.1; 13.1; 14.1; 17.1; 24.2).

Purpose

This section reiterates a statement from the preamble in order to clearly establish the purpose of the Department’s funding and, in relation to SAs for contributions, limit the organization’s use of the Department’s funding towards eligible expenditures.

Canada's Funding

This section establishes that there are, as set out in 'Schedule B', limits to the amount of funding HRSDC is committed to providing to the organization under the terms of the agreement.

Appropriation

This section establishes that the Department's funding is contingent upon broader funding decisions as made by Parliament.

Reduction or Termination of Funding

This section acknowledges that broader funding decisions made by Parliament, the Treasury Board or HRSDC could ultimately have a negative effect on the organization's project. The section gives HRSDC the authority to reduce its overall and fiscal year maximum funding amounts, or to terminate the agreement altogether.

That being said, it also gives the organization the opportunity to discontinue the project, without any harm to its reputation, should the organization believe that the decrease in funding would make the continuation of the project unsustainable.

This is the only situation in which an organization is given the authority to terminate the funding agreement without notice of default. HRSDC, however, could terminate an agreement for convenience's sake in order to accommodate the organization where a notice of default would be inappropriate (see Termination of Agreement).

Recipient Declarations

This section, formally known as "Declaration Regarding Outstanding Amounts Owed to the Government" and "Lobbying Act", contains two declarations made by the organization to provide HRSDC with assurance that the organization is in good financial standing relative to the Government of Canada and to ensure that the organization is respecting the provisions of Canada's Lobbying Act.

Amounts owing in default are debts for which the organization has not yet made satisfactory repayment arrangements. They may be set off against funds made available via a new funding agreement, after the organization has been informed of this possibility as per the set-off provision within the Treasury Board Directive on Transfer Payments. Part XI, subsection 155. (1) of the Financial Administration Act, however, outlines the Minister's right to deny consent to any set-off proposed.

If a set-off is applied, the appropriate federal department or agency would receive the resulting payment to offset the outstanding debt, and the organization would not be reimbursed for the resulting loss of project funds.

Applications incorporate a notice to applicants informing them that they are responsible for ensuring anyone who lobbies on their behalf is registered with the Office of the Registrar of Lobbyists as pursuant to the Lobbying Act. All organizations should, therefore, understand federal policies concerning lobbying.

Program delivery staff must not interpret the Lobbying Act for applicants or organizations. Such requests should be directed to the Office of the Commissioner of Lobbying of Canada or to the organization's own advisors.

Project Records

This section identifies three types of project records that the organization will have to preserve during the project and for a period of six years afterwards.

Canada's Right to Audit

This section does not require the organization to self-audit or to hire an external auditor at its own expense; it simply secures, for a specified period, the Department's right to audit the organization's books and records (at the Department's expense) and commits the organization to cooperate with us in any such audit.

This section does not, as does the section on financial and activity monitoring, require the organization to provide us with copies and extracts (at their cost and as an eligible expenditure) of their books and records, but simply requires them to allow the Department to acquire (at the Department's cost) such copies and extracts when requested.

Financial and Activity Monitoring

This section secures for HRSDC the right to conduct on- and off-site monitors of project activities and expenditures throughout the project period only (i.e. inclusively between the project start and end dates).

HRSDC may, on the basis of this clause, also conduct results monitors.

Inquiry by the Auditor General of Canada

This section establishes the Auditor General of Canada's legal right to inquire into a number of factors, with respect to an organization, under any funding agreement.

This legal right stems from subsection 7.1 (1) of the Auditor General Act which limits its own application to organizations excluding the following:

  1. a Crown corporation;
  2. a departmental corporation;
  3. the government of a foreign state, a provincial government or a municipality, or anyof their agencies;
  4. a band, as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Indian Act, any member of the council or any agency of the band or an aboriginal body that is party to a self-government agreement given effect by an Act of Parliament or any of their agencies;
  5. a corporation that is controlled by a municipality or a government other than theGovernment of Canada; or,
  6. an international organization.

Hence, an organization which can be classified within one of the above-mentioned categories will not be subject to an inquiry by the Auditor General of Canada, as per the limitations specified in the Auditor General Act, should an agreement be negotiated with such an organization.

Final Report

This section sets out the organization's obligation to provide the Department with a final report for the project regardless of the program providing the funding. Some programs, such as the 'Homelessness Partnering Strategy Designated Communities', 'Aboriginal Homelessness' and 'Rural and Remote Communities' streams, require a more specific final report from organizations. When this is the case, a clause shall be included in Schedule C to this effect.

Evaluation

This section commits the organization to cooperate with HRSDC should the organization's project be selected for review generally as part of a formative or summative evaluation of the funding program. It also sets out the manner in which the organization will be expected to cooperate.

Contracting Procedures

This section sets out to ensure that the organization uses the Department's funding in a way that does not favour contractors on the basis of relationship.

Given that there may be situations where it would be in the best interest of the project for the organization to:

  • issue a sole source contract;
  • procure goods or services from a contractor with which it has a proscribedrelationship; or,
  • hire a contractor or consultant in order to manage all, or a portion, of the project onits behalf, this section allows departmental officials to authorize such exceptions.

Authorizations under this section may only be granted by the departmental official with delegated authority to sign the agreement / minor amendment. They must be communicated to the organization in writing (an email is acceptable) and must be in respect of a written request to this effect provided by the organization to the Department and containing appropriate justification.

Program delivery staff must clearly document all requests and authorizations under this section in the project file.

Note: The Department must refrain from refusing to refer a candidate or pay a contribution to hire a person who meets all eligibility requirements for the sole reason that the individual is a member of the immediate family of an organization. Such action would be discriminatory on the grounds of family or marital status under the Canadian Human Rights Act. Although the Department wants to avoid any conflict of interest in the use of public funds, it also wants to avoid any discriminatory practice in the application of its nepotism policy.

Termination of Agreement

This section begins by listing five situations linked to the stability of the organization's performance with regard to the project that might lead HRSDC to terminate the funding agreement.

Its clause set out financial implications related to termination of the agreement. It provides for an interim measure whereby program delivery staff may withhold any claim or advance payment for a reasonable period of time until the organization has addressed the issue.

Program delivery staff should generally be following the Escalation Protocol when invoking this clause.

There is a second part to this section that establishes HRSDC's right to terminate an agreement 'for convenience'. Termination due to a reduction or termination of funding is one type of termination for convenience.

The 'termination for convenience' clause establishes a means for HRSDC to terminate an agreement when termination for default should not be considered because the organization is not in default. Usually, this will be done upon request by the organization to this effect.

The final part of this section sets out to ensure that the organization protects itself against onerous cancellation costs linked to project-related contracts.

Indemnification

This section rests on the notion that Canada is a funder of the project and not an employer of, or partner to, the organization (see Relationship between the parties and non-liability of Canada). It requires the organization to protect HRSDC against all project-related legal action attempted by any third parties.

Insurance

This section goes hand-in-hand with the Indemnification clause. It requires the organization to purchase a general liability insurance policy in order to enable the organization to protect itself and HRSDC against all legal action related to the project that any third party may attempt.

If a new general liability insurance policy is contracted, or an existing one is enhanced by the organization, in relation to the project, the cost of the insurance is considered an eligible cost.

Relationship between the Parties and Non-liability of Canada

This section establishes that HRSDC and the organization are fully independent parties; it also requires that the organization, in no way, conveys the contrary to the public, to contractors, to partners or to any other party.

For more on this topic please see section 8.8 below, Avoiding Employer-Employee Relationships.

Conflict of Interest

This section specifies that the organization supports the awareness of conflict of interest policies which apply to public servants and parliamentarians.

For information on policies that apply to public servants, see the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Service.

For information on policies that apply to parliamentarians, see the Library of Parliament publication entitled Conflict of Interest Codes for Parliamentarians: A Long Road.

Informing Canadians of the Government of Canada's Funding

This section specifies that HRSDC's funding of the project is appropriately recognized, that the Department has an opportunity to conduct or participate in the first public announcement of its funding, and that it has an opportunity to conduct or participate in any other public announcement related to the project.

(See CoE Bulletin no. 8 for further information regarding this clause.)

Access to Information

This section informs the organization that HRSDC is subject to the Access to Information Act and, as such, the information it shares with the Department in relation to the project could potentially be accessed by the Canadian public.

Although some materials—such as trade secrets and certain financial, scientific, business and technical information—can remain confidential under this Act, each request is dealt with on a case-by-case basis, and confidentiality cannot be guaranteed by way of the agreement.

Proactive Disclosure

This section informs the organization that in accordance with the Government of Canada's commitment to proactive disclosure of grant and contribution awards, basic information about the project could be disclosed by the Department to the Canadian public.

In effect, all grants and contributions valued at $25,000 or more will be disclosed to the Canadian public via the HRSDC Web site.

Disposition of Capital Assets

This section specifies that the organization does not sell, destroy or, in any other way, dispose of any capital asset purchased with HRSDC funding until the project is over. The clause also gives program delivery staff the right to instruct the organization on how to dispose of the capital assets in a manner of the Department's choosing, the two most desirable methods of which are explicitly set out in the clause.

Program delivery staff must never instruct an organization to turn the title to a capital asset over to HRSDC for its own use or to other federal departments or agencies, including the Crown Assets Disposal Corporation.

Unless it is likely that the organization will continue with similar activities following the project and another participant or another employee could use the equipment, a capital asset that is purchased specifically for a project participant or project staff member with a disability should be turned over to the individual at the end of the project.

Property/leasehold improvements (i.e. alterations or renovations that significantly increase the performance, value or capability of a capital asset or extends its useful or economic life by more than a year) are not subject to the 'Disposition of Capital Assets' provisions of the agreement but, when incurred in order to benefit a facility offering services to a targeted community, they are generally subject to repayment provisions.

Note:The definition of 'capital assets' may vary between programs in terms of the threshold amount set out in the clause (e.g. the threshold for aboriginal programs is generally "more than $5,000" (before taxes) as opposed to "more than $1,000” (before taxes) for all other programs).

Also note: Some funding agreements require organizations, via a generic optional clause, to provide annual financial reports to the Department that include a detailed listing of capital assets leased or purchased by the organization with HRSDC funding during the period of the financial report.

Intellectual Property

This section identifies the organization's ownership of intellectual property and copyright for products resulting from the agreement and secures a number of rights for the Department regarding these products including:

  • the right to having HRSDC's contribution properly recognized on the work;
  • the right to securing a copy of any such work; and,
  • the right to use the work as desired except for selling it to clientele that theorganization would otherwise sell it to.

An organization may choose to register the copyright in order to ensure greater proof and clarity regarding such ownership. The registration cost, however, would only be deemed eligible if the registration process was listed as a project activity under Schedule A of the agreement.

Notices

This section explains the manner in which the Department and the organization are to exchange notices, documents and any other information.

Dispute Resolution

This section specifies the means of resolving conflict or misunderstanding between the parties, regarding the agreement, with the intention of avoiding legal proceedings.

Assignment of the Agreement

This section explains that the organization may not transfer the benefits or obligations of the agreement to another party, in whole or in part, without HRSDC's consent.

It is important to note that when an assignment is made, the organization is not discharged of its obligations towards the Department, meaning it must monitor the third party to which the assignment is made.

There is, however, one arrangement by which an organization may transfer all of its benefits and obligations under the agreement to a third party, and thus be discharged of all its obligations vis-à-vis the Department – a 'novation' is generally used when an organization:

  • merges with another organization, or,
  • is replaced due to poor health, death or other unforeseen circumstances, and,
  • no changes to the project description, financial provisions or any additionalprovisions are being requested.

Program delivery staff should discuss potential novation situations with management prior to approval, and senior management (whether the regional Executive Head, Service Management or the NHQ program Director General) should be apprised of the circumstances, especially if the situation can be considered as 'sensitive' or 'difficult'.

A novation must not be used to address difficulties relative to an agreement; instead, other options, such as amendment or termination, should be explored (see Chapter 11 'Mitigation' for further information).

Steps involved in setting up a Novation Agreement:

  1. Provide the organization with an official confirmation; both the organization's requestand HRSDC's official response should be filed in the original and the new project files.
  2. Amend the previous agreement to change the end date and reduce the fundingneeded until the termination and subsequent close-out of the agreement.
  3. Create a new file in the CSGC – indicate the original project number, the reason forthe novation and its start date in a note to file and complete "Relate Project" screenin CSGC.
  4. Determine how much of the funding balance from the original agreement will beincluded in the novated agreement in order to balance the project account in theCSGC and CMS (Corporate Management System) -- then negotiate a reasonablestart date to begin the novated agreement.
  5. Prepare the appropriate form and proceed through the regular agreement process –complete enough copies of the appropriate novation agreement for each party.

Branches may have specific novation agreement forms or instructions. Those who don't may use forms EMP5364B (Novation Agreement Substituting a Party) or EMP4081B (Novation - Employment Benefits and Support Measure).

Note: If an organization undergoes a legal name change but its legal status, mission and vision remain unchanged, a novation is not required (see section 16.10.1 of the CSGC User Guide for information on how to update the organization's legal name.)

Successors and Assigns

This section highlights that whether an organization should, with HRSDC's agreement, novate the agreement to a successor or assign some or all rights and obligations in relation to the agreement to an "Assign" or "assignee", the terms of the agreement would be binding on either party.

Compliance with Laws and Applicable Law

These two sections highlight the fact that the laws and regulations found at various levels of government and governing bodies must be respected, and would supersede the agreement in cases of conflicting requirements.

Amendment

This section establishes the right of the parties to amend the agreement as well as outlining the basic principle to governing amendments -- namely, the requirement for the written, mutual consent of both parties.

Signing of amendments shall be performed in accordance with guidelines for signing of the agreement.

For more information on amendments, see section 11.2, General Mitigation Strategies, within chapter 11.

Unincorporated Association

An unincorporated association is a group of persons who enter into a mutual agreement (written or verbal) to pursue a common purpose. An unincorporated association does not have separate legal status.

This section clarifies that the persons who sign an agreement with HRSDC on behalf of an unincorporated association will be held personally responsible for any organization obligations under the agreement.

Counterparts

This section establishes that the parties may accept faxed or scanned signed copies of the agreement as the original. Program delivery staff are not required to obtain from, nor provide to, the organization an original of the faxed or scanned signed copy.

The section states that the faxed or scanned (signed) copy and the original (unsigned) copy "taken together shall constitute one and the same agreement." To ensure that the faxed or scanned copy is identical to the original copy, program delivery staff should verify that all pages, clauses and words are accounted for and are legible.

English Language

This section is to be included in agreements concluded in English with an organization based in the province of Quebec.

The CSGC will automatically include or exclude this clause from each agreement as required.

Schedule A – Project Description

The project description is the main component of Schedule A which includes the following elements:

  • Contact Information
  • Project Duration
  • Total Number of Participants (if applicable)
  • Project Objectives
  • Project Activities
  • Expected Results

The CSGC generates this schedule using information entered or updated during previous phases of the project life cycle (see section 6.1 of the CSGC User Guide for further details). The schedule must be detailed enough to both indicate the organization's accountability for project results, and allow the Department to monitor project activities vis-à-vis clearly-defined expectations.

Clearly written project descriptions help ensure that:

  • expected project outcomes are well defined;
  • progress can be easily monitored; and,
  • results can be measured and the project readily evaluated.

Important: The content of Schedule A must in no way repeat, reformulate, or contradict the Articles of Agreement.

Contact Information

Up to two contact persons for each party may be identified in the agreement. This information forms an integral part of the agreement and as such may only be changed through a formal amendment to the agreement. For approval purposes, program delivery staff are to treat this as a minor amendment and have it approved by the departmental official with delegated authority to sign the agreement / minor amendment.

The organization's primary contact information is transferred into Schedule A from the CSGC 'Primary Application Contact' field, and the secondary contact information (if applicable) is transferred into Schedule A from the CSGC 'Secondary Application Contact' field.

The HRSDC primary contact information is transferred into Schedule A from the CSGC 'Community Relations Officer' field, and the secondary contact information is transferred into Schedule A from the CSGC 'Administration Officer' field.

Project Duration

The project duration is the timeframe between the start and end dates of a project. This information is transferred into Schedule A from the CSGC Project Duration screen (Agreement Set-Up phase).

Project duration dates have a profound impact on CSGC financial elements, impacting the forecast of project expenditures, budgets, fiscal year splits, commitments, financial coding and system edits; hence, both start and end dates must be verified to ensure that all further calculations are also accurate.

Total Number of Participants (if applicable)

The information in this box of Schedule A is transferred from the CSGC Total Participants screen (Project Set-up phase).

Project Objectives

Organizations are bound to the approved project objectives for the entire duration of the funding agreement. This is rooted in the terms of Appendix B, Section 2.2 of the HRSDC Grants and Contributions Policy. Program delivery staff must neither change nor alter the officially approved project objectives for any reason.

Care must be taken, at the Recommendation and Approval phase, to ensure that project objectives are S.M.A.R.T. (specific; measurable; attainable; relevant; and, time based) and that they are:

  • realistic, given individual and organizational constraints, timeframes and availableresources;
  • consistent with program terms and conditions and departmental priorities; and,
  • appropriate responses to identified community needs. (See RecommendationReport Guidelines for further guidance)

The project objectives are transferred into Schedule A from the CSGC Project Description screen (Agreement Set-Up phase). Program delivery staff must review this screen prior to closing the phase to ensure that the approved project objectives are accurately reflected.

Project Activities

Project activities describe what steps the organization will take to reach the project objectives and to demonstrate how expected results will be achieved. Activities must, therefore, be specific, measurable, realistic and relevant to project objectives.

The list of project activities must include reasonable timeframes, milestones and means of evaluation to help determine the overall success of the project, taking into consideration the cost and duration of the project, and the capacities and constraints of the organization. Milestones are significant points during the life of the agreement. Ultimately, they make it easier for program delivery staff to monitor the progress of related activities. (See Recommendation Report Guidelines for further guidance)

The project activities are transferred into Schedule A from the CSGC Project Description screen (Agreement Set-Up phase).

Although project activities may be amended by the parties, the original agreement should generally reflect the approved project activities. Any changes to the approved project activities must be fully disclosed to the departmental official with delegated authority to sign the agreement / minor amendment, preferably in writing.

Expected Results

The federal government insists that funded project activities produce an anticipated set of results and that projects be evaluated—whether formally or informally—to measure organization levels of success or failure in achieving those results.

Expected results further define and often quantify project objectives. Where expected results are difficult to quantify, this section should generally specify how the organization will demonstrate that the results have been achieved.

The expected results are transferred into Schedule A from the CSGC Project Description screen (Agreement Set-Up phase).

Although expected results may theoretically be amended by the parties, the original agreement should habitually reflect the approved expected results. Any changes to the approved expected results must be fully disclosed to the departmental official with delegated authority to sign the agreement / minor amendment, preferably in writing. Where it appears that the actual results will not meet the expected, it is best to document the situation and provide justification in a monitoring report or note to file and in the Close-out Summary Report in the CSGC.

HRSDC programs that fund relatively complex initiatives—such as research or demonstration projects— may require that organizations submit their project to a formal evaluation. Funding applicants must, therefore, provide an evaluation plan as part of their funding application. Their application may also include an evaluation budget to, for example, hire an independent evaluator.

Schedule A must contain evaluation plan details in these cases. Such details could include descriptions of:

  • the evaluation methodology;
  • data to be gathered;
  • instruments to be used;
  • control or comparison groups;
  • performance indicators;
  • implementation timeframes;
  • milestones; and,
  • requirements for reporting and distributing findings.

Some programs, however, require less complex project evaluations that may rely on the following ways to measure expected results:

  • numbers or percentages, such as the number of participants expected to achievethe outcome compared to the number enrolled;
  • an assessment of the completion, distribution and use of related products;
  • a projection of the possible future results of intervention;
  • participant follow-up surveys assessing participant satisfaction, length of jobplacements, retention rates, etc.; and,
  • program delivery staff observations and overall project assessment.
Schedule B – Financial Provisions

Schedule B contains standard financial provisions that the parties are bound to such as:

  • Maximum Funding of Canada
  • Interest Earned on Contribution
  • Repayment Requirements
  • Other Sources of Funding
  • Project Budget
  • Budget Flexibility
  • Conditions Governing the Eligibility of Expenditures
  • Terms of Payment
  • Annual Financial Reports

Schedule B also identifies all cash and non-cash (in-kind) contributions made in support of the project by the organization and other organizations or partners, where applicable.

Program delivery staff use this schedule to monitor agreement expenses and recommend upward or downward amendments to the agreement if expenses change.

Maximum Contribution of Canada

This section is to be included in both grant and contribution agreements.

For grants, it sets out, pursuant to the section entitled Canada's Funding in the Articles of Agreement, the maximum amount of funding HRSDC will contribute towards the project for its entire duration. This amount is transferred into Schedule B from the CSGC Budget screen (Create Grant Letter phase)

For contributions, this section sets out, pursuant to the section entitled Canada's Funding in the Articles of Agreement, the maximum amount of funding HRSDC will contribute towards the project, per fiscal year, for its entire duration.

These amounts are transferred into Schedule B from the CSGC Budget and Manage Fiscal Year Splits, screens (Agreement Set-Up phase). This screen will only be available before the signature of the agreement, an amendment will be required for any changes afterwards.

The clause allows fiscal year budgets to be modified with the proper "authorization in writing by Canada".

  • A request for such authorization should be considered as soon as it is identified thatthe amount payable by fiscal year as indicated in Article 1.2 of Schedule B will notbe fully expended.

Such authorization should never be granted for a previous fiscal year. Changes to thresholds per fiscal year for current or future fiscal years must be made by way of a formal amendment to the agreement. For the purpose of this Directive, the current fiscal year end is March 31. After giving consideration to the above-listed points, program delivery staff must take the following steps in order to provide a written authorization to exceed the maximum amount of the current fiscal year:

  1. Clearly establish, in collaboration with the organization, the financial needs to change the current and or future fiscal year allocation (purpose and amount);
  2. Verify whether there are sufficient unencumbered funds in the program budget to increase the current fiscal year budget by the established amount;
  3. Obtain sign-off from the departmental official with delegated authority to sign the agreement / minor amendment on the proposed written communication to convey Canada's authorization to the organization;
  4. Send the approved written authorization (an email is acceptable) to the organization and, if required (see note below), adjust the fiscal year split in the CSGC.

Note: Program funds which are not spent or de-committed by the end of a fiscal year are lapsed and cannot be invested in other projects or program initiatives.

Interest Earned on Contribution

This section sets out to ensure that any significant amount of interest (more than $100) earned on HRSDC's contribution is reinvested in the project.

Program delivery staff should encourage organizations to place advanced funds in an interest bearing account if some circumstance delays the incurrence of eligible expenditures.

All organizations who receive advance payments must disclose, on their final claim form for payment, the full amount of any interest earned on Canada's contribution. If this amount exceeds $100, the organization owes the full amount to HRSDC. The organization may reimburse the Department with a cheque made out to the Receiver General for Canada, or program delivery staff may deduct the amount from the final payment due the organization, if applicable. If the full amount of interest earned is less than or equal to $100, the organization may keep the money.

Repayment Requirements

This section outlines a number of situations under which an organization may incur, and be required to reimburse, a debt owing to the Government of Canada under its funding agreement with HRSDC. For convenience and proactive disclosure, it explicitly references the relevant terms of Canada's Interest and Administrative Charges Regulations or, if the project is funded under EI Part II, the Employment Insurance Regulations.

Other Sources of Funding

This section secures for program delivery staff the authority to ensure that any program stacking limitations and mandatory leveraging requirements are respected.

While potential organizations will usually be informed of any program stacking limitations and mandatory leveraging requirements at the application stage, program delivery staff may wish to inform the funding organization during the signing of the agreement, or during the initial contact, that the other sources of funding clauses will be used to enforce these requirements.

Refer to program Terms and Conditions or policy documents to ascertain the stacking limit for a particular program. Appendix C of the Treasury Board Directive on Transfer Payments provides additional definitions and related factors to be taken into account when calculating total Canadian government funding for any one project. HRSDC's Grants and Contributions Policy also provides details on the stacking of assistance.

For agreements over $100,000, the organization must provide a statement at the end of the project outlining the total funding received from all sources. This will provide added assurance for the Department that the organization has complied with the terms of this section and informed the Department of any changes to its declaration regarding other sources of funding.

Note regarding in-kind contributions: In-kind contributions are goods or services provided by the other organizations/partners. They could include land, buildings, equipment, use of facilities, labour, goods and securities required to carry out projects and activities. Programs often accept non-cash assets as part of an organization's matching contribution (see Guide on In-Kind Contribution for further details).

Project Budget

SAs contain two new features that have been introduced in the project budget:

  1. Other sources of funding are no longer divided per cost category. The detailedbreakdown will still be requested of funding applicants in order to enable programdelivery staff to conduct a thorough assessment of the project, but only the totalamount of cash and in-kind contributions from other sources of funding will bedisplayed in the project budget in the agreement.
  2. Budget notes are now included in the agreement following the project budget. For thepurposes of the agreement, budget notes are generic definitions of the cost categoriesused within the project budget; contrary to budget negotiation notes, they are notmeant to detail specific expenditure items.
Budget Flexibility

This section establishes that organizations may transfer funds between cost categories at their discretion. Depending upon the situation as specified in the clause, various levels of departmental permission may be required:

  1. With one exception (see below), transfers that increase or decrease the amountbudgeted in any cost category by no more than 10% of the original approvedlevel or formally amended level, if applicable, do not require departmental approval but must be disclosed by the organization to the Department. This could be done on an ad hoc basis or at the time of submitting the next claim form;
  2. All transfers requiring departmental approval (that don't involve a change to theproject activities or some other substantial aspect of the project) may be authorizedby the department through a minor amendment; and
  3. Any costs which were initially disallowed by the delegated authority duringapproval phase must go through a major amendment.

Despite point 1 above, all proposed transfers involving a cost category labelled with an asterisk (*), as indicated in the budget detail template, require a minor amendment.

Flat Rates

A number of HRSDC programs have up to two cost categories that may benefit from flat rates and, as such, not be subject to financial monitoring. When this is the case, program delivery staff will have the option, through the CSGC Print Agreement screen (Agreement Set-up and Agreement phases), to include additional clauses in the agreement as sections 6.4 and 6.5 of Schedule B. These clauses describe the formula for establishing flat rates, which are contingent upon amounts budgeted for other cost categories.

Conditions Governing the Eligibility of Expenditures

This section identifies the conditions under which program delivery staff should disallow expenditures, and defines the appropriate use of departmental funding. This section normally contains eight items {i.e. (a) to (h)}. However, depending on the program, the CSGC may automatically add a small number of extra items to this list (e.g. this would apply to HPS regionally delivered streams).

Two external documents are referenced under this section:

  1. The Travel Directive of the National Joint Council of Canada; and,
  2. The Treasury Board of Canada Directive on the Management of Expenditures onTravel, Hospitality and Conferences.

Program delivery staff should not hesitate to provide organizations with the URL's to the above documents for ease of reference.

For information on goods and services tax/harmonized sales taxes rebates, program delivery staff should refer organizations to the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) guide entitled RC4033 General Application for GST/HST Rebates. It is the responsibility of organizations to contact CRA in order to obtain a ruling on the GST/HST rebates to which their organization is entitled.

Within a contribution agreement, HRSDC will only reimburse the GST/HST portion of eligible expenses that is not subject to rebate or input tax credit to the organization by the CRA. Hence, if an organization is entitled to a GST rebate from the CRA, then HRSDC would not be paying for the portion for which they are entitled to a rebate.

There exists a difference between grants and contributions with respect to rebates. When HRSDC issues a grant, program delivery staff determine beforehand whether the organization is eligible for a GST/HST rebate, and then determine the approximate amount that they could claim from the CRA. For example, if an applicant, who is eligible for a 50% GST rebate, requests a grant to cover $50,000 (taxes included) worth of renovations, they would pay approximately $2,200 in GST and would be eligible to claim $1,100 from the CRA. In this case, program delivery staff would recommend the Department grant the applicant $48,900 of the $50K requested.

In the context of a contribution agreement, program delivery staff may verify the books and records of an organization. This provides an opportunity to identify and recover any amounts claimed by an organization to which they were not entitled, including any tax credit or reimbursement that the organization was entitled to receive from another source such as the CRA.

Terms of Payment

This section is to be included in both grant and contribution agreements.

For grants, it identifies the instalment schedule as per the data in the CSGC Manage Grant Instalments screen (Grant Letter phase).

For contributions, it identifies the payment method and frequency; two options for payment method (progress and advance) and two options for payment frequency (monthly and quarterly) are available:

Method
  • progress payments
  • progress payments
  • advance payments
  • advance payments
Frequency
  1. monthly
  2. quarterly
  3. monthly
  4. quarterly

The payment method and frequency will be determined automatically based on the nature of the program and risk of the project. However, section 8.2 of the SA for contributions offers the flexibility for program delivery staff to change the payment method or frequency at any time during the life of the agreement. This authority should be viewed as a risk management and mitigation measure and should only be applied where warranted such as, for example, upon re-assessment of the risk (through the Assess Project Risk screen in the Monitoring phase), if the risk score is significantly reduced or increased.

Program delivery staff are required to follow the CSGC PLC Module - Fiscal Year End Instructions when issuing quarterly advance payments at the end of a fiscal year.

Following the end of each payment period, the organization must provide a claim form to the Department. If advances are the payment method, the claim form will be comprised of three parts: Part 1 - Claim Information; Part 2 - Forecast of Project Expenditures; and Part 3 - Activity Report. If progress payments are the payment method, the claim form will be comprised of parts 1 (Claim Information) and 3 (Activity Report) only.

Deadlines for submitting claim forms are generally within 15 days following monthly payment periods and 30 days following quarterly payment periods. However, certain programs (e.g. Youth Career Focus and Youth Skills Link) set the deadlines at thirty days for both monthly and quarterly payment periods while other programs (e.g. Homelessness Partnering Strategy regionally delivered streams that use the community entity model) set the deadlines at thirty days for monthly payment periods and forty-five days for quarterly periods. The applicable deadlines will be automatically inserted into subsection 8.4(2) of Schedule B based on pre-determined program-specific criteria (i.e. program delivery staff will not be required to, nor do they have the option to, specify these deadlines).

Finally, these Terms of Payment give HRSDC the authority to withhold payments under certain conditions specified in section 8.5 of Schedule B to the agreement, and to retain a holdback of up to 10% of HRSDC's maximum contribution (see chapter 9 for information about Managing the Holdback Amount).

Annual Financial Reports

This section is only included in agreements where warranted by the nature of the program (e.g. Aboriginal Skills and Employment Training Strategy). For some programs, it may be available for inclusion in Schedule B through the CSGC Print Agreement screen (Agreement Set-up and Agreement phases); for others it may be included automatically.

The clause requires the organization to provide HRSDC with an annual financial report. The report must usually be reviewed by an independent accredited auditor, but HRSDC may waive the audit requirement where appropriate relative to each annual report.

Such a waiver should not be granted as a general waiver applicable to all annual financial reports, but rather should be considered separately, relative to each annual report. The departmental official with delegated authority to sign the agreement / minor amendment must agree to the waiver and, although not specified in the agreement, any such waiver should be communicated to the organization in writing within fifteen (15) days of the end of the year of the report in order to avoid the organization unnecessarily hiring an external auditor.

Carry Forward

This section is only included in contribution agreements with aboriginal organizations. It applies to agreements that span two or more fiscal years and allows the organization to carry forward unused advances from one fiscal year to the next without reducing the total HRSDC contribution amount.

Schedule C – Additional Provisions

Schedule C generally includes clauses addressing, as applicable depending on the program or project, the following topics:

  • Official Languages
  • Environmental Protection
  • Specific Reporting Requirements
  • Activities Involving Redistribution of Funding Towards Sub-Projects
  • Activities Involving the Establishment of Facility Property
  • Activities Involving Participants
  • Collection and Protection of Information
  • Debt Assignment
  • Ad-hoc clauses

The schedule may also contain ad hoc clauses, drafted for a specific situation and validated by Legal Services.

Official Languages

The Official Languages clause reflects HRSDC's obligations to parts IV and VII of Canada's Official Languages Act (OLA). Through it, HRSDC effectually transfers its obligations under these parts of the OLA to the organization whose project is funded.

The clause is generic and therefore may not specifically cover all aspects related to each particular project. Given the variety of possible scenarios, the Official Languages clause may be applied differently from one project to the next. As such, program delivery staff should ensure that Schedule A to the agreement includes a description of organization obligations particular to the project being funded; for example, the project description could mention that a specific service or product will be provided or available in both official languages.

The Official Languages clause must be included in a grant or contribution agreement when the assessment has determined that the project should cater to members of both official language communities or provide services in both official languages (see section 5.2 for more information).

This clause does not purport to direct the organization to use a particular language of work within its organization or in its interactions with HRSDC, but rather to communicate with the targeted beneficiaries of the project, the general public and nearby official language minority communities, if applicable, in the language of their choosing.

Unless a predetermination has been made relative to the applicability of the Official Languages clauses to all activities under a program, program delivery staff will be required to manually, in accordance with the guidelines set out above, include or exclude these clauses from Schedule C through the CSGCPrint Agreement screen (Agreement Set-up and Agreement phases).

Environmental Protection

This section establishes HRSDC's authority to require the organization to comply with any mitigation recommended by an environmental assessment, as specified by section 5.3.4 (Ensure that Mitigation is Implemented) of the HRSDC Environmental Assessment Guide and Reference.

The clause should generally be included in Schedule C to the agreement only if the screening process has identified a requirement to conduct an environmental assessment.

Unless a predetermination has been made relative to the applicability of the Environmental Protection clauses to all activities under a program, program delivery staff will be required to manually, in accordance with the guidelines set out above, include or exclude these clauses from Schedule C through the CSGC Print Agreement screen (Agreement Set-up and Agreement phases).

Specific Reporting Requirements

A number of programs have specific reporting requirements. For example, providing program delivery staff with annual work plans and investment plans or reports on sub- projects to which funding is redistributed.

The CSGC will automatically include relevant clauses in Schedule C, when applicable, based on the nature of the funding program or stream.

Activities Involving Redistribution of Funding in Support of Sub-Projects
