Appendix G (Funding Agreement Provisions for Contributions) of the Treasury Board Directive on Transfer Payments requires departmental managers to ensure that contribution agreements address a number of issues where organizations further distribute departmental funds to third parties (i.e. an organization other than the organization).

This practice is to be considered as being distinct from 'sub-contracting' (see the Contracting Procedures provision in the Articles of Agreement); the sub-contracting provision pertains to an organization contracting out all or a portion of its management and reporting responsibilities under the agreement to a third party. Redistribution of funding pertains to the organization funding third parties undertaking projects that will yield results aligned with HRSDC funding program objectives.

Currently, only a few funding programs at HRSDC (e.g. Homelessness Partnering Strategy regionally delivered streams; Opportunities Fund community coordinator; Aboriginal Skills and Employment Training Strategy) allow for redistribution of funding by the organization to third parties.

A generic set of clauses on this topic has been developed for automatic inclusion, by the CSGC, in Schedule C where relevant.

These clauses relate to the third party project (or 'sub-project') selection process, the content of agreements with third parties, the conditions under which the organization may itself undertake a sub-project, and sub-project monitoring and audit.

Activities Involving the Establishment of Facility Property

A number of HRSDC programs support projects intended to establish or enhance a facility that will offer services to persons with a particular set of needs (such as persons with disabilities or the homeless).

A generic set of clauses have been developed for automatic inclusion, by the CSGC, in Schedule C where relevant.

These clauses relate to what the funding will be used for which, depending on the program, could include the purchase of land or a building or the construction, expansion, renovation or remodeling of a building. The clauses also specify what services the facility is to render and identify repayment provisions whereby the organization may be required to reimburse all or a portion of the funding provided to it by HRSDC if it fails to complete the work on the facility or if the facility does not render the services originally identified.

These repayment provisions generally apply for up to five years beyond the completion of the project, and hence, the clauses also include monitoring provisions or a requirement for the organization to report annually on the status of the facility.

Activities Involving Participants

A number of HRSDC's programs (e.g. Opportunities Fund, Youth Employment Strategy) fund projects that help individuals gain work experience, training or some other help related to increasing their involvement in learning, work and community.

A generic set of clauses on this topic has been developed for automatic inclusion, by the CSGC, in Schedule C where relevant.

These clauses relate to participant eligibility criteria, collection and protection of participant information, and the content of agreements between the organization and participants, or between the organization and other organizations, who agree to provide paid or voluntary work experience to a participant.

Collection and Protection of Information

A number of HRSDC's programs have a requirement in their Terms and Conditions for a personal information protection clause to be included in funding agreements.

A generic set of clauses on this topic has been developed for automatic inclusion, by the CSGC, in Schedule C where relevant.

The purpose of these clauses is to reinforce the requirement that all personal information collected by the organization in carrying out the project must be handled with care.

Debt Assignment

This provision is included in Schedule C for projects involving a Community Coordinator only. The clause establishes a means for a funding organization to reduce a debt, owed to HRSDC, under a funding agreement by transferring to HRSDC the title to a debt owed to the organization by a project participant, or an employer, who was compensated by the organization under the agreement in order to provide work experience to a project participant.

Ad-hoc Clauses

On rare occasions, a project involves such particular circumstances that the standard clauses described above are not sufficient to govern these circumstances. When this is the case, program delivery staff may, in accordance with the Change Management Protocol for Standardized Agreements, include an ad-hoc clause (or set of clauses) at the end of Schedule C by adding it into the "Additional Conditions" box on the CSGC Prepare Schedules screen (Agreement phase).

8.3 Committing Funds

Prior to preparing a funding agreement and having it signed by the Department and the applicant, program delivery staff must commit the funding amount in the Corporate Management System (CMS) via the CSGC.

While a budget is always prepared for the entire duration of the project, if the duration spans two or more fiscal years, program funds are to be committed and accounted for on a fiscal year basis. The amount to commit per fiscal year may be identified through negotiations between the applicant and the Department, however, generally, program managers determine fiscal year splits based on the applicant's forecast of project expenditures.

The CSGC Manage Fiscal Year Splits screen is used to establish or modify the negotiated fiscal year split. The CSGC Commit Funds screen is then used to submit this information to the CMS and establish a hard commitment. Only then will program delivery staff be able to issue payments to the applicant. For more information on managing fiscal year splits, see Assessing the Impact of Fiscal Year End on Advance Payments in Chapter 9.

8.4 Signing the Agreement

Signatories to an agreement are presumed to have read and understood all of the agreement's terms and conditions, but the complete agreement should be reviewed with each organization, prior to signing, in order to confirm that this is indeed the case.

Parties are required to sign in full the final page of each part of the agreement (i.e. the Articles of the Agreement and each Schedule). Although this should only occur on very rare occasions and with proper justification, should it be necessary to strike out a clause from the agreement, the signatories to the agreement would be required to initial the change. Agreements must be signed prior to the agreement start date in order to remain compliant with the CFO Grants and Contribution Policy. Please refer to the policy for exceptional circumstances.

In accordance with HRSDC's Grants and Contributions Policy, the organization's duly authorized representative(s) must sign the funding agreement first; the departmental official with delegated authority signs last.

Note: most organizations will allow a single representative to sign agreements on their behalf but some may require a combination of two or more to do so. In order to confirm the signing requirements, program delivery staff may request a copy of the organization's relevant by-law or statutes and place it on the project file following examination. Depending on the organization's track record with the department, this may be done prior to or following signing of the agreement by HRSDC.

As described above in relation to the Counterparts clause, the agreement may be transmitted for signature by fax or email if needs be. If time is not an issue, the traditional method of signing agreements should be used. That is, two copies of the agreement are printed, the organization's duly authorized representative(s) signs them both and returns them to the program, the Department's delegated representative signs them both, then program delivery staff place one signed copy in the paper file and return the second signed copy to the organization for their own records.

Note: Where a program uses an 'application-agreement', upon submitting its application, the applicant declares it he or she has read and understood the applicant guide and the articles of agreement attached to the application form. This attestation serves as a signature to the agreement and will be validated at a later date should funding be approved.

8.5 Delegated Authority

There are three types of delegated authority:

  • Approval of Proposal / Application / Major Amendment
  • Approval to Sign Agreement / Minor Amendment
  • Certification (expenditure approval) authority (under Section 34 of the FAA)

As the approval authority varies from program to program, as well as by the dollar value of the proposed project, program delivery staff must check the Financial Delegation Instrument (FDI) to confirm the approval process, identify the level of departmental signing authority required for individual programs, and adhere to the interpretations provided by regional consultants for every program.

All delegation of authority charts are submitted to Internal Control and Financial Policy of the Chief Financial Officer Branch (CFOB) at national headquarters for approval. The FDI for each program has been incorporated into the CSGC, which will display the appropriate level of signing authority whenever it is required (for recommendation, approval, signature of agreement, amendment, claim forms).

Approval Authority

Approval authority differs from program to program. Although it is ultimately the Minister's responsibility, approval authority is often delegated to officials at the national, regional and local levels.

To ensure funding decisions are objective and follow proper controls, the person who approves a project is never the same person who prepared the recommendation. The approval and signing authorities, however, may be the same person.

If consulting the Financial Delegation Instrument, note that column 'A' represents the authority to approve a recommendation for funding and a major amendment.

Signing Authority

Departmental officials with delegated signing authority can sign new agreements and minor amendments that have already been approved.

Officials with delegated signing authority must first sign a Specimen Signature Card before they can officially sign an agreement, as per the delegation of authority.

If consulting the Financial Delegation Instrument, note that column 'B' represents the authority to sign an agreement or a minor amendment.

Expenditure Approval Authority

Following initial verification by program delivery staff, the expenditure approval authority verifies the accuracy of a claim form and supporting materials before signing it. Their signature certifies that the expenditures comply with the terms and conditions of the agreement, as well as with section 34 of the Financial Administration Act.

Example: the Sunnyside Children's Group has submitted a monthly claim form for their Skills Link project that shows they made a capital purchase of $1,275 for a laptop computer; they have attached an invoice for the computer to the claim form. Program delivery staff compare the invoice to the original Skills Link agreement Schedule B and the budget negotiation notes to verify prior departmental approval of this purchase. The purchase is confirmed as being eligible; the claim form is forwarded to the expenditure approval authority for signature, and then sent on for processing and payment.

If consulting the Financial Delegation Instrument, note that column 'C' represents the authority to issue funds (section 34).

8.6 The Agreement (or Initial) Visit

The initial visit with the organization is an opportunity to review agreement provisions, as well as the obligations and responsibilities of both parties.All attempts should be made to conduct this visit prior to the signing of the agreement by the parties, especially with organizations that are unfamiliar to HRSDC.

During this visit, program delivery staff should confirm that the organization clearly understands each provision in the articles of agreement and the content of all attached schedules.

As the departmental representative, one must advise the organization during this meeting that:

  • agreements have specific start and end dates; they cannot hold activities or incurexpenses outside of those dates;
  • funding cannot exceed the amount specified in the agreement unless both partiessign an amendment before the end of that agreement;
  • funding will not continue beyond the agreement end date; and,
  • agreements are not automatically renewed; organizations must undertake a newapplication process in order to apply for any further funding.

Program delivery staff should also review the following issues with the organization, as they may require further action:

  • Union Concurrence: If applicable, the organization must obtain the concurrence ofits union or employee associations.
  • Permits: The organization must obtain all necessary licenses and permits, andmeet all legal requirements.
  • Insurance: The organization must have appropriate insurance, such as third partyliability, business/commercial liability, theft, and fire.
  • Acts and Regulations: The organization must be aware of, and in compliancewith, all applicable acts and regulations, including:
    • provincial and federal income tax;
    • Canada/Quebec pension plan;
    • vacation pay and minimum wage; and,
    • Employment Insurance premiums, health insurance and workers'compensation.
  • Issuing T4s: At the end of the calendar year, an organization must issueT4A/Relevé 1's to all employees, showing deductions for EI, CPP/QPP andincome tax.
  • Garnishee: If an organization is served a legal notice of garnishee of wages for aparticipant or administrative staff employee, provincial/territorial legislation must berespected.
  • Monitoring: Establish a tentative schedule for visits and off-site monitoring with theorganization; explain the nature of monitoring and determine what supportingdocumentation will be required.
  • Participants: If applicable, ensure participant documentation and recruitment isunderstood.
  • Dates and Documentation: Confirm the project start date; review documentation the organization must submit to the Department.
  • The Department's policy on Charging Interest on Receivables applies to contributions paid for by the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

This meeting is also used to develop a relationship with the organization by providing them with further helpful information on claim form completion, reporting and other administrative requirements that they will need to meet during the course of the agreement. This would be an appropriate time to share the anticipated frequency of each monitoring type. Such an exchange will also encourage an organization to seek further clarification when required.

Finally, this visit can be used to meet with the organization's bookkeeper or financial officer and confirm that the necessary financial record keeping system is in place. If one is unfamiliar with their accounting system, ask the financial contact to explain its organization.

If appropriate, the agreement visit may be replaced by a telephone conversation. However, if working with a first-time organization, program delivery staff are encouraged to meet the organization in person as more time to review the agreement may be required.

After the visit, program delivery staff must document details of the meeting—topics covered, questions asked, issues requiring follow up, etc.—in the CSGC.

8.7 Incorporating Risk Management

HRSDC follows a flexible, organization-focused approach to risk management. Section 6.5.7 of the Treasury Board Policy on Transfer Payments states that administrative requirements of organizations must be proportionate to the:

  • risk specific to the program;
  • value of funding in relation to administrative costs; and,
  • risk profile of the organization.

The associated Directive promotes the application of a measured response to risk throughout the project management cycle.

Program delivery staff should, therefore, keep previously-determined risk factors in mind while drafting the agreement, referring to CSGC project file notes and checklists for details; one may need to incorporate specific provisions into the agreement in order to either reduce or control risk.

The Risk Assessment, Management and Mitigation (RAMM) strategy provides more specific guidance relative to managing risk; see Chapter 6 for further details.

8.8 Avoiding Employer-Employee Relationships

Program delivery staff must ensure that an employer-employee relationship does not develop between the Department and the organizations (or their employees). The following situations should be avoided by the Department:

  • direct how an organization should achieve agreement objectives;
  • specify how an activity should be carried out;
  • provide tools, equipment or premises for activities (although the Department may contribute to these costs through the agreement);
  • present the project as being organized by the Department – project activities cannot, therefore, be located on federal premises; communication materials cannot present the project as being a part of departmental operations; and, agreements cannot refer to an organization performing any activity 'on behalf of the Department';
  • invite project staff to internal departmental meetings or use them to replace departmental staff; or,
  • entertain offers of services from organizations.

The Canada Revenue Agency publication RC4110(E) 1219 Employee or Self-Employed can also be consulted in order to help identify an employer-employee relationship.

8.9 Employment Equity Issues

Some programs address the needs of particular client segments such as Aboriginal peoples, persons with disabilities, new Canadians and youth with barriers to employment (also known as "youth at risk").

Agreements that deliver interventions targeting these and other groups must establish measurable objectives with respect to hiring or providing services for these groups.

If costs are associated with serving a target group (e.g. adaptive technologies, printed materials in multiple languages), the organization must calculate eligible expenditures according to program guidelines; these must be clearly reflected in the agreement.

8.10 Revenue Generation

Non-profit organizations are encouraged, whenever feasible, to generate revenues and reduce their dependence on government funding.

By definition, "revenue" generated within the non-profit sector must be reinvested, unlike within the private sector where it can be shared with investors as profit.

When preparing the agreement, program delivery staff must, therefore, determine whether the project will generate revenue and if that revenue will be used to offset departmental funding (while assuring compliance with the program's Terms and Conditions). One must outline any such arrangement in the agreement schedules.

If the revenue will be used to continue activities, however, program delivery staff must also document this fact in the agreement as an organization's ability to generate and retain revenue is highly desirable when a project is to continue beyond the termination of departmental funding.

Should revenue be generated in an unanticipated manner – such as interest earned on an advance not immediately used – such revenue is deemed as being a part of the contribution and must, therefore, be taken into account when processing subsequent claim forms. For further details, consult section 5.14 of the Department's Grants and Contributions Policy.

Chapter 10. Activity Reporting and Payment

Once the funding agreement has been signed and activities are underway, the recipient will require payment for eligible expenditures associated with the project.

Two authorities provide departmental, administrative and legislative guidance on issuing payments to the recipient:

  • The Treasury Board Policy on Transfer Payments and its associated Directive provide administrative guidance to ensure sound management of, control over and accountability for all payments.
  • The Financial Administration Act (FAA) is the legislative authority under which payments are made.

The agreement and its attached schedules draw upon the guidance provided by these documents to outline the:

  • type of payments;
  • frequency of payments; and
  • documentation required to support claims.

10.1 Type of Payments

The Treasury Board Policy on Transfer Payments and related Directive identifies the two types of payments used to deliver contribution programs:

  1. progress payments (or, reimbursement of actual expenses); and,
  2. advance payments.

Partial payments for grants are known as installments which may, for example, be used to pay for training and apprenticeship programs where the continuing eligibility of the recipient is a requirement.

For a grant up to $250,000, programs have full discretion on whether to pay the grant in a lump sum or to pay it in installments. A grant over $250,000 is to be paid in installments unless the full amount is required in a single payment to meet the objectives of the grant. A rationale (via a note to file) for a single installment over $250,000 is required. When a grant is to be paid in installments, programs have the discretion to determine the amounts and timing of the installment payments.

Progress Payments

Progress payments—or reimbursement of actual expenses—are made after the recipient has incurred the expenses. Such payments cover the period in which the activity and expenditures have occurred, prior to completion of the entire agreement. Progress payments are available to all recipients regardless of their risk level.

Advance Payments

Advance payments provide recipients with funds before expenditures occur. Essentially, these are government-funded payments for which a recipient has not yet submitted a claim. When a recipient receives an advance payment, money is, in effect, being borrowed from the Government of Canada. It becomes money owed to the Crown and, therefore, funds are at risk.

10.2 Frequency of Payments

Payments are issued on a monthly or quarterly basis and are based upon the risk level of an organization. It is also possible to have payments based on the achievement of pre-determined milestones as described and outlined in the agreement.

As per the table below, the frequency of advance payment is based upon the risk level of an organization. The risk level of five pre-determined RAMM factors (activity performance, ability to demonstrate results, financial performance, organizational administration, and stability of the board and/or organization) is automatically calculated and the overall organization score informs the advance payment frequency to be followed. The frequency of payment and reporting is automatically generated and displayed by the CSGC.

Factors

Organizational risk

Activity Performance

Ability to demonstrate results

Financial Performance

Organizational Administration

Stability of the board and/or organization

Risk Level

Advance Payment & Reporting Frequency

High (31-50)

 Monthly

Medium (16-30)

 Quarterly

Low (0-15)

 Quarterly

Based on the overall organizational risk level, recipients with a low- to medium-score will receive advance payments on a fixed quarterly basis. Recipients with a high-risk score will receive advances on a monthly basis.

10.2.1 Fixed Quarters for Advance Paying Project:

All programs (with the exception of the Canada Summer Jobs program) are required to follow a fixed quarter schedule in all new advance payment projects. (This requirement applies to Career Focus, Skills Link and Opportunities Fund for Persons with Disabilities as of January 1st 2016.)

Given that a fiscal year is the period commencing on April 1st in one calendar year and ending on March 31st in the next calendar year, the fixed quarter schedule is:

  • April 1st – June 30th (Quarter 1);
  • July 1st – September 30th (Quarter 2);
  • October 1st – December 31st (Quarter 3); and
  • January 1st – March 31st (Quarter 4).

Projects not starting the first day of a quarter or not ending the last day of a quarter would still follow the fixed period schedule. For example, although a project may begin in June and end the following January, its quarters would still follow the fixed period schedule and certain periods would simply be shorter. For this example, the project first quarter would only include June expenditures and activities, while its last quarter would only include January expenditures and activities.

10.3 Documentation Required to Process Payments

To request the payment of expenses eligible for reimbursement under a funding agreement or to reconcile actual expenses against advance payments, recipients must submit a claim, including an activity report and other supporting documentation as required for the period covered that demonstrates recipient progress towards achieving objectives – through the completion of activities and the realization of expected results - as described in the funding agreement. Activity reports are mandatory and must be attached to the claim.

A forecast of project expenditures (FPE) is mandatory for advance payments. The FPE supports cash management and fiscal year splits for the project.

FPEs are optional for progress payments. However, some programs require an FPE for all projects in order to support cash management and fiscal year splits. Consult the program specific guidelines in order to determine whether an FPE is required.

Supporting documentation is determined by the implementation of a risk-based approach. The Department uses the organizational risk level in a strategic way, enabling a tailored approach to managing the risk, with more efforts directed to the higher risk projects.

The requirement of supporting documentation for processing a claim is based on the total score of five (5) criteria for “organizational risk” determined for the project: activity performance, ability to demonstrate results, financial performance, organization administration, and stability of the board and/or organization. Projects with a medium and high organizational risk score have to submit a GL or financial spreadsheet along with the claim. The submission of a GL or financial spreadsheet is to assist the program delivery staff in their selection of transactions within higher risk cost categories for the purpose of processing the claim. It may also be used for a financial monitor. The following table illustrates what supporting documentation is required based on the RAMM score for the organizational risk:

  • Claim
  • Activity report

  • Claim

  • FPE (for advance paying projects)
  • General Ledger or financial spreadsheet (transaction-level detail)

Please note that any claim over $500,000, regardless of their risk level (with the exception of agreements with provincial and territorial governments) will be treated as high risk, due to their high dollar value, and will be subject to the submission of supporting documentation.

As of December 17th, 2012, all programs (with the exception of Canada Summer Jobs) will be required to use the following standard documents for all new projects:

  • the claim (based on program cost category set);
  • the activity report; and
  • the FPE (if on advance payment).
10.3.1 Claim Information

Project recipients complete their own tombstone data. They also enter the actual expenses incurred under each relevant, eligible cost category listed on the form. A zero should be recorded if no expenses were incurred within a certain cost category.

10.3.2 Activity Report

In addition to the claim, project recipients submit an activity report. Specific timing for reporting is outlined in the funding agreement.

Project recipients use the activity report to demonstrate how the funding received is used to support their project objectives.

The activity report summarizes:

  • the overall progress achieved toward the objectives;
  • activities carried out to achieve the outcomes; and,
  • possible issues which could affect the success of the project.

Note: the activity report is not intended to show every detail of the project. It should be used as a systematic summary of key information about the project. For more information, please consult the How To Activity Report tools.

10.3.3 Forecast of Project Expenditures

All contribution projects (with the exception of the Canada Summer Jobs program) that use an advance payment frequency must include a forecast of project expenditures (FPE) in order to support cash management and fiscal year splits.

The purpose of the FPE is to plan and outline the anticipated financial requirements of a project as well as when those funds are required. It includes the expected amount of funding required for each future reporting period and actual amounts spent and/or approved for past periods.

Recipients complete the FPE to identify expected expenditures for their project, taking into account:

  • the project’s financial need (how much money is needed);
  • timing (when they need it); and,
  • the project’s current financial.

Recipients may either submit their FPE electronically via the Grants and Contributions Online Services (GCOS), electronically or in paper format.

When updating the FPE paper form, recipients should enter the actual amounts of expenditures approved by the Department in past periods, regardless of the amount they have claimed to date. Requests for remaining periods should reflect the estimated amounts required to complete project activities and achieve expected results. The total of all such past and future periods, however, cannot exceed the total agreement value.

In order to ensure sound financial management of project and program budgets, the forecast of project expenditures should be reviewed on an ongoing basis to determine if the annual budget will be fully expended. At a minimum this should be reviewed in the last quarter of the fiscal year. If it is determined that the recipient will not utilize its current fiscal year budget, these funds should be de-committed from the project prior to period 13 (prior to March 31). The de-commitment of funds may be used to meet other fiscal year priorities, or will be lapsed. In the case of multi-year agreements, the unused commitment may be moved over to the next fiscal year using new year budget and should be based on financial need and budget availability. This must be completed prior to period 13 (prior to March 31). A minor amendment is always required to complete these adjustments (please refer the Monitoring and Mitigation Strategies Chapter for additional information).

10.4 Steps in Processing Payments

Whether a recipient is receiving progress or advance payments, the steps in processing payments are the same:

  • Step 1: receiving and reviewing the claim;
  • Step 2: verifying the account;
  • Step 3: obtaining payment approval; and
  • Step 4: requisitioning a payment (if applicable).
Step 1: Receiving and Reviewing the Claim

The recipient submits a claim (by email, via GCOS or in paper format) accompanied by an activity report, and if applicable, an FPE and other supporting documents on a monthly or quarterly basis. If program-specific guidelines allow, project recipient can fax their claims, but they must be clear and legible.

Given the slight variations in claims (three standard forms), program delivery staff must ensure that project recipients are provided with, and submit, the applicable claim containing the proper cost categories.

Once the claim from the recipient has been received, program delivery staff should review it carefully to determine whether:

  • the project recipient has completed the claim properly;
  • the claim is consistent with the frequency of payments prescribed within the funding agreement;
  • supporting documentation is submitted (if applicable);
  • eligible expenditures incurred correspond to approved activities and have been entered into the correct cost categories, and the cost categories are in agreement with the program-specific cost category set;
  • amounts claimed for each eligible expenditure category meet the terms and rates defined within the agreement (generally schedule B);
  • the expenditures were incurred within the approved timeframe;
  • the claim reflects actual project costs;
  • the sum of all payments made does not exceed the total amount allowable under the agreement;
  • the project recipient is meeting the agreement provisions;
  • the latest monitoring report supports the issuance of further payments; and
  • the claim was signed by the delegated representatives of the organization, as identified in the Signing Officers form.

Note: If the claim has not been completed proprely, program delivery staff must ask the recipient to re-sumbmit a corrected claim, or ask the recipient to initial the corrections made by the program delivery staff.

Following receipt of the claim, begin by capturing claim information in the Financial Management phase of the CSGC Project Life Cycle module using the Capture Claim Information screen. The Financial Management Chapter of the CSGC User Guide describes the screens and processes which should be used in order to enter and reconcile claims.

Step 2: Verifying the Account

Program delivery staff is expected to review the activity report to ensure the activities are in line with the claimed expenses.

Once the claim and activity report have been received and reviewed (as detailed above), the program delivery staff will request supporting documentation (for example invoices, receipts or other supporting documentation as determined by the Department to support expenditures claimed). All reviews should be documented and saved in the supporting documents function within CSGC. The note should include a confirmation of the outcome (i.e. that all documents reviewed were satisfactory and accounted for the required minimum percentage, or that additional information is required to substantiate the claimed amount).

Selecting transaction level information (only applicable for medium and high risk)

The submission of a GL or financial spreadsheet is to assist the program delivery staff in their selection of transactions within higher risk cost categories for the purpose of processing the claim, and may be used during a financial monitor. A minimum percentage of the total claimed expenditures (5% for medium and 10% for high risk projects) from higher risk cost categories will be reviewed.

Medium organizational risk level

  • Program delivery staff request a sampling of receipts selected from transactions in the General Ledger (GL) or a financial spreadsheet only for the first two reporting periods, if no issues are identified. If there are issues identified with the first two claims, program delivery staff will continue to request supporting documentation until there are two claim periods without any discrepancies or issues. If issues persist, or if the project is of a short duration, program delivery staff should schedule a financial monitoring to address the issue(s). The transactions for review are to be taken from the higher risk cost categories as defined below. Program delivery staff will request supporting documentation (for example receipts, invoices, or other supporting documentation as determined by the Department from the higher risk cost categories to substantiate a minimum of 5% the amount claimed under those higher risk cost categories).

It is important to note that payment will not be withheld while waiting for the supporting documents. Should issues be identified with the receipts in the post-payment verification phase, the amount can be disallowed on subsequent payments. However, the observation should be documented for future reference.

High organizational risk level

  • Program delivery staff requests a sampling of receipts selected from transactions in the GL or financial spreadsheet for all reporting periods. These transactions are to be taken from the higher risk cost categories defined below. Program delivery staff will request supporting documentation (for example, receipts, invoices or other supporting documentation as determined by the Departmentfrom the higher risk cost categories to substantiate a minimum of 10% of the amount claimed under those higher risk cost categories.

It is important to note that payment is withheld until receipts are received. Should issues be identified with the receipts in the pre-payment verification phase, the amount is disallowed from the claim.

Higher risk cost categories include:

  • Individual cost categories with a total amount in excess of 50% of total value of the claim (e.g. total claim is $100,000, and a specific cost category represents $65,000)
  • Other categories such as:
    • Capital costs / Capital assets;
    • Project costs (including Hospitality and Travel – if applicable in cost set); and
    • Travel (applicable to Set A with Flat Rates projects)

Note that higher risk cost categories may vary from program to program as well as from project to project. The following additional cost categories have been identified for ASETS, SPF and HPS agreements (where applicable):

  • Sub-projects Administrative costs
  • Child Care costs
  • Sub-projects Project costs

Other cost categories

If the minimum amount to review has not been achieved by sampling the above mentioned higher risk cost categories, program delivery staff may request a percentage of receipts and/or invoices from the remaining cost categories

  • Administrative costs (with the exception of programs using flat rates)
  • Wages
  • Rent (Set A for Opportunities Fund and Skills Link only)

Other Considerations

As the claim is supported by an activity report, program delivery staff should select sample invoices and/or receipts based on activities that occurred during the reported period. For example, should the activity report identify a trip and/or a conference, it is suggested that the program delivery staff request invoices and receipts to substantiate that particular expenditure. It is also recommended that the sample of cost categories vary from the two reporting periods. For example, if wages are sampled during the first reporting period, it is recommended that a different cost category be sampled during the second reporting period.

For short term medium risk projects (less than 6 months)

As previously stated in the Risk Assessment Chapter, medium risk projects have a quarterly reporting frequency. According to the supporting documentation requirements, medium risk projects must submit a general ledger or financial spreadsheet for the first two reporting period. In addition, the project is subject to one financial monitoring during the life of the agreement.

Step 3: Obtaining Payment Approval

After the claim has been received, checked and verified, program delivery staff can obtain approval for that claim. Under section 34 of the Financial Administration Act, the expenditure approval authority must review the claim and supporting documents, if applicable; to confirm the verification process was adequate.

In CSGC, after entering the claim information, program delivery staff will see a claim approval screen. This approval screen includes a summary of the submitted information as well as a signature section which is to be printed and sent for the necessary internal approval of section 34. To ensure that the correct delegation of authority is applied, program delivery staff should verify the Signing Authority Web Application (SAA) as this central system provides electronic access to the Delegated Authorities and facilitates the maintenance of the departmental specimen signature cards. When the project recipient submits a paper claim, the claim approval form is to be printed from the CSGC and attached to the paper submission before being sent for section 34 approval.

As part of their management control function, Cost Centre (CC) managers (or whoever oversees budgets) have primary responsibility for costs incurred and expenditures charged to their budgets. They must, therefore, perform expenditure pre-audit prior to transaction release in order to verify that:

  • claims submitted for payment are originals or copies;
  • the signature of the expenditure approval authority officer appears on the payment document. Initials are required in the ‘Pre-audit performed by’ section of the claim or advance and activity report for project entered in the CSGC prior to December 17th, 2012); and,
  • the name, address and project number that appear in SAP correspond to those in the project file.

Do not exceed the limits of delegated authority; refer to the Financial Delegation Instrument to confirm expenditure approval authority.
The CSGCAuthorize Transaction screen allows program delivery staff to record the payment approval (or rejection).

Note that in the rare case where a claim for $0 is submitted, a section 34 certification is not required as no payment is being issued.

Capture Claim Screen

The CSGC Capture Claim Information screen is used to:

  • record the details of expenditures claimed by the organization; and,
  • change and re-submit claim rejected during the first review stage.

See the Financial Management Chapter of the CSGC Users Guide for more information about the processes followed to capture and reconcile claim data.

Step 4: Requisitioning a Payment

The Department issues a payment once the claim and supporting documentation is verified and approved.

Once a claim has been approved, program delivery staff have no further duties to perform where requisitioning the payment is concerned. Once approved, the claim is entered into SAP, which then automatically informs Public Services and Procurement Canada (PSPC) of the request for payment. PSPC then issues and sends the payment to the organization. Please ensure the organization’s e-mail is on file. A confirmation e-mail will be sent to the recipient when the payment has been issued.

Please note that effective April 1, 2015, amendments to the Financial Administration Act were implemented to streamline low value payments. Payments of $2.00 or less will no longer be paid out or collected.

10.5 Issuing Advance Payments

Under section 34 of the Financial Administration Act, program delivery staff must ensure the following conditions are met before authorizing advance payments:

  • the funding agreement specifies that advance payments are a permitted payment option;
  • the recipient has identified their need for advance payments and provided a rationale—including a forecast of project expenditures (FPE); and
  • advance payment amounts will be limited to the recipient’s imminent cash requirements, based on the FPE and project activities.

Program delivery staff must exercise prudence in making advance payments and must have sufficient basis for issuing all payments to a recipient.

Advance payments may include:

  • initial advance payment;
  • subsequent advance payments; and,
  • final payment.
10.5.1 Initial Advance Payment

Subject to the terms of the funding agreement identified during the Agreement Set-up phase, program delivery staff can issue the first, or initial advance payment (which may account for up to two periods) based on the recipient’s needs, as identified on their forecast of project expenditures (FPE) to help the recipient pay for eligible expenses that must be incurred at the beginning of project activities.

This advance represents the first period on the FPE depending on the frequency of the advance i.e. monthly or quarterly. The actual amount of an advance is based upon the FPE and can only be issued after the funding agreement is signed by both parties.

For further information concerning the issuance of initial advance payments, please consult the section Prepare Initial Advance, of the CSGC User Guide.

Note: While reviewing the following information, you may also wish to consult the Financial Management Chapter of the CSGC Users Guide, which describes the screens and processes used to issue advances.

10.5.2 Subsequent Advance Payment

Any advance payment issued after the initial advance is referred to a subsequent advance.

All advance payments are tied to the FPE and should not be issued any earlier than necessary. This FPE is mandatory for all projects using advance payments.

Before issuing advance payments, program delivery staff must carefully assess the recipient’s FPE against corresponding project activities approved in the funding agreement to determine the appropriate advance payment amount. If the FPE does not appear realistic, one should discuss issues of concern with the recipient and request an updated version.

Two consecutive advance payments may be issued prior to receiving a recipient’s claim, however, a third advance payment cannot be issued until a claim is received and reconciled for the first advanced period.

The total of these payments cannot exceed the amount indicated in the FPE for that period. If the FPE is amended by the recipient for previously paid out periods, an adjustment payment can be processed.

Recipients claim eligible expenditures using the departmental standardized forms: claim, FPE, activity report and supporting documentation (if applicable).

Once program delivery staff receives and processes claims, subsequent advances should be issued based on a detailed review of these claims and supporting documentation. Note that, although variations may exist between programs, generally it is expected that claims are submitted to the Department within 15 days following the reporting period (refer to section 10.10 – Service Standards). Refer to section 10.4 for information on how to process a claim.

Determining the amount of the subsequent advance payments involves several steps: reconciling the amount that has been claimed by the recipient against the amount that was advanced to them and then, issuing the subsequent advance.

Steps to determine subsequent advance:

Reconciling the claim

  • [Amount claimed for period 1] – [Period 1 advance] = amount to be paid
  • If the claim is greater than the amount of the advance for the period, CSGC will generate a claim payment for the difference.
  • Once the claim payment is approved in CSGC, you can prepare the next subsequent advance.

Issuing the subsequent advance

There are three possible outcomes when reconciling a claim.

  • The claim is equal to the advance: No payment issued
  • The claim is greater than the advance: A claim payment is issued
  • The claim is less than the advance: The balance goes into the unaccounted funds.

Example:

The recipient forecasted $10,000 for the month of September, which was issued as an advance payment on August 20th.

On September 1st, the recipient submitted a revised FPE in which $15,000 was forecasted for September.

On September 3rd, program delivery staff confirmed that the increased advance aligned with the project activities for September, adjusted the FPE in the CSGC, and recommended the issuance of an additional payment of $5,000 for September.

Example:

An advance payment of $10,000 was issued to the recipient for the month of May. On June 15th, the recipient claimed $8,000 in eligible expenses for that month.

The FPE for June shows $10,000. The CSGC will automatically assume that the unclaimed balance of $2,000 will be carried over to the next month.

The CSGC, therefore, will permit a maximum advance of $8,000 for June.

Although it is an acceptable practice to issue two consecutive advance payments prior to receiving a claim, the Department cannot issue a third advance payment until a claim for the first period is received and processed. The CSGC prevents any further advance payments from being issued until at least one of the advance payments has been reconciled against a claim for actual expenses incurred.

Example:

$10,000 in advance payments was issued to the recipient for each of the months of May and June for a total of $20,000. There are now two outstanding advance payments issued to the recipient and no claim has been submitted to date. The recipient’s forecast of project expenditures for July is also $10,000.

On June 15th, program delivery staff receives a claim for $6,000 of eligible expenses for the month of May. This claim is processed. Now one advance payment has been reconciled with $4,000 carried over ($10,000 issued less $6,000 claimed). One advance payment is still outstanding for $10,000 for June.

In June, program delivery staff can still issue an advance payment for July up to the maximum of $6,000 ($10,000 required for July less $4,000 balance from May). Again, the recipient will have two outstanding advances: one for June of $10,000 and one for July of $6,000. The claim for costs incurred in June must be processed before any further funds can be advanced.

Program delivery staff cannot issue an advance retroactively; one has until the last day of a period (monthly or quarterly) to issue advances for that period.

Examples:

If the project is on a monthly reporting schedule, April 30th is the last day that an advance payment can be issued for the month covering April 1st to 30th.

If the project is on a quarterly reporting schedule, June 30th is the last day that an advance payment can be issued for the quarter covering April 1st to June 30th.

Program delivery staff cannot issue an advance for a period when the subsequent period has already been advanced.

Example:

On August 10th, program delivery staff issued an advance payment of $10,000 for September as per the recipient’s FPE. On August 29th, program delivery staff issued an advance payment of $10,000 for October as per the recipient’s FPE.

On September 3rd, program delivery staff receives a revised FPE from the recipient that shows a need for an additional $3,000 in September.

However, the October advance payment has already been issued, so no further advances can be made for September. Program delivery staff would have to negotiate with the recipient one of the following options:

  • Adjust the October FPE to make up for the $3,000 shortfall and issue a second advance for October (with this option, watch that CSGC does not issue a separate payment for any shortfall registered for September despite the second advance for October).
  • Alternatively, the recipient may submit a claim for September for the actual expenses. If the total for September is $12,595, then the CSGC will issue a separate payment to the recipient for $2,595 ($10,000 less $12,595 = negative balance of $2,595)
10.5.3 Final Payment

If the claim is the last one of the project, please refer to the Close-Out – Making Final Payments Chapter.

10.5.4 Interest Earned on Advance Payments

Interest earned on advance payments is deemed to be part payment of Canada’s contribution. Recipients must, therefore, account for any interest earned in excess of one hundred dollars ($100) on advance payments. The interest will be taken into account in the calculation of the final payment by Canada, or repayment by the Recipient.

10.5.5 Managing the Holdback Amount

The Department may hold back a portion of the allocated funds until project completion in order to minimize the risk of overpayment and to encourage the recipient to comply with agreement provisions. Holdbacks apply to funding agreements using advance payments.

To avoid the possibility of overpayment, program delivery staff should not pay the full funding amount available under the agreement as an advance. The retained holdback should only be paid after the recipient has submitted their final claim and other supporting documentation as required by Canada.

Up to a maximum of 10% of the total funding amount can be held back. The general rule is to hold back 10% of the total funding amount; however, program delivery staff do have the option, upon request, of reducing the holdback amount. To do this, one must ask the recipient for a letter (which can be emailed, faxed or uploaded to the GCOS) that requests the reduction and provides a rationale for granting it. Program delivery staff, in turn, must document the request, providing a recommendation and, if affirmative, include a rationale in CSGC for the reduced holdback. Some programs have other specific guidelines and therefore program delivery staff should, if applicable, refer to those guidelines.

Example:

A contribution agreement was signed with a recipient.  The agreement value is $250,000, and a holdback was established at $25,000 ($250,000 x 10%), thus leaving $225,000 available to advance funds.

If you had an agreement with a total value of $270,000, and the holdback is 10%, the total holdback would be $27,000.

If the money was needed before the final claim and monitoring was completed, the holdback could be reduced to a lower amount, as low as zero.

Prior to reducing the holdback amount, the recipient must request in writing that the holdback amount be reduced, and provide a description and rationale for the use of all the funds held in the holdback. You must approve this rationale and document in CSGC.

If, by the end of a project, the total payments made to the recipient exceed the allowable expenses, the difference—an overpayment—becomes a debt to the Crown. This outstanding balance must be recorded as an account receivable transaction in the Departmental Accounts Receivable System (DARS). It will then be recovered from the recipient.

Whenever a recipient fails to provide adequate accounting, or has not used departmental funds for authorized purposes, a demand for accounting or repayment can be issued under the Financial Administration Act (04-01) Section 76(1)(b) and (c).

Please refer to the Overpayments section of the Close-Out Chapter for additional information.

One may also wish to consult the section 9.2 Agreement / Create Grant Agreement Chapter of the CSGC User Guide, which describes the screens and processes used to establish holdbacks.

10.6 Carry-forwards of Unused Commitments

Carry forward is defined as the act of transferring the balance of an unused commitment from one fiscal year to the following fiscal year. The Treasury Board Policy on Transfer Payments and its associated Directives dictates if and how a carry forward is allowed for contribution programs.

The automatic transfer of unused commitment from one year to next year’s budget is not an acceptable practice unless otherwise authorized in writing by Canada in the form of an amendment to the agreement (Schedule B of the contribution agreement, clause 1.2).

Program delivery staff are encouraged to follow the principles of the financial management policies regarding commitment controls and to de-commit unused funds as soon as they are identified. Upon receipt of a carry forward request, a review of the organization’s financial track record and project activities for the previous and upcoming fiscal years should be conducted by program delivery staff to determine if the request is reasonable and gauge the organization’s ability to expend, in the upcoming fiscal year, both the planned carry forward commitment as well as their annual allocation for that fiscal year.

The Department’s decision to approve the carry forward request must be documented via an amendment and if approved, an amended agreement will be required in CSGC to reallocate the funds accordingly. Please refer to the Monitoring and Mitigation Chapter for additional information.

10.6.1 Assessing the Impact of Fiscal Year End on Advance Payments

Generally, program delivery staff cannot issue advance payments to recipients in one fiscal year when the related expenditures will likely not be incurred until the following fiscal year.

Approved funds must be spent in the fiscal year for which they are appropriated and must not be carried forward by means of advance payments.

One must, therefore, issue advance payments required for the new fiscal year as of April 1st and charge these to an appropriation in the new year; remember to consider outstanding advances from the previous fiscal year when issuing further advances or claim payments in the new fiscal year. Also, advise recipients that fiscal year-end requirements prevent program delivery staff from issuing monthly or quarterly advances in April as quickly as other advances may have been issued.

Exceptions, however, may be made to this fiscal year rule if they are necessary to meet program objectives. Such exceptions must be well documented and monitored to ensure advanced funds are properly accounted for.

In such cases, program delivery staff can only issue an advance for the month of April from old year funds. One must do this before March 31st to count it as eligible for payment from the old fiscal year; after that, issue the advance from new fiscal year funds. Each February, Fiscal Year End Instructions are posted on the CoE Website and provide information on dealing with year-end processes.

In situations where an agreement extends beyond one fiscal year and an advance is provided in the first fiscal year, but a portion of that advance has not yet been used by the recipients by the end of that fiscal year, the Department may allow the recipient to carry forward the unused portion as an advance for the new year. This approach usually applies when the unused amount is relatively insignificant (i.e. less than the projected expenditures for April). A note to file should be added detailing the situation.

When an agreement ends and the recipient is left with a surplus during the final accounting because advances exceeded actual expenditures incurred, program delivery staff must review this balance to confirm the amount. In cases where funds then remain outstanding, the amount owed to the Department must be documented. Once the recipient has been notified and given an appropriate amount of time to repay the amount due, but fails to do so, program delivery staff can then set up an overpayment in DARS. Please refer to the Close-Out - Overpayments Chapter for information on how to manage overpayments.

10.7 Managing Payable-At-Year-End (PAYE)

The term "payable-at-year-end", or PAYE, refers to the mechanism used to process payments that occur at fiscal year-end but are paid in the new fiscal year using old year funds.

All federal departments use a standard "P" and "Q" system to identify all periods and quarters of the fiscal year in which grants and contributions funds, operating and maintenance funds, and salaries are allocated, forecasted, committed and expended.

P1

April

 Q1 - First quarter April 1 to June 30
P2 May
P3 June
P4 July

Q2 - Second quarter July 1 to September 30
P5 August
P6

September – a common period for forecasting program expenditures for the remainder of the fiscal year
P7 October

Q3 - Third quarter October 1 to December 31
P8 November
P9

December – also a common period for forecasting program expenditures for the remainder of the fiscal year and for identifying slippage in funds
P10 January

Q4 - Fourth quarter January 1 to March 31
P11 February
P12

March – the P-13 period is identified and communicated to all staff with guidelines for PAYE practices
P13

April following the past fiscal year

  

This fiscal-year system is standard across the Department and must be adhered to by all staff, regardless of agreement start and end dates or the various fiscal-year systems used by recipients.

When payments are due close to March 31st, program delivery staff must ensure payment is made within the old fiscal year of the original fund commitment. The timelines for handling fiscal year-end transactions change from year to year but encompass a period of about three weeks from late March to mid-April.

The use of PAYE transactions should be the exception rather than the rule. That being said, take PAYE practices into account for all agreements that end near or after March 31st and discuss related issues with recipients to make appropriate arrangements; while program delivery staff must ensure claims and documentation are submitted in a timely manner, recipients must also be given adequate time to reconcile expenses with their banks, process bill payments and address other issues associated with project completion. The articles of agreement specify how many days are acceptable in order to wrap up an initiative.

If the project end date is near March 31st but the recipient is unable to reconcile and submit all documentation required to close out the file by the identified deadline following fiscal year-end (period 13 --P13), then a PAYE transaction must be prepared. To charge a claim against the old fiscal year budget, one must estimate the amount of the late claim(s) and create a PAYE account for the project. Continue to communicate with the recipient in order to develop this estimate, avoid missing the P13 deadline, and minimize slippage (unused funds).

Example: On March 1st, program delivery staff receives an internal announcement that P13 is April 5th to 26th. A current agreement being managed ends on March 25th. Inform the recipient that their final claim must be processed as soon as possible, but no later than April 23rd in order to allow sufficient time for verifying the claim and processing the transaction.

Note that some programs may have varying capacities to re-profile funds; please refer to program-specific guidelines.
Remember that the old fiscal year accounts are closed in SAP at the end of the P13 period; after that, it is no longer possible to directly account for expenses incurred in the old fiscal year.

When the claim is accepted against an old fiscal year, the system will automatically charge the expenses against the PAYE account. If the actual past fiscal year claim exceeds the PAYE funds available, the system will automatically charge the excess against the current fiscal year commitment. If the claim is less than the PAYE, the remaining funds in the PAYE will be lapsed.

For agreements that rely on advance payments, please consider the following:

Before setting up a PAYE transaction on an advance payments agreement, program delivery staff must confirm that the recipient has submitted an updated FPE showing the expenses covered by PAYE in the old fiscal year.

SAP will automatically carry over the unaccounted advance payment balance to the new fiscal year. As a result, program delivery staff only needs to set up a PAYE transaction when the recipient’s March claim will exceed the outstanding advances already issued.

Example: On March 1st, an internal announcement is received that P13 is April 5th to 26th. A current agreement being managed started in January and ends in October.

The recipient received advances of $10,000 for February and $10,000 for March, as per their FPE. They have claimed $7,000 for February but nothing yet for March.

They advise the Department that they will need an estimated $13,000 to cover March expenses. Program delivery staff will not, therefore, need to set up a PAYE transaction because the $3,000 carried over from February's claim will be reconciled against the March claim if it is received early enough to process the claim before the P13 deadline on April 26th.

If the recipient had forecasted $14,000 in March expenses, however, one would then have to set up a PAYE transaction for the balance of $1,000.

Please note that all unused PAYEs are to be de-committed as required.

10.8 Direct Deposit

The recipient can choose to receive their grant and contribution payments by cheque or direct deposit. Direct deposit for recipients is available for all programs. A recipient must complete a Grants and Contributions Direct Deposit Request Form to initiate direct deposit. The financial institution account will be tested once by depositing project funds. A program official will contact the recipient to confirm that they received the test payment. This measure helps to ensure that the payments are deposited safely and quickly. For detailed information, refer to the Direct Deposit Desk Aid.

Note: PSPC is phasing out cheques, please refer to Direct Deposit Desk Aid for additional information on Direct Deposit.

10.9 Manual Payments

All grant and contribution payments must be processed in the Common System for Grants and Contributions (CSGC). However, exceptional situations sometimes arise where a payment cannot be processed through CSGC and the only solution is to proceed with a manual payment in myEMS.

Before requesting a manual payment, ensure that you have exhausted the capacities of the CSGC file. Open a ticket in the Business Expertise Request Tool (BERT) so that an adviser can assist you during the process and confirm that a manual payment is the only option.
Once it has been determined that a manual payment is the only option, please refer to Guideline on Manual Payments and Returned Funds for further detail and step by step instructions.

10.10 Service Standards

The Department has established a Time to Payment service standard. The timeframe differs depending on whether the transfer payment method is a grant or contribution. In either case, information entered into the CSGC for each claim allows for the performance measurement of this standard.

The Time to Payment service standard states that:

For approved Contribution projects, the Department’s goal is to process the payment within 28 calendar days of receiving a completed claim package.

For approved Grant projects, the Department’s goal is to process the payment no later than 15 calendar days after the approved project start date.

Concerning contributions, two mandatory sections exist in the CSGC – a ‘Date Complete Claim Received’ field (located directly beside the ‘Date Claim Received’ field of the ‘Capture Claim Information’ and ‘Capture Close Out Claim’ screens) and the ‘Authorize Transaction’ screen (which provides the date that the request is sent to SAP). Once completed, these two sections will provide an exact measurement of the contribution aspect of the Service Standard.

The Service Standard’s timeframe for grants is measured by way of two sections in CSGC – ‘Project Start Date’ and the ‘Authorize Transaction’ screen (which provides the date that the request is sent to SAP). Note that the Service Standard applies only to the first payment. Once completed, these two sections will provide an exact measurement of the grant aspect of the Service Standard.

Program staff and managers are able to review individual program statistics with the aid of the four ‘Speed of Service’ performance measurement reports located within the ‘Operational Reports/Performance Measurement’ section of the CSGC – ‘Time to Process Claim Payments (Contributions – Progress Payments)’; ‘Time to Process Claim Payments (Contributions – Monthly Advances)’; ‘Time to Process Claim Payments (Contributions – Quarterly Advances)’; and, ‘Time to Process Installment Payments (Grants)’.

Chapter 11. Monitoring and Mitigation

Please refer to the 2012 Ops Guide, Chapter 10 and Chapter 11

10.0 Monitoring

Managing projects is based, in large part, upon risk level as assessed by program delivery staff. The RAMM tool enables a comprehensive assessment of the risk factors for individual organizations and projects, and determines the level of monitoring required by project.

As of December 15th, 2012, a new risk-based methodology, using the assessment information entered into the RAMM tool, has been introduced. The RAMM tool remains the same, however now the risk score is used in a more strategic way with more monitoring efforts being directed towards the highest risk areas, thus enabling a more tailored approach to managing risk.

The new approach does not change the way program delivery staff assess the 10 RAMM factors. Once the 10 RAMM factors have been assessed, justified and saved, the CSGC advises program delivery staff on the frequency of certain risk mitigation activities, including monitoring activities (financial, activities, and results).This new approach allows the frequency of each monitoring type to be tailored to respond to the level of assessed risk of specific, pre-determined combinations of RAMM factors.

The new risk-based methodology only applies to projects which have been entered into the CSGC on, or after, December 15th, 2012. In the case of existing projects, or those entered into the CSGC prior to December 15th, 2012, the RAMM overall risk score continues to inform the frequency of the risk mitigation activities, which includes monitoring activities (see chapter 6 for more information on risk management).

The practices outlined in this chapter are standard monitoring activities and can be used in conjunction with the appropriate RAMM monitoring type. See:

  • monitoring
  • mitigation strategies

For low risk projects, mitigation strategies may include (but are not limited to):

  • corrective measures;
  • amendments;
  • additional monitoring; and,
  • no immediate action required;

For situations where monitoring has turned up significant issues in a project that cannot easily be mitigated and where the organization fails to take corrective action, stronger measures must be taken, such as:

  • audit;
  • probation;
  • suspension; and,
  • termination.

10.1 Monitoring

Monitoring is a proactive process for managing, reviewing and problem-solving issues within a project context to ensure the agreement is implemented as approved by both parties. Regular monitoring increases the odds of project success and provides for opportunities to support the organization, anticipate potential problems and plan necessary mitigation strategies to address these problems.

All monitoring activities and schedules are based on the assessed level of risk associated with each project. Lower-risk projects warrant less monitoring than higher-risk projects. The frequency of monitoring required, based on organization and project risk provides a reasonable assurance that project objectives will be met and that public funds are spent in the intended manner.

Project monitoring is intended to:

  • verify that public funds are used as intended;
  • verify that project activities are conducted as described in the agreement;
  • verify that expected results are achieved as described in the agreement; and,
  • provide support to the organization in order to support the success of the project.

Information gathered through monitoring helps the Department to:

  • review the effectiveness of procedures, systems and controls;
  • track the performance history of project organizations;
  • share expectations for financial accountability;
  • develop standardized, generic tools in support of grants and contributions; and,
  • improve upon project management practices.

Finally, monitoring can also be used for outcomes research and evaluation, to build corporate memory, and to promote awareness of issues and effective mitigation practices.

The Monitoring Plan

The monitoring plan (as found under the Monitoring Summary screen within CSGC) describes the frequency and type of monitors that are to be performed on each particular project. The monitoring plan ultimately provides both the organization and HRSDC with opportunities to increase project success through strategically-planned observations and interventions. In developing a plan, agreement provisions, as well as organization needs and expectations, must be balanced against the time required to adequately monitor the agreement. The Policy on Transfer Payments requires that the level of monitoring of organizations reflects an assessment of the risks specific to the program, the value of the funding in relation to administrative costs, and the risk profile of organizations.

The monitoring plan can be thought of as a virtual calendar or appointment book, as it helps organize time and workload. The completed plan details the:

  • timing (when the monitoring will be conducted);
  • frequency (how often monitoring will take place);
  • strategies (what type of monitor will be performed and whether it will take place on-site or off-site); and,
  • scope (what will be monitored).

While each monitoring plan should address these standard components, the plan should remain flexible enough to respond to the changing needs of the project. Any changes and alleviations to the monitoring plan must be documented on file.

At a minimum, each project is to be monitored at least once for each type of monitoring (activity, financial and results) during the project lifetime. The RAMM tool and its relevant approaches identify the frequency of monitors required for each project. The monitoring plan requires that this frequency be respected. Any additional monitoring activities beyond the minimum required by RAMM must be discussed and approved, with written justification, by supervisory staff.

Monitoring plans are to be reviewed and revised accordingly whenever the project risk assessment changes. This could happen as a result of an amendment to the project, or a change in circumstances (for example, change of book-keeper or withdrawal of a project partner), or simply as a result of new information. As the perceived risks of the project change, the risk assessment is to be re-assessed and the monitoring plan revised if necessary. If a new risk score modifies the frequency of monitors, program delivery staff will be advised to modify the monitoring plan. Any time the project risk assessment is revised, so, too, should the risk mitigation strategies be verified for continued applicability.

The CSGC generates a report on outstanding monitors; supervisors and program delivery staff alike are encouraged to make regular use of this feature in order to support timely project monitoring, and also encourage appropriate follow-up and the maintenance of proper documentation.

Documenting Risk Mitigation and Monitoring Activities

All program delivery staff managing a project must understand:

  • the risk level associated with the project and the reasons for the ranking;
  • the need for this risk assessment and its associated monitoring plan; and,
  • identified mitigation strategies and, if applicable, any actions taken.

All decisions made, in terms of mitigating risks and actions taken pertaining to a project, must be documented. The justification boxes in the risk assessment screen of the CSGC capture this information. In addition, a separate text box within this same screen captures information on any additional risk mitigation strategies that have, if applicable, been implemented.

Risk assessment and monitoring strategies are to be documented, as well as any required follow-up actions, the ensuing results of that follow-up, and any outstanding issues.

Monitoring reports, including those completed outside of CSGC, must be completed and entered into the CSGC using the ‘Record Monitoring Details screen’. Program delivery staff are to verify that any outstanding issues raised during previous monitors have been resolved and recorded, by making use of the “Follow–up required” function in the CSGC.

Changes in the monitoring schedule, as well as all types of informal contact with the organization, must be documented by a ‘note to file’ in the CSGC, in order to ensure the continuity of the project file. The reasons for changes to risk assessments, and the changes to risk mitigation that result, must be documented in the CSGC using the justification dialogue boxes in the ‘Assess Project Risk’ screen.

The Monitoring Schedule using the Overall RAMM Score (projects entered into the CSGC prior to December 15th, 2012).

RAMM is HRSDC’s standard tool used to assess and manage project-related levels of risk for all funding agreements entered into the CSGC before December 15th, 2012, and signed as of April 1st, 2010, as well as for those pre-existing agreements converted to RAMM in the CSGC.

Monitoring under the use of the overall RAMM score:

  • determines the frequency of monitoring as tailored to respond to the level of assessed risk for a particular project;
  • defines HRSDC approaches according to three types of RAMM monitoring:
    • type 1: review of financial and activity report(s);
    • type 2: in-depth review of expenditures and activities; and,
    • type 3: results review.
  • proposes the use of RAMM-specific mitigation strategies;
  • recognizes the review and processing of activity reports and claim forms as an integral aspect of project monitoring;
  • gives program delivery staff greater flexibility to complete paper-based or on-site monitors, thus reducing the administrative burden for both the Department and the organization; and,
  • provides greater opportunity to re-assess the level of risk throughout the project life cycle.

The monitoring schedule, found below, outlines the number and type of monitoring activities program delivery staff must perform each year relative to the monitoring strategy developed for a specific project. Monitoring frequency is based upon a project’s overall level of risk; high-risk projects are monitored more frequently while low-risk projects are monitored less frequently. Hence, it is important to update the risk level rankings for each of the criteria identified in the RAMM risk assessment tool, via the CSGC, as circumstances change, as monitoring frequencies may then change as well. The frequency of monitoring is calculated for a 12-month period and is prorated for the project duration. Note that, in the CSGC, the frequency of monitoring displayed indicates the number of monitors to be conducted for the entire duration of the project.

  Red Red Red Yellow Yellow Yellow Red Red Red
Risk Score 81-100 71-80 61-70 51-60 41-50 31-40 21-30 11-20 0-10
Type 1: reports 12 12 12 4 4 4 4 4 4
Type 2: results 4 3 3 2 1 1 1 1 1
Type 1: reports 3 3 3 2 2 2 1 1 1
Type: Reports
  • The review and processing of claim forms and activity reports submitted by the organization.
  • CSGC calculates the number of claims/reports submitted and processed, and records this information as part of the monitoring plan.
  • Type 1 monitors are completed based on the current payment frequency
Type 2: In- depth
  • Thorough monitoring and in-depth review of the project finances and activities. For financial monitoring, an in-depth analysis of financial transactions is required. The activity and the financial monitoring can be done separately.
  • More in-depth, than Type 1, review of finances and activities.
  • Must be accompanied by substantiating documentation for period under review (e.g. invoices, receipts, detailed breakdown of activities).
  • May be either paper-based or conducted on site.
  • Findings of both the financial and activity monitors must be recorded in the CSGC.
Type 3: Results

This type of monitoring answers the following four sets of questions:

  • Is the project on track? Is it achieving, or on its way to achieving, the expected results as described in the agreement? Is the initial plan (activities, resources, milestones and timelines) still valid?
  • Are there any issues that could jeopardize project success (i.e. issues that could affect the anticipated results of the project)?
  • How does, or will, the project contribute to the overall program objective or outcomes?
  • List any outputs or results achieved to date.

Type 1 monitoring follows the normal route of reviewing, approving and processing claim forms and activity reports; completion status of the number of Type 1 monitors recommended by the CSGC does not hinder project advancement through the system.
