Completion of Type 2 monitors is mandatory in order to allow the project to advance through the CSGC. Completion of Type 2 monitors includes the monitoring and recording of both project activities and finances. All Type 2 ’Bring Forwards’ items must be completed before the project can be closed.

Type 3 monitoring does not affect project advancement through the CSGC. These results reviews contribute to our knowledge of overall project and program effectiveness, and contribute to departmental planning cycles.

Type 1: Review of Financial and Activity Reports

The review and processing of organization claim forms and activity reports is considered a monitoring action; the CSGC calculates the number of claims and reports submitted and processed, and records this information as an integral part of the monitoring plan.

The frequency of Type 1 monitoring reflects the project payment method, whether monthly or quarterly.

Although claim forms are processed using the CSGC, program delivery staff must confirm that project activities have also been reviewed. Type 1 monitoring must, therefore, include the review of both expenditures and activities, although these functions can be completed by two separate program delivery staff members.

Due diligence should be applied when approving claims for payment under section 34 of the Financial Administration Act. Project expenditures need to be monitored sufficiently to ensure this due diligence while continuing to balance accountability with flexibility.

Under normal circumstances, additional financial documentation for Type 1 monitors should not be requested. If additional, substantiating documentation is required in order to verify the financial or activity portion of the claim, one has now moved into a Type 2 monitor.

Certain financial arrangements represent higher risks within a project, hence, claims review, as part of Type 1 monitoring, and should pay particular attention when these are at play. These include contracting (for goods or services), travel, hospitality, honoraria (where applicable) and all third-party arrangements or sub-contracts.

Type 2: In-depth Review of Expenditures and Activities

Type 2 monitoring is an in-depth review of both project activities and finances, whether done on or off site. Greater attention should be focused on financial transactions than during type 1 monitors.

Activity monitoring involves a thorough review of: the progress of agreement activities; timelines; and, milestones.

Financial monitoring involves a thorough review of financial transactions, including supporting documentation such as the general ledger or other source documents (detailed list of expenditures, invoices, receipts, cheques, etc.) On-site reviews are based on viewing original documentation, whereas off-site, paper-based monitoring requires the organization provide copies of supporting documents.

Although on-site monitoring is not mandatory, a minimum number is strongly recommended.

Certain program activities—such as those that are new or experimental, or involve multiple partners—can be riskier than others. Yet even the lowest risk projects require one to identify the most significant areas of potential risk and then concentrate monitoring efforts on those areas. For example, when an organization has demonstrated strong bookkeeping and financial reporting skills but has no experience with project activities, one should focus monitoring and the mitigation strategy on assuring the successful completion of project activities, and minimize the resources focused on financial monitoring.

Where additional mitigation strategies are implemented to minimize potential project risks, one needs to ensure they are adequate and properly documented.

Type 3: Results Review

The RAMM approach to monitoring requires HRSDC officials to plan, track and record the results review independently of other kinds of monitors. Some of the information obtained during type 1 and type 2 monitors may also contribute to type 3 monitors.

Essentially, type 3 monitoring looks again at why HRSDC funded the project and if desired results are being achieved. In other words, it moves away from project details in order to focus on the bigger picture.

The information captured during type 3 monitoring looks at the impact of activities. It verifies that the project is on track to achieve the overall expected results identified in the agreement and contributes to the objectives of the program; in other words, it tells the performance story. It does this by:

  • evaluating overall project status;
  • identifying the impact of project intervention on the individual participant, organization, sector, industry, region, etc.; and,
  • identifying any issues that may affect overall progress and success, such as timelines, resources, activities and milestones.

Type 3 monitoring does not necessarily involve an on-site visit; one can complete the results review by analysing activity and monitoring reports and correspondence with organizations.

Whatever approach is taken, one should document answers to the following questions:

  • Is the project on track? Is it achieving, or on its way to achieving, the expected results set out in the agreement? Is the initial plan (activities, resources, milestones and timelines) still valid?
  • Are there any issues that could jeopardize project success (i.e. issues that could affect the anticipated results of the project)?
  • How does, or will, the project contribute to the overall program objective or outcomes?
  • List any outputs or results achieved to date.

Ultimately, results monitoring should reflect the program terms and conditions as well as the objectives and intended outcomes for the particular project and program. Expected results and outcomes need to be clearly articulated in the project agreement in order to facilitate the task of monitoring.

The RAMM Monitoring Schedule using Targeted RAMM Factors (projects entered into the CSGC on or after December 15th, 2012).

As of December 15th, 2012, (as detailed in Chapter 6), the frequency of each type of monitoring, whether financial, activity, or results, is determined based on different pre-set combinations of five RAMM factors that are relevant to that monitoring type.

Program delivery staff assess the 10 RAMM factors, justify the risk level selected and save their assessment. The frequency of monitoring is then system generated and is displayed on the Monitoring Summary screen.

Monitoring Types Frequency of Monitoring
Low (0-15) Medium (16-30) High (31-50)
Financial Once during the life of the project Annual Semi-annual
Activity Annual Semi-annual Quarterly
Result Semi-annual Quarterly Quarterly

The frequency of monitoring is calculated for a 12-month period (based on the start date of the project) and is prorated for the project duration.

Note that in the CSGC the frequency of monitoring displayed indicates the number of monitors to be conducted for the entire duration of the project. It is the responsibility of program delivery staff to ensure that monitoring occurs at the determined frequency (based on the above table).

Semi-annual is defined as ’twice a year’ (year being defined as a 12 month period based on the start date of the project).

Quarterly is defined as a three-month period.

It is the responsibility of program delivery staff to plan monitoring according to the frequency established in the table above.

It is the responsibility of program delivery staff to familiarize themselves with the determined frequency (annually, semi-annually or quarterly).

Example:

A project has a start date of February 20th, 2013 and an end date of June 19th, 2014 (duration of 16 months). The project risk level is medium for all three monitoring types. The number of monitors displayed in the CSGC will be as follows:

Monitoring Types Frequency of Monitoring
Low (0-15) Medium (16-30) High (31-50)
Financial 0 2 0
Activity 0 3 0
Result 0 6 0

Program delivery staff are required to conduct and complete 2 financial monitors during the lifetime of the project:

  • one between February 2013 and February 2014; and,
  • one between March 2014 and June 2014.

Program delivery staff are required to conduct and complete 3 activity monitors during the lifetime of the project, on a semi-annual basis:

  • one during the period of February 2013 to July 2013;
  • one for the period of August 2013 to January 2014; and,
  • one during the period of February 2014 and June 2014.

Program delivery staff are required to conduct and complete 6 results monitors during the lifetime of the project, on a quarterly basis:

  • one during the period of February 20th, 2013 to May 20th, 2013;
  • one during the period of May 21st, 2013 to August 20th, 2013 ;
  • one during the period of August 21st, 2013 to November 20th, 2013;
  • one during the period of November 21st, 2013 to February 20th, 2014;
  • one during the period of February 21st, 2014 to May 20th, 2014; and,
  • one during the period of May 21st, 2014 to June 19th, 2014.

Considerations:

When conducting a monitor, program delivery staff may decide to focus on only one monitor type as number of monitors per type varies. For example, in the case of the project mentioned above, three activity monitors will be conducted during the lifetime of the project, but only two financial monitors will be conducted for the same project, meaning at least one activity monitor will be conducted on its own.

Low Financial Risk – If a low financial risk project has a duration of one year or less, the financial monitor should be done approximately ¾ into the project. The first month should be reviewed randomly for all cost categories to verify that no expenses were incurred prior to the start date, and to identify the expenditures that are claimed to a specific line item. Review randomly the cost categories that can be contentious (e.g. capital costs, direct costs, etc.). If the project has a low financial risk and is more than one year in duration, then the financial monitor can be conducted mid-way or ¾ way through the project with a consideration to the first month of the agreement as explained above.

Medium Financial Risk – When the monitor is conducted will depend upon the duration of the agreement. In the first year, the monitor can be conducted shortly after the first quarter or, at the latest, by the mid-year point, in order to ensure that the organization has understood the requirements which were discussed during the initial visit. If issues exist, mitigation strategies could then be put into place at that time. Again, the first month should be reviewed to verify that no expenses were incurred prior to the start date, and then following periods reviewed randomly thereafter on an annual basis. It is suggested that all invoices and expenses for the first month of the agreement be reviewed.

High Financial Risk – The monitor must be conducted by the mid-year point (6 months) in order to verify that the organization has understood the requirements which were discussed during the initial contact. Again, the first month should be reviewed to verify that no expenses were incurred prior to the start date, and then following periods reviewed randomly thereafter on a semi-annual basis. It is suggested that all invoices and expenses for the first month of the agreement be reviewed.

Monitoring Tools for all Types of Risk Based Approaches (based on RAMM overall score or based on scores of pre-determined combinations of RAMM factors)

As one prepares to conduct a financial, activity or result monitor, the appropriate training, tools and documentation will be required.

Key to this task are the agreement, observations on the part of program delivery staff, a basic knowledge of accounting principles, and a thorough understanding of the program’s terms and conditions and operational guidelines.

One should have the following items when conducting a monitor :

  • a copy of the project agreement and its schedules, and the project's forecast of project expenditures;
  • copies of any financial records and activity reports relating to the agreement that have been received from the organization;
  • any previous claim forms submitted;
  • other documents related to project activities, such as annual reports, conference reports, magazine articles, records of discussions/decisions, and participant feedback,;
  • a calculator; and,
  • a copy of the On-Site Monitoring Report (or a program’s equivalent form), which documents the results of a monitor. Part A is used to document activity monitoring. Part B focuses primarily on a review of financial records and administrative systems.

Monitoring may take place either on or off the organization’s premises. The frequency and type of monitoring need to strike a balance between the nature of the risks involved, and the resources available. For example, an off-site monitoring may be more appropriate for high-risk projects located in remote areas.

On- or off-site monitoring can be applied to:

  • project activities;
  • project expenditures and financial records; and,
  • project results.
Off-site Monitoring

Off-site monitors are less expensive and a more convenient way to conduct either activity, financial or result monitors. They are usually an adequate approach to monitoring lower-risk projects where the organization has a good track record, and no significant problems are foreseen. That said, they are often used in combination with on- site monitoring.

There are two main types of off-site monitoring:

  1. a paper-based review; and,
  2. direct contact monitor.

All off-site monitors should be scheduled, and completed, during the life of the agreement.

If any issues were identified during the monitoring, program delivery staff must return to the RAMM tool and re-assess the RAMM factors and, if applicable, update the information (in the justification boxes), as updated information may affect the risk assessment and, consequently, the frequency of monitoring. If any changes are made to the RAMM tool (risk levels and/or justifications) the program delivery staff needs to save the updated information. The supervisory staff is responsible to ensure that a re- assessment of the RAMM factors and their justifications have been completed by the program delivery staff.

Paper-based Review

To conduct a paper-based or file documentation review for a financial monitor:

  • Select a claim period, preferably early in the life of the agreement;
  • Review the claim form to verify that expenditures relate directly to activities as described in the activity report;
  • Select one or more cost categories and request the substantiating documentation, such as invoices or payroll records, for expenditures claimed under these cost categories. Note that administrative costs subject to flat rate (under cost category Set A – Opportunities Fund for Persons with Disabilities {OF} and Skills Link are not monitored);
  • Based on a review of supporting documentation, determine whether the amounts claimed in the selected cost categories are eligible under the agreement;
  • Follow up on any discrepancies by contacting the organization to seek clarification:
    • when discrepancies are found, request substantiating documentation until sufficient information has been provided to determine that the organization has addressed the problem; and,
  • Document the findings of the paper-based review exercise, and all relevant notes, in the project file and in the CSGC using the Record Monitoring Details screen.

To conduct a paper-based or file documentation review for an activity monitoring;

  • Review the activity reports accompanying the claim forms, notes to files, correspondence with the organization, etc. and answer the following questions:
    • Are project activities as described in the agreement?
    • Are activities progressing in accordance with the agreement?
    • Have milestones, timelines and deliverables been met for the specific period being monitored?
    • Has there been any amendments to the agreement? Is there a need to modify the agreement to reflect the changes in activities, milestones or timelines?
    • Have any partnership commitments been achieved?
    • Have any project staff members or participants left the project since the last monitor or project start date? If so, why? Have they been replaced? Have any additional project employees been hired since the last monitor or project start date?
  • Follow up on any discrepancies by contacting the organization to seek clarification:
    • When discrepancies are found, request substantiating documentation until sufficient information has been provided to address the problem; and,
  • Document the findings of the paper-based review exercise, and all relevant notes, in the project file and in the CSGC using the Record Monitoring Details screen

To conduct a paper-based or file documentation review for a results monitoring:

  • Review the activity reports accompanying the claim forms, notes to files, correspondence with the organization, documents received, etc. and answer the following questions:
    • Is the project on track? Is it achieving or on its way to achieve the expected results set out in the contribution agreement?
    • Are there any results related issues that could jeopardize the success of the project?
    • How does or will this project contribute to the overall program objectives/outcome(s)? (Contribution to the program)
  • List any outputs and/or results achieved to date.
  • Follow up on any discrepancies by contacting the organization to seek clarification:
    • When discrepancies are found, request substantiating documentation until sufficient information has been provided to address the problem.
  • Document the findings of the paper-based review exercise, and all relevant notes, in the project file and in the CSGC using the Record Monitoring Details screen.
Direct Contact Monitor

Every form of communication can help ensure project activities are achieving expected outcomes and to address promptly any issues that may jeopardize the success of a project. All communication with the organization and other key players should be documented as ‘notes to file’ in the CSGC.

  • Electronic communication: Copies of all correspondence, including e-mails, written correspondence, and faxes, should be kept on file either in the document location of the CSGC or in the paper file.
  • Correspondence: Any written correspondence between HRSDC and the organization can be used to track progress on project activities.
  • Phone contact: This gives one an opportunity to explain and clarify written information, as well as to verify observations made during an on-site visit.
  • Teleconferencing or video teleconferencing: These are effective tools for holding distance meetings that involve groups from both inside and outside of the Department when both parties have access to the necessary technology.

To conduct a direct contact monitor:

  • Select a claim period, preferably following a paper-based, or file documentation, review;
  • Contact the organization to discuss the project’s progress and ask the following questions:
    • How are project activities proceeding relative to what is outlined in the agreement?
    • What milestones or deliverables have been met during this period, as described in the agreement?
    • What partnership commitments have been realized?
    • Have any project staff members or participants left since the last monitor or project start date? If so, why? Have any new employees been replaced? If so, why? Have any additional project employees been hired since the last monitor or project start date?
    • Are there any difficulties with the project? Can they be described? What might be some possible solutions?;
  • Contact participants to determine whether their needs, as described in the agreement, are being met;
  • Communicate with project partners and stakeholders to verify that project activities are proceeding as planned;
  • Request substantiating documentation from the organization, for some or for all cost categories, including copies of invoices, financial records, reports and deliverables for the selected claim period. Note that administrative costs subject to flat rate (under cost category Set A – Opportunities Fund for Persons with Disabilities {OF} and Skills Link) are not monitored;
  • Based on a review of the supporting documentation, determine whether the amounts claimed are eligible under the agreement and directly relate to project activities;
  • Follow up on any discrepancies by contacting the organization to seek clarification;
  • When discrepancies have been found, request substantiating documentation until there is evidence that the organization has addressed the problem. Depending upon the type of discrepancy found and its resolution, one may decide to adjust the RAMM assessment to determine a revised monitoring strategy in order to address a higher level of risk; and,
  • Document the direct contact monitor in the project file and the CSGC using the Record Monitoring Details screen.
On-site Monitor

On-site monitoring consists of face-to-face meetings with the organization and others— the bookkeeper, project staff, project participants, etc.—on the premises where their financial records are kept and project activities held. It is generally associated with higher-risk agreements and may involve:

  • a direct review of the organization’s financial records;
  • a visit to project locations; or,
  • interviews with project participants (if applicable).

On-site monitoring has the advantage of personal contact with the organization and makes it easy to observe the project first-hand, meet with other key players and evaluate the consistency of information gathered from written reports and other contacts. All on- site monitors should be scheduled, and completed, during the life of the agreement.

The monitoring visit itself is, of course, the focal activity and requires careful preparation.

When conducting an on-site financial or activity monitor, one should :

  • verify that activities undertaken correspond to those in the agreement;
  • verify that all organization documentation received, such as financial and activity reports, correspond with documentation on the organization's premises;
  • verify that all cash and in-kind contributions have been verified and that supporting documentation is on file. Organizations should demonstrate that partners have submitted both the cash and in-kind contribution amounts for the time period being monitored. Organizations are held accountable to track and, at the end of the project, report on all contributions received from other sources; and,
  • complete the detailed checklists on the On-site Monitoring Report form (or the program’s equivalent form), noting any issues of concern, and possible follow-up action, such as subsequent visits or off-site monitoring. Enter these details into the CSGC Record Monitoring Details screen.

While most on-site monitoring is planned in advance, the schedule should be flexible enough to include spontaneous monitoring, particularly when there are performance concerns or discrepancies between what is reported and results from previous visits.

On-site monitoring can be time-consuming; it also doesn't allow for continuity and communication between visits. For that reason, when planning the monitoring schedule, ensure projects are adequately monitored based on the level of risk and that on-site and off-site monitors are used appropriately.

Monitoring Visits

The number of monitors is generated by the CSGC through the risk assessment. Although one may want to concentrate on a single aspect (activities, finances or results), other issues might come to light that could either be delved into immediately or at a later date.

When planning a project’s monitoring visits, verify that, over the life of the agreement, finances, activities and results are reviewed.

To plan a monitoring visit, one should:

  • initiate the visit;
  • prepare for the visit; and,
  • confirm arrangements.

Once on site, one should take specific steps when undertaking an:

  • activity monitor;
  • financial monitor; and
  • result monitor

If any issues were identified during the monitoring, program delivery staff must return to the RAMM tool and re-assess the RAMM factors and, if applicable, update the information (in the justification boxes), as updated information may affect the risk assessment and, consequently, the frequency of monitoring. If any changes are made to the RAMM tool (risk levels and/or justifications) the program delivery staff needs to save the updated information. The supervisory staff is responsible to ensure that a re- assessment of the RAMM factors and their justifications have been completed by the program delivery staff.

Initiating the Visit

Before contacting the organization to set up the monitoring visit, one should take the following steps:

  • Clearly define the purpose of the monitor. For example: the purpose of this visit is to review activities conducted during a claim period and verify amounts shown on the claim.
  • Establish the monitoring period, if applicable.
  • Assess the environment in which the monitor will be conducted. This assessment may identify key areas to investigate, such as previously identified trouble spots. Consider:
    • organization willingness to cooperate and disclose information;
    • how project administrative files are kept (are they organized or scattered throughout the office?);
    • organization willingness to allow the interviewing of participants and personnel;
    • openness of the organization to allow for the observation of a training session for the clients; and,
    • whether the organization keeps appointments.
  • Decide whether this will be:
    • A planned visit, which is most often the case. Advise the organization ahead of time, stating the purpose of the visit and the information they must have ready for review. Ensure the project coordinator and bookkeeper will be available to explain their accounting procedures so that the accounts and expenditures can be verified.
    • A spontaneous visit: There may be times when a spontaneous visit is more appropriate. For example: if reports are received indicating that something is going wrong or there is no evidence of work being done, a surprise visit may offer a more clear understanding these concerns.
Preparing for the Visit

In the days leading up to a meeting with the organization, one should:

  • review the agreement, previous claims, activity reports and, if applicable,participant information;
  • develop a clear understanding of the agreement;
  • prepare questions to ask based on information already in the project file such asclaim forms, activity reports, etc.;
  • review previous monitoring reports to identify any specific areas for follow-up;
  • ascertain what has to be accomplished during the visit (measuring successindicators, financial and activity indicators, reviewing the agreement,amendments, etc.);
  • prioritize the work hoped to be accomplished during the visit;
  • decide how to conduct the visit -- who should be interviewed? What questionsshould be asked? What records should be verified;
  • identify key contacts within the organization and ensure their availability(bookkeeper, project manager, etc.);
  • remind the organization of the upcoming visit and request any supportingdocumentation that is needed ahead of time to ensure it is ready for review uponarrival; and,
  • collect the documents and equipment required for the meeting (copy of theagreement, last claim form, calculator, on-site monitoring report, etc.).
Confirming Arrangements

Just before the visit, one should:

  • confirm the appointment with the organization, ensuring that all staff,documentation and participants will be available; and,
  • verify the length of the visit, allowing enough time to talk informally with theorganization, participants (if appropriate) and project staff.
Interim Visit

Once the project is underway, ongoing monitoring activities take place according to the monitoring schedule, which is based on risk assessment results. Where the initial visit (not considered a monitor) verifies all necessary financial and organizational supports are in place, interim visits follow up on project activities and results, and monitor finances to verify expenditures.

In conjunction with other monitoring activities, interim monitoring visits should address the following questions:

  • Are activities consistent with the agreement? Which activities are progressing particularly well?
  • Which activities are not progressing as well and appear to be problematic?
  • How are participants progressing (if applicable)? Is project administration—office and financial procedures—sufficient for the project?
Activity Monitor

Activity monitoring addresses:

  • project objectives and outcomes to answer the question “What’s going on?” using bothqualitative and quantitative information;
  • activity progress and milestones to ensure that activities are being carried out asdescribed in the funding agreement; and,
  • participant progress (if applicable) to assess the quality of participantdevelopment.

On-site activity monitoring involves the following steps:

  1. Interview the organization and key project staff (such as the project coordinator).State the purpose of the visit, ask for a detailed description of project activities to dateand answer the following questions:
    • Are project activities in line with those described in the agreement?
    • Did any activities occur prior to the agreement start date?
    • Are activities progressing as per the agreement?
    • Which deliverables (e.g. processes, tools, training, best practices, guides) havebeen completed by this point in the project?
    • Have any issues arisen to date?
    • Are any amendments to the agreement required?
    • Is there appropriate HRSDC visibility?
    • Have partnership commitments been realized?
    • Have new employees been hired since the last monitor or project start-up?
    • Have any employees been replaced? If so, why?
  2. Interview participants, if applicable, to confirm activities have taken place andprogress is being made. Ask the following questions:
    • Are participants aware of other HRSDC services websites or services offered?Are these appropriate for participants?
    • Is each participant aware of, and following, the applicable work activities,development or personal action plan?
    • Are they being properly supervised?
    • Are there any safety concerns?
    • Are they receiving income support?
    • Have they been receiving their cheques on time?
  3. Visit project premises to ensure they are appropriate for project activities and thatadequate safety measures and equipment are in place.
  4. Observe participants during activities and verify that they are performing these asspecified in the funding agreement.
  5. Discuss participant progress with project staff.
  6. Ask for any evidence that activities have taken place, including meeting minutes,conference reports, workshop agendas, etc.
Financial Monitor

Financial monitoring verifies that:

  • bookkeeping systems and accounting practices are in place to manage and controlHRSDC funds; and,
  • the money is being spent as outlined within the funding agreement.

Project expenditures should be monitored once, as a minimum, during the life of the agreement, and more often, if warranted by the assessed risk level. The importance and frequency of financial monitoring increases as the level of risk increases.

Once it is felt that a complete understanding of an organization’s bookkeeping systems and accounting practices has been attained, one is ready to undertake the financial monitor itself.

Final or Close-out Contact

A final or close-out contact is the opportunity to address any outstanding matters that should be resolved prior to the conclusion of the project. One should also remind the organization to submit a close-out activity report and final claim form, while informing them of when the report is due and how it should be completed. One of the monitoring activities identified in the monitoring plan (CSGC monitoring summary) may be considered the final or close-out monitoring if it is conducted and completed during the life of the agreement.

Given individual project circumstances and program capacity and resources, a final visit may not be practical or warranted. In cases where a final visit is possible or necessary, which activities remain incomplete and how quickly the file can be closed can be established.

Prior to this final contact, program delivery staff should:

  • review the agreement, amendments (if applicable), monitoring reports and notes to file;
  • if warranted, do a monitor using the On-site Financial Monitoring Report Form (or the program’s equivalent form); and,
  • complete the Final Close-out Summary Form (or the program’s equivalent form) to document findings, comments and recommendations; in particular, note any anomalies or difficulties the organization encountered during the project’s life cycle and how they resolved them.

Final contact should verify:

  • all follow-up issues and outstanding matters have been settled satisfactorily;
  • agreement activities have been completed and objectives met;
  • all expenditures were related to contracted activities within the specified project duration (note that organizations may be allowed to incur administrative costs that may not be directly related to the project but are necessary for the organization to function effectively as a whole {cost category Set B});
  • financial records are up-to-date and complete;
  • all remittances and participant-related documentation are in order (e.g. Receiver General remittances, vacation pay, Records of Employment {ROE} completed, T4s or T4As in process);
  • capital assets have been dealt with as per the agreement;
  • storage of records and files has been arranged;
  • the final report regarding project results is on file; and,
  • where the project is related to work experience, the number of successful participants is confirmed, follow-up questionnaires have been completed and outcomes recorded in the CSGC.

10.2 Understanding the Organization's Administrative Processes

The many and varied accounting and financial systems used by organizations to manage agreement funds can easily take the monitoring of certain types of projects well beyond the expertise of most program delivery staff. When such complex accounting practices are encountered, ask project organizations to explain their accounting procedures by adopting a "show me" attitude to verify accounts and expenditures. If difficulty is encountered in understanding the financial information they provide, get help from someone with an accounting background (a co-worker or finance officer). One may even wish to bring them along if one is performing a financial monitor on site.

While accounting credentials are not required to do a financial monitor, a basic knowledge of accounting will help complete this assignment. First, learn to distinguish between the concepts of bookkeeping and accounting. While bookkeeping is the recording of transactions, accounting includes the design of accounting management and control, the preparation of financial statements, and the analysis and interpretation of accounting information as an aid to making business decisions. The purpose of accounting is to provide financial information about any economic entity, in this case the project. It extends beyond creating records and reports to realizing the ultimate objective of being able to use, analyze and interpret the information gathered. Organizations must demonstrate both adequate bookkeeping and accounting practices.

Within this context, as the person conducting the financial monitor, program delivery staff should, therefore, understand:

  • Canadian and international accounting standards (that is appropriate to the magnitude of the project);
  • what constitutes a good record-keeping system;
  • the purpose of internal control systems; and,
  • how to assess the quality of these systems.

Together, these four elements ensure accurate recording, summarizing, reporting and interpretation of financial information. If one is not yet familiar with the organization's accounting, payroll and other administrative procedures when setting out to do a financial monitor visit, ask the organization or bookkeeper to describe:

  • how they manage funds;
  • what accounting procedures and systems they use;
  • how payments are authorized and by whom;
  • who has the authority to spend funds; and,
  • what the procedures are for signing cheques.

The following sections describe the attributes of sound bookkeeping and accounting practices:

  • record-keeping systems
  • internal control systems
  • general ledger
  • petty cash
  • cheque register

For organizations who do not have access to an accounting system (whether manual or computerized), one can offer them sample accounting forms to help them keep adequate financial records, including the receipts and disbursement record form, payroll record form, and calculation of monthly remittances form. Noted that the use of such sample accounting forms is by no means mandatory and should only be offered to organizations as a resource.

Canadian and International Accounting Standards

HRSDC program delivery staff should have a basic understanding of two important accounting models:

  • the current use of Canadian Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP)
  • the recent introduction of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).

While not specific to the Department, they are both highly influential within the organizations that HRSDC deals with on a daily basis, guiding the setup and administration of their financial systems.

For more information and resources on both, see the Canadian Accounting Standards Board and the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants (CICA).

Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP)

HRSDC program delivery staff should develop an understanding of the Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) used in Canada to support their examination of an organization's accounting practices when monitoring individual projects, as well as efforts to track monitoring across entire programs. These rules or standards support the integrity of financial information and the ability to compare current financial reports to prior period reports, and the reports of other businesses and organizations. The accounting profession has adopted these principles as guidelines for maintaining financial accounts and producing financial reports.

Starting in 2011, all publicly-traded companies and financial institutions will have to apply the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) in lieu of the GAAP. While governments, not-for-profit and private organizations are not required to implement IFRS in their accounting systems, they may elect to do so for the benefit of their stakeholders.

In short, GAAP practices are founded upon the following principles:

  • The business entity principle considers how the reader will interpret information concerning the entity contained in the report. Accountants sometimes prepare consolidated reports for a corporation that has many divisions. Each division, however, may also generate reports when they are operated as distinct profit centres.
  • The continuity or going-concern principle implies the business will continue to exist long enough to carry out preset plans and meet contractual commitments.
  • The monetary principle assumes the unit of measurement is money and that, in Canada, that unit of measurement is the Canadian dollar unless otherwise noted.
  • The time-period principle: Although accounting periods can be as short as one month or one quarter, the normal accounting period is one “fiscal” year that begins on a given day and ends 12 months later. When two or more financial reports are compared, one must, therefore, ensure that they entail comparable time periods.
  • The cost principle: When the transaction is recorded, the associated cost usually represents the fair market value of the goods or services as stated on the receipt or agreement. With the passage of time, the economic value of an asset may change greatly, particularly in periods of inflation. The cost principle, however, requires that the historical cost (rather than a later "fair market value" cost) continue to serve as the basis for values in financial statements.
  • The revenue principle: For any given period, revenue refers to the monies collected as cash or receivables from sales or other means during that period. Revenue is recorded when the sale is made, not when the goods are manufactured.
  • The matching principle states that the costs associated with revenue realized during a given period must be recorded in that same period. For organizations with a funding agreement, this means they must report and claim the interest revenue earned on HRSDC's contribution for the period in which it was earned, not the period in which it was received. The costs incurred to earn the interest revenue would be matched in the same period.
  • The objectivity principle: As much as possible, accounting should be based on objective evidence, such as verifiable invoices and contracts. The term "verify" indicates to prove something by examination of the evidence or underlying facts.
  • The consistency principle: An organization’s annual financial reports must be comparable from one period to another in order to identify trends. For this comparison to be useful, accounting principles must be applied consistently from one period to another and changes noted in financial statements.
  • The disclosure principle requires that financial statements include all information necessary to provide a fair presentation of an organization’s financial position. The concept of financial disclosure applies not only to transactions that occur during the reported period, but also to additional information that affects the business (e.g. a legal proceeding). When an organization’s financial statements are monitored, therefore, make sure to also review all accompanying notes as well as the financial data.

If it is found during a monitor that all of these functions are performed by the same individual within an organization, the internal controls should be more closely examined and the project may require more in-depth monitoring.

International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)

Starting in 2011, all publicly-traded companies and financial institutions in Canada will have to apply the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) instead of the Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). While governments, not-for-profit and private organizations are not required to implement IFRS in their accounting systems, they may elect to do so for the benefit of their stakeholders.

If HRSDC enters into agreements with companies or organizations using the IFRS, some knowledge of these standards will, therefore, be required to do financial monitoring.

Essentially, the IFRS is a collection of international accounting standards that promotes the reporting of transparent, comparable information in financial statements. Although not identical to the Canadian GAAP, these new standards are based on a similar conceptual framework. Adoption of the globally-accepted IFRS system will, ideally, increase access to world-wide capital markets for Canadian businesses, streamline international accounting practices and, thus, enhance the clarity and comparability of financial information around the world.

For more information on the IFRS as industry prepares for their adoption, see the IFRS section of the Canadian Institute for Chartered Accountants website.

Record-keeping Systems

Record-keeping systems are the ways in which organizations track their financial activities; during a financial monitor, program delivery staff are required to examine the quality of this system.

While they vary from organization to organization, good record-keeping systems are:

  • Clear: If accounting information is to be useful, it must be presented in terms that are understandable to the user. Sometimes, however, the complex nature of the business prevents simple reporting. In such situations, one should ask the organization to explain how a transaction is recorded, then track an expense through the stages of receipt, to payment, to its resulting financial statement.
  • Verifiable: If accounting information is verifiable, any person can find evidence of the transaction. For example, to verify the number of employees in a given project, view payroll records, transactions of salaries paid, and deductions to individuals reported as part of the project.
  • Up to date: Since the basic reason for developing accounting information is to use it in making decisions, this information must be recorded in a timely fashion to help the user determine forecast of project expenditures requirements, assess variance from budget, and measure outcomes against financial resources.
  • Consistent: Consistency is key to ensuring financial reports are comparable from one reporting period to another (i.e. they must use the same eligible cost category each time an expense is recorded). Similarities and differences appearing in the financial statements must, therefore, reflect basic conditions in the organization and not merely differences in the accounting treatment.
  • Complete: Financial reporting must include all financial transactions and information; this is often referred to as "full disclosure". Complete financial information and its full disclosure facilitate understanding and avoid misleading implications.
Internal Control Systems

Program delivery staff are required to examine the organization's system of internal control, or measures they take to:

  • protect resources against waste, fraud and inefficiency;
  • ensure accuracy and reliability in accounting and reporting data;
  • guarantee compliance with the funding agreement and other HRSDC requirements; and,
  • evaluate project performance.

A good system of internal control will ensure that no one person handles all phases of a transaction from beginning to end.

To check the effectiveness of an organization’s internal control system, review the process for purchasing project goods and services by asking the following questions:

  • Who recommends purchases, approves and signs purchase orders, etc.?
  • How many signatures are required on cheques?
  • Who reviews and signs claim forms?
General Ledger

The general ledger is a record or book that includes all of the different asset, liability, revenue and expense accounts listed in the chart of accounts. Every once in a while—but usually within predetermined time frames—all entries from the general journal (a chronological record of all transactions) are transferred or "posted" into the general ledger.

Unlike the general journal, the general ledger is set up using the chart of accounts with each account having a debit, credit and balance column. The balance column keeps an up-to-date balance of each separate account when posted.

An organization can use the general ledger to produce useful financial reports such as a trial balance, an income statement, a balance sheet and other financial statements. The information contained within the general ledger also assists the organization in filling out the claim form required by the Department.

Petty Cash

Petty cash is money kept on hand or in a special bank account as a convenient way to make small payments. If the organization uses petty cash as a method of reimbursing expenses, all petty cash transactions must be clearly documented and supported by appropriate receipts or vouchers.

These receipts should be listed in the petty cash register and include the:

  • date of purchase;
  • name of the vendor;
  • description of the item;
  • amount paid;
  • chart of account name and number for the disbursement(s);
  • GST amount; and,
  • balance remaining in the petty cash fund.

All receipts should be filed in support of any cheques issued to reimburse the petty cash fund, and the petty cash register must be updated and documented accordingly. The register should be signed and dated by any person receiving a cash disbursement. At any given time, the total of receipts and vouchers, plus the cash on hand, must equal the original amount of the petty cash fund.

Cheque Register

Program delivery staff should encourage organizations to use a cheque register to record all issued cheques and thus assist in the project's record keeping. It is good practice to use cheques that are pre-numbered by the bank. If the organization's financial systems are automated, they may produce cheques automatically, but this does not negate any alternate processes.

Cheques should be entered sequentially in the cheque register. Any missing numbered cheques should be accounted for and the appropriate cheque stub with the signature(s) attached to the register.

10.3 Undertaking a Financial Monitor

Essentially, the role of program delivery staff in carrying out a financial monitor is to ensure that:

  • all expenditures are eligible, given the project's objectives, and in accordance with the clauses of the agreement;
  • the amount paid is reasonable;
  • the item exists or the service has been performed; and,
  • the purchase is supported by appropriate documentation. To conduct a financial monitor, one can take the following steps:
    • Become familiar with the financial requirements outlined in the agreement, reviewing which cost category set the projects falls under, and reviewing financial information sources such as the:
      • chart of accounts;
      • accounts payable and receivable records;
      • bank statements and cancelled cheques; o claim form(s);
      • general ledger and sub-ledger;
      • cheque register;
      • cash receipts and invoices;
      • payroll journals and evidence of support to individuals;
      • Receiver General remittances; and,
      • petty cash records.
  • Verify capital costs and project administrative costs.
  • Use a sampling approach—a test of payroll transactions and non-payroll expenditures—because there is no need to review 100% of the entries or cheques. Generally, start with five of each type of transaction. If concerns or issues arise, increase the sample size. For further information, see Treasury Board Financial Management, Expenditure and Cost Management, Account Verification, Appendix A - Account Verification.
  • If there is an area of concern, review 100% of all expenditures in that area.
  • Check petty cash and cheque stubs first.
  • Choose some entries and books, and track them back to their origin.
  • Select some cheques and track the corresponding invoices and entries.
  • Always ask for bank reconciliations.
  • Investigate any item outstanding on bank reconciliations for more than two months.
  • Compare previous months’ figures to previous months’ claim form(s).
  • Initial all verified documents, as this will provide an audit trail for future reviews.
  • Verify that cheques payable to signing officers are for valid, adequately-supported project expenses.
  • Confirm that there are two or more signing officers for non-profit organizations.
  • Never remove original financial records from the agreement site; if necessary, ask for photocopies of anything required.
  • If one finds expenses that are incorrectly recorded or classified improperly while monitoring a project’s financial records, advise the organization and make a note to file to ensure proper follow-up.

If mistakes or other problems in the financial records of a project are encountered, do not attempt to correct these as this is not the role of program delivery staff. The organization has signed an agreement stating they will maintain the project's financial accounts in proper order; the organization and their bookkeeper must, therefore, learn from the observations of program delivery staff and take corrective action on their own. Ask them about their plans to correct the problems identified and ensure a time is agreed upon for correction so this can be verified as part of the next planned monitor.

During an on-site financial monitor, one can also ask oneself the following questions to ensure the necessary information is gathered:

  1. Were all expenditures incurred after the agreement start date? Look at invoice and purchase order dates.
  2. Was the item purchased necessary to complete project activities? Ask the organization what it is used for and how often it is used. If appropriate, ask for a demonstration. This may not be applicable, depending upon the cost category set used.
  3. Was the purchase cost reasonable? Compare the price paid to the market value for similar products or services.
  4. Did the organization follow guidelines concerning the acquisition and disposal of capital assets? Visually inspect the proof of purchase. Determine if the organization followed agreement provisions when acquiring and disposing of capital assets.
  5. Were the costs incurred within the maximum allowable? Check these against theagreement schedule that details eligible costs.
  6. Are receipts available to verify amounts paid? Ask to see receipts for actual costsincurred for the item that were previously identified.
  7. Are any purchased items located on project premises? Look for and count significantitems (i.e. if the invoice indicates 10 computers were purchased, look for them. Ifthey cannot all be accounted for, ask the organization where they are).
  8. Is the organization keeping accurate, up-to-date records in either a computerized ormanual accounting system? (Most computerized systems post transactionsimmediately while manual systems are usually posted at least twice a month.) Ask theorganization to show how they have kept specific information, such as payrollinformation, attendance records, invoices, etc. Have them describe how they processvarious financial transactions for the project. Confirm the delegated signing authority.Determine whether the organization has retained project financial records separatefrom those of the parent organization, if appropriate.
  9. Is the use and application of funds consistent with agreement provisions?Interview both the organization and participants to learn the status of theiractivities with respect to Schedule A.
Review of Claim Forms

Prior to doing a financial monitor, review the claim form(s) submitted by the organization for the period covered by the monitor and ensure that the total on the claim form is mathematically correct and consistent with the forecast of project expenditures. During the monitor, expenses can then be verified and supported, as necessary, by appropriate documentation such as invoices. Follow the audit trail to monitor expenditures claimed; in practice, this means one should compare the claim form to source documents such as payroll records, invoices, cheques, general ledgers and bank reconciliations. Select and analyze expenditures (consider targeting those items of significant amount) from each of the eligible cost (and sub-costs) categories outlined in the agreement, such as staff wages, capital assets, participant costs and project costs.

Cash Receipts

Some projects receive cash from selling products or services. In these instances, program delivery staff should encourage organizations to keep a register of cash receipts and record all business sales, including those paid by cash or credit. This register or ledger shows the money actually coming in (as opposed to the sales journal which lists all sales, even those where money has not yet been received) and is used to:

  • track all money entering the organization;
  • meet the requirements of revenue-producing projects;
  • record sales and revenues;
  • update accounts receivable records; and,
  • meet Canada Revenue Agency taxation requirements.

One can monitor the cash receipts register to track revenue from other sources. When assessing this:

  • ensure it is up to date;
  • make certain it is done daily or weekly;
  • go through the deposit slips and compare them to the bank statement;
  • review the amount of HRSDC cheques received and recorded on register andcompare this to HRSDC payment records;
  • verify that cheques issued by HRSDC have been recorded and deposited in the correct bank account;
  • confirm that all cash went into the proper account; and,
  • check the dollar value, the date, from whom the money was received, and what it was used to pay for.
Payroll Journals

Payroll is usually the largest expense in HRSDC-funded projects and, therefore, merits particularly close scrutiny during a financial monitor.

A payroll is any system by which the total wages earned by employees and the total deductions made against those wages are recorded for a specified period of employment.

All payroll records should show each employee by:

  • their name and social insurance number;
  • their rate of pay per hour, week or month;
  • the number of regular and overtime hours they worked;
  • their rate of pay for overtime;
  • their gross earnings;
  • any other earnings such as vacation pay, bonuses or commissions;
  • the precise amount of deductions for Canada Pension Plan, income tax, Employment Insurance and mandatory deductions;
  • any other deductions; and,
  • their net pay, which is determined by subtracting all deductions from the gross wage.

Every organization should designate someone other than the person responsible for staffing and supervision to prepare the payroll and payments. If this is not the case, one should be especially prudent when reviewing the project’s financial information.

By reviewing payroll procedures, one can:

  • confirm the right individuals are being paid on time and for wages specified in the agreement;
  • verify wage costs by referring to payroll records, attendance records, the check register and pay stubs;
  • confirm the rate of pay and proper deductions Mandatory Employment-Related Costs (MERCs) for each employee and project participant (if applicable) through a review of payroll records for the claim period;
  • check that participants do, in fact, exist (through activity monitoring, if applicable);
  • cross-reference payroll with attendance records;
  • confirm payment of wages in the cheque register;
  • check pay stubs, if necessary; and,
  • ensure payments are made and posted in a regular and timely manner.

Ask oneself the following questions in order to obtain the information required when completing this aspect of the financial monitor:

  1. Is the payroll processed by the organization or through an external organization such as a bank or an agency?
  2. Are project staff salaries or benefits claimed to the project according to the approved budget?
  3. Are attendance records maintained?
  4. If yes, what kinds of records are maintained?
  5. If no, how does the organization record absences?
  6. How many hours are in a normal work week?
  7. Who certifies the records?
  8. How frequently is certification performed?
  9. How many employees were on the payroll at the time of the visit?
  10. Were any reasons noted for undue absenteeism?
  11. Are TD-1 forms completed and signed by employees under the agreement?
  12. Does the organization provide employees with bonus payments, overtime or other forms of compensation?
  13. How are employees paid (cheque or direct deposit)?
  14. Are the T-4 slips consistent with employee earnings records?
  15. Were T-4 slips prepared for the taxation years covered by the project?
  16. Has vacation pay been paid, taken in time or accumulated for disbursement, for each pay period?
  17. If vacation pay was not paid on every pay cheque, has it been paid to all terminated employees?

More detailed financial monitoring may also involve comparing participant data forms with payroll records for social insurance numbers and endorsement signatures.

When checking payroll records for employees, simply record the employee’s name as it remains the organization's responsibility to ensure that all project employees are legally entitled to work in Canada; HRSDC, therefore, does not require the social insurance numbers of staff members.

Participant Costs

Program delivery staff can consult substantiating documents—the journal, general ledger, cheque register, receipts, disbursement records, invoices, vouchers—and take the following steps to verify participant costs:

  • Confirm that all expenditures have been authorized under the agreement.
  • Ascertain whether they are necessary for project activities.  Make sure that receipts with the correct amounts, dates and names of individuals are available to corroborate each expenditure.
  • Check that the receipts/voucher/invoice amount corresponds to the information listed in the journal of accounts payable, receipts and disbursement records, and that this is the same information found in the cheque register and on the cancelled cheque.

Verify with project participants that they have indeed received the amounts shown on the claim form.

Receiver General Remittances

Receiver General remittances are the amounts that employers pay the federal government, on their own behalf and on behalf of their employees, such as Employment Insurance, CPP/QPP deductions, etc. Check these to verify that the:

  • employer is following correct accounting practices; and,
  • employee will receive the benefits if and when the need arises.

Program delivery staff should confirm that:

  • all remittances to date have been sent out by the 15th of the following month;
  • no penalties incurred by late remittances have been charged to the project because such penalties are the organization’s responsibility;
  • the total for EI plus CPP plus tax deducted from employee's pay is in agreement with the payroll totals for the same period;
  • the correct total by category for CPP and EI was multiplied by the correct factor for the employer's share;
  • the employer's cost is mathematically correct; and,
  • the total remitted amount was correct.

Keep in mind that it may not always be possible to corroborate the above points when monitoring a large organization. Specifically, when there is a large organization payroll involved and the project payroll is only one component of the larger whole, one may only be able to confirm that remittances were calculated correctly on the payroll, and that the organization is submitting overall organizational remittances. If program delivery staff have any concerns in this area, discuss them with colleagues, the manager or a financial officer.

Capital Costs/ Capital Assets

Program delivery staff can consult substantiating documents—the journal, general ledger, cheque register, receipts, disbursement records and invoices—and take the following steps to verify capital costs during a financial monitor:

  • confirm that all capital expenditures have been authorized under the agreement;
  • review invoices to ensure they are properly addressed and dated and include a description of the goods or services;
  • establish that the capital assets listed in the invoices are actually on hand. For example, ask to view the items during the visit. Verify the number of pieces of equipment and, if applicable, their serial numbers; and,
  • check that the purchase amount and supplier who issued the invoice correspond to the information listed in the journal of accounts payable, receipts and disbursement records, and that this is the same information found in the cheque register and on the cancelled cheque.
Project Costs

Program delivery staff can consult substantiating documents—the journal, general ledger, cheque register, receipts, disbursement records, invoices, vouchers—and take the following steps to verify project costs:

  • confirm that all expenditures have been authorized under the agreement;
  • review invoices to ensure they are properly addressed and dated and include a description of the goods or services; and,
  • Check that the purchase amount and supplier information who issued the invoice correspond to the information listed in the journal of accounts payable, receipts and disbursements records, and that this is the same information found on the cheque register and cancelled cheque

Chapter 12. Close-out

Close-out occurs when the project has come to an end and the Department has received and processed the required information. This process determines and documents whether the recipient has:

  • met project objectives;
  • completed project activities; and,
  • achieved expected results.

From a financial administration point-of-view, this phase involves the close-out, in the Common System for Grants and Contributions (CSGC), of an open project after the final claim has been received and accepted as a fair representation of allowable expenses. Once the Department establishes the recipient’s final entitlement to outstanding funds, any unused portion is de-committed (returned to the Department’s budget) and the project closed.

Close-out is also a unique phase in CSGC; please see the Close-out section of the CSGC User Guide for further details.
The funding agreement and project monitoring reports determine which specific tasks must be undertaken before a project and the project file can be closed and archived.

Program delivery staff should remind the recipient, prior to the project end date, of their responsibilities, as described in the agreement. These may include (but are not limited to):

  • submitting the final claim, activity report and supporting documentation (if applicable) within the allocated timeframe following the project end date;
  • submitting final project reporting (providing evidence of completed activities);
  • account for cash and in-kind contributions from the recipient and/or other sources of funding (if applicable);
  • submitting any other reports as per the agreement; and
  • disposing of capital assets as per agreement.

Program delivery staff are, in turn, responsible for:

  • reviewing the final claim, activity report, other reports i.e. final project report, cash and in-kind contributions from other sources and supporting documentation (if applicable);
  • issuing final payment (if applicable);
  • reviewing interest and / or revenues generated by project activities (if applicable);
  • documenting any issues that require follow-up; and
  • informing the recipient of those issues and their timelines to address them.

12.1 Final Project Evaluation

Before one can officially close out a project in CSGC, several tasks must first be completed in order to confirm that the recipient and the Department are ready for this stage.

Evaluation work may begin with a final contact with the recipient, assess project status and discuss any outstanding issues such as the disposal of assets and any overpayment amounts they may owe.

In certain cases, it may be decided that an audit is warranted in order to verify a project’s financial or program compliance.

Final Contact

Given individual project circumstances and program capacity and resources, a final on-site visit may not be practical or warranted.

In cases where a final on-site visit is feasible the final visit can help establish what activities remain incomplete and how quickly the file can be closed.

Within the framework of a final contact, program delivery staff should:

  • review the agreement, amendments (if applicable), monitoring reports and any notes to file;
  • if warranted, do a final monitor using the Financial Monitoring Report Form or program equivalent form ;
  • complete the Close-Out Summary Report or the program’s equivalent form to document findings, comments and recommendations; in particular, any anomalies or difficulties the recipient encountered during the project’s life cycle, and how they have addressed them;
  • review interest and / or revenues generated by project activities and,
  • follow through on any special situations – disposal of capital assets, overpayments, audits -- as listed below.
Disposal of Capital Assets

The funding agreement includes a clause on how to dispose of the capital assets.  When applicable, the recipient will submit a request to dispose the capital assets acquired as a result of the project. Program delivery staff should assess the request to ensure that the capital assets will be disposed of in a manner approved by the funding program.  Only the Department can approve the disposal request for capital assets and a copy of the approval must be retained in the file.

Overpayments

An overpayment occurs when the recipient has received payments in excess of what they are eligible for. 

As per the Grants and Contributions Policy, once an overpayment has been identified, program delivery staff must:

  • inform the recipient both verbally and in writing of the amount owing;
  • ask the recipient to remit the overpaid amount, by cheque, to the Receiver General for Canada within 30 days.

If payment is not received within the 30 day time period, program delivery staff must:

  • Send an overpayment notice to the recipient and request that an overpayment be created in the Departmental Accounts Receivable System (DARS).
  • To establish an overpayment in DARS a request must be sent through the Accounting Services Catalogue under Account receivable (DARS) – Transaction Request (Establishment Request).
  • Program delivery staff must also record information about the DARS account in CSGC using  the Establish Overpayment in DARS screen. This will ensure that information is readily available to other program areas dealing with the same recipient, and;
  • Lastly, program delivery staff must add a note to file indicating that there is an overpayment registered in DARS with the date and the amount of the overpayment.

If payment or other satisfactory arrangements are not made within a reasonable amount of time, the Canada Revenue Agency has the responsibility for debt collection once it has been entered in DARS.

Any overpayments discovered after the project is closed should be recorded directly in DARS and documented in the CSGC as a note to file.

Please refer to CFOB’s Guideline on Manual Payments and Returned Money for the additional information on how to address an overpayment.

In some circumstances, an organization’s overpayment may be removed from the Department’s accounts receivable records after all reasonable collection efforts have been exhausted without success. This is known as a write-off.  Write-offs are recommended to the Department by Canada Revenue Agency and approved by the delegated authority.

Unlike the remission of an overpayment—where the overpayment is cancelled and the Crown gives up the right to resume collection at a future date—a write-off does not forgive or cancel the organization’s overpayment, and must meet the criteria of the Treasury Board Debt Write-off Regulations as being uncollectible. The Crown also reserves the right to recover the overpayment at a later date.

For additional information please refer to the CFOB policy on debt write-off.

Audits

The new Risk Assessment, Management and Mitigation (RAMM) approach will introduce a new audit strategy for departmental Gs&Cs programs. This section will therefore be revised as new information becomes available.

Auditing is the systematic examination and verification of accounting or project activity records that is undertaken either internally or by a qualified third party (such as a chartered accountant, certified general accountant or certified management accountant).

There are two main types of audits:

  1. Financial audit: covers concepts of reasonable assurance, completeness, management estimates, internal controls and presentation format for information assessed against Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). It helps the Department form an opinion as to whether financial statements and other financial information are presented fairly and agree with GAAP.
  2. Recipient audit: examines compliance with agreement provisions, confirming whether specified activities were undertaken, and claimed expenditures were for eligible costs.
Paying for Audits

Audits can be paid using:

  • Operations and Maintenance funds: The Department must pay the cost of monitoring, audit and evaluation activities related to transfer payment programs, unless the funding agreement contains a provision that specifies otherwise. In other words, if the Department contracts an external auditor to conduct the audit on behalf of the Department, it must do so using a service contract paid for using O&M funds. The audit report then becomes the property of the Department.
  • Contribution funds: Program delivery staff may invoke an existing audit provision in the funding agreement if one requires an outside auditor to review the project’s financial records and the cost has been included in the budget as an eligible expenditure.

To invoke this provision:

Determine first if the funds allocated for auditing expenses are sufficient, or if an amendment to the agreement is required;

  • if an amendment is required, calculate whether the agreement has reached its maximum level of contribution; and,
  • confirm the level of delegated authority required for approval.

When contribution funds are used, the audit report becomes the property of the organization. The Department, however, has the right to approve the selection of the external auditor and require that the auditor’s opinion be supported by signed, audited financial statements and a statement of disposition of federal contribution funds, including their eligibility. The Department can also ask the auditor to forward a copy of the audit to program delivery staff with written authorization from the organization.

12.2 Steps for Closing a File

Once the final project evaluation has been completed, one can start working through the more technical steps involved in closing a file.

These steps involve:

  • releasing the holdback amount;
  • making final payment;
  • completing the CSGC close-out;
  • writing the close-out summary report;
  • closing the project file; and,
  • monitoring post-agreement obligations.
Releasing the Holdback Amount

The retention of a holdback amount encourages recipients to submit final claim, activity reports and supporting documentation (if applicable) on time, and helps avoid overpayment situations.

The holdback can be issued once:

  • the recipient has complied with the agreement and completed all project activities in a satisfactory manner;
  • the project expenses are properly documented and supported;
  • the final claim, activity reports and supporting documentation (if applicable) are accurate and accepted as fairly representing eligible costs; and,
  • any other reports required as part of the agreement.

Once all these requirements are met, the documents required by the program delivery staff to initiate the final payment, de-commit remaining funds and close out the project in CSGC can be prepared.

Making Final Payments

The final payment can be issued once:

  • the final claim and supporting documentation (if applicable) has been received and verified;
  • the data in the CSGC View Financial Transactions screen, confirming that all financial issues have been resolved, has been reviewed;
  • the total on the claim is mathematically correct and, that the approved signing authority (identified on the claim or advance and activity report) has signed and dated it to certify the expenditures;
  • it has been ensured that the recipient has either disposed of all capital assets (as per the agreement) or negotiated a disposition plan;
  • if applicable, all financial or recipient audits required by the agreement have been received, and all related reports, indicating that all requirements have been met, have been accepted;
  • all recipient reports specified in agreement provisions, including the final activity report, have been received; and,
  • it has been confirmed that there is no outstanding overpayment.

Once the final payment has been issued, any remaining funds should be decommited. These funds will automatically be placed back into the program budget.

Completing the CSGC Close-out

In the CSGC, you must use the Complete Close-Out screen to:

  • Ensure there are no outstanding financial transactions in the system (i.e. status of pending, await settlement, await approval, approved, or cancel pending). If an outstanding commitment exists at the time of close-out, the CSGC automatically sends a transaction to SAP to close the commitment; and,
  • The balance of the unaccounted advances/ expenses must be zero. If the balance is not zero, an overpayment must be established in DARS.  Refer to overpayment section.
Writing the Close-out Summary Report

The Close-Out Summary Report is a brief evaluative summary of how the project performed; it contains information about the recipient, project status, project deliverables and total funding. This report often proves valuable to other program delivery staff that have no previous experience with the recipient and would like to research their project management capacity before considering them for future funding.

Program delivery staff must:

  • complete the Close-Out Summary Report within the CSGC;
  • have it approved;  and  
  • record approval in CSGC.

In essence, the close-out summary report is written to:

  • demonstrate how project objectives and priorities were met, activities completed, and timelines kept;
  • summarize project management;
  • outline project participant impacts and benefits, if applicable;
  • compare expected to actual results;
  • summarize monitoring activities completed during the project, as per the Assess Project Risk - Monitoring Plan developed earlier;
  • identify any issues encountered;
  • describe the disposal of capital assets, if applicable;
  • note any overpayments;
  • recommend whether to enter into an agreement with this recipient again; and,
  • indicate actions requiring follow up, such as repayment,  outstanding reports or audit requirements.

Program delivery staff observations and comments are drawn from information obtained from reports, monitoring, on-site visits, and correspondence with:

  • the recipient;
  • other project staff;
  • participants; and,
  • community and other stakeholders.

The report should present objective facts in a professional manner, as the report and all other documentation in the project file, are accessible to the public through the Access to Information Act.

Closing the Project File

Once a project has ended and all of the CSGC close-out functions have been completed, it is time to close both the hard copy and e-copy (in CSGC) of the project file. Before one can do this, one must ensure the file is complete, well-documented and free of drafts, unnecessary papers and duplicate materials. It is not expected that every electronic documents and correspondence related to the project file be printed and saved in the paper file.  The information should be saved and stored according to its submitted format.  Electronic documents should be saved in CSGC under Supporting Documentation, while hard copies of the documents should be retained in the physical project file.  One does not have to mirror the other, however; together, they must have all the elements of a complete project file.

Importantly, program delivery staff must check with the program in order to identify which of the following elements are required either in the hard copy or electronic version to complete the project file:

  • the signed application, including negotiated changes;
  • any application attachments, such as annual and audit reports;
  • documented evidence of community support;
  • documented consultations with the member of Parliament, union representatives  and others;
  • the Proposal Assessment, Recommendation and Approval Form and detailed notes of the assessment;
  • ensure the Schedule Monitor Details screens in the CSGC are complete;
  • the agreement itself with original signatures, including schedules and the Forecast of Project Expenditures;
  • any amendments to the agreement;
  • completed monitoring reports: On-Site Monitoring Report;
  • follow-up items;
  • correspondence with organization;
  • original claim form or advance and activity reports for all periods;
  • any internal correspondence between staff, peers and managers relating to the project;
  • any notes to file (in addition to CSGC notes to file) summarizing phone conversations and action coming out of those conversations (time, place, issue, commitments);
  • participant tracking data;
  • signed File Close-Out Summary Report;
  • DARS check;
  • documents related to authorized purchases of capital assets or equipment for persons with disabilities and confirmation of disposal of these items at close-out; and,
  • any additional program-specific documentation and checklists.

The file can be considered closed once the file content checklist has been completed.

The responsibility for retaining official files varies from region to region. The Departmental Security Officer (DSO) advises departmental staff with respect to meeting legislative requirements, storage, archiving and disposal of government materials. Program delivery staff should consult with the manager to confirm the appropriate procedures for the particular office or region.

12.3 Monitoring Post-agreement Obligations

In some cases, the recipient is obligated to supply additional information—such as follow-up surveys and evaluation reports— to the program, according to timelines that extend beyond the project end date. A file may, therefore, be in the Close-Out phase in CSGC and final payments reconciled in these situations before the outstanding materials are submitted. This phase must remain open until all outstanding information has been received and recorded in CSGC.

If the recipient does not meet post-agreement obligations, program delivery staff must contact the recipient at least twice by phone or in writing to request the additional information. Within one month of the second attempt, one should:

  • outline the recipient’s post-agreement obligations and document the attempts to contact them; and,
  • inform them in writing and by phone that their failure to comply with these post-agreement obligations has been documented in the file and will be taken into consideration if they apply for departmental program funding in the future.

Once the non-compliance has been documented in CSGC, the file can then be closed.
